webTitle: Vialli victim of Chelsea player power

fields.headline: Vialli victim of Chelsea player power
fields.standfirst:
Italian pays the price for his failures in man-management
David Lacey comment
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli yesterday paid the price for becoming a clone of the man he grew to hate, the man who was manager before him, Ruud Gullit.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli yesterday paid the price for becoming a clone of the man he grew to hate, the man who was manager before him, Ruud Gullit.

Chelsea's decision to sack Vialli was largely precipitated by his distant and insensitive treatment of players, especially Gianfranco Zola, which came straight from the Gullit manual of man-management. Such behaviour played a major part in the Dutchman's downfall. Now it has done for Vialli.

Chelsea will seek a replacement who can not only inspire the team as a person but bring the sort of success to Stamford Bridge that their millionaire status demands. The bookmakers have made Zola favourite, though Chelsea may now be tempted to go for someone with a proven track record. There has also long been speculation that George Graham is destined for the Stamford Bridge hot-seat.

The axe fell on Vialli without warning. The day began with news that Chelsea had made an inquiry about signing Vialli's friend and former Juventus team-mate Paolo di Canio from West Ham. But by the afternoon Vialli himself had become the story. He was summoned to a meeting with the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates and the managing director Colin Hutchinson at 5pm yesterday, and it was decided to terminate the Italian's contract forthwith.

If the move was swift when it came, it was hardly a complete shock. Chelsea's results have been disappointing by the club's newly adopted high standards. After finishing third in the Premiership two years ago, Vialli could only manage fifth last season, not only failing to win the title, but missing out on a lucrative Champions League place as well.

Bates showed his impatience with Chelsea's inconsistent domestic form last season and there was also criticism of Vialli's insistence on rotating his strikers.

This summer, in an attempt to meet Bates's aspirations, Vialli promised to direct all his efforts and those of the team to lifting the Premiership title. He was given £23m to spend on players to underpin that pledge but the season went wrong almost as soon as it started.

Unrest among players both present and recently departed began to surface in the press. Frank Lebeouf, Didier Deschamps and Dan Petrescu all voiced their unhappiness at the way the club was being managed. And the stress began to show in fractured performances on the field.

Chelsea have managed one win in their five games this season leaving them a disappointing 10th in the table - a dismal record which includes surrendering a two-goal lead at home to Arsenal and losing to the Premiership's poor relations, Bradford City.

But it was Vialli's treatment of Zola which upset the Chelsea hierarchy. The striker could not understand why a man whom he once classed as a friend changed so much once he took charge of Chelsea in February 1998, his first managerial role.

Suddenly Vialli started to blank Zola and drop him without explanation. It may have been an attempt to avoid charges of favouritism and to separate himself from his old team-mates now he was in charge. But it was insensitive and unsuccessful.

Yesterday the only player to speak up in support of Vialli was Chelsea's England left-back Graeme le Saux who said: "All the players are shocked and no one had any idea this was happening."

Chelsea would only supply an official statement, but that also intimated that Vialli's exit was about more than the team's performance on the field. "Chelsea have great admiration for the achievements of Gianluca Vialli in his two-and-a-half years in charge of team affairs and would like to place on record our appreciation for his services to Chelsea Football Club," said the official release. "However, the club feels that in a wider context it is in our best interests to seek a change of direction."

Vialli now joins the list of great players who struggled to translate their skills into management. He won two league titles and a European Cup while playing in Italy, but at Stamford Bridge he could not bring home either - and neither did he look like doing so. The European Cup Winners' Cup, FA Cup and Worthington Cup that he did manage were not enough to satisfy Chelsea's demand for prestige or their craving for revenue.

The club said that an announcement on Vialli's successor will be made in due course. For the immediate future the current staff, including Graham Rix and Ray Wilkins, will take charge of the team, beginning with tomorrow's Uefa Cup tie against St Gallen.

Bridge of sighs and sideswipes

'Errors of judgment have been made with the rotation system [but] it's also down to the players' attitude when they go out on the pitch'
Ken Bates, Nov 1999

'Vialli has problems with everybody, with Albert Ferrer and many others. It's normal for a coach to get on with his lads, but not him'
Frank Leboeuf, August 2000

'The fans wanted me to play but Vialli didn't. And his word is final. Vialli never said anything to me but the message was very clear'
Dan Petrescu, August 2000 'You could imagine the effect inside the Chelsea dressing room. This kind of thing is poison to team spirit and, with things how they are at Chelsea, simply disastrous'
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink (after Arsenal pulled back two-goal deficit, Sept 6)
'I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became'
Didier Deschamps, August 2000

'At the end of the day it is going to make us a better side. We have to aim for the Champions League' Peter Osgood, yesterday

webTitle: Champions League: Arsenal bonus as Silvinho goes solo

fields.headline: Arsenal bonus as Silvinho goes solo
fields.standfirst:
Silvinho 33
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Arséne Wenger will not be booking flights for the final in Milan next May on the basis of this poor performance but at least it gave a perfect start to Arsenal's Champions League campaign thanks to a moment of magic from Silvinho.
fields.body:
Arséne Wenger will not be booking flights for the final in Milan next May on the basis of this poor performance but at least it gave a perfect start to Arsenal's Champions League campaign thanks to a moment of magic from Silvinho.

The Brazilian left-back scored another memorable goal to put Arsenal on course for the second phase, but they will have to do better than this to tread with the best.

After two successive failures in the premier European club competition, a repetition is unthinkable for Arsenal. Yet they can hardly have expected such an easy ride against opponents who came into this match fresh from a fortnight's rest and with seven wins out of seven.

Uppermost in Wenger's mind was avoiding defeat by the team he believes will vie with Arsenal for the second group place behind Lazio. There had been much evidence last season to build his confidence as his players had visited Fiorentina, Barcelona and Solna without defeat. Home form has tended to be their undoing.

Arsenal's defence was still without the captain Tony Adams, but Wenger, who has said he will sign no more French players because it could upset the balance of the squad, was able to recall Patrick Vieira since the midfielder's five-game suspension applies only to domestic matches.

Not surprisingly Vieira and his team-mates spent much of the early stages on the back foot in a 20,000-seat stadium, packed despite a quadrupling of admission prices for the occasion. Arsenal's tendency to concede possession hardly helped their cause, although Sparta seemed desperately to lack a cutting edge. When a mistake by Fredrik Ljungberg allowed Petr Papousek to present Marek Kincl with a clear sight of goal the striker sent his shot wildly off target.

For a team usually so full of pace and vitality in attack, Arsenal began disappointingly. A free-kick by Thierry Henry never threatened to beat Tomas Postulka and when Ljungberg atoned for his sloppiness by curling a cross on to Henry's head, the Frenchman nodded wide. As the Arsenal players struggled to establish a rhythm Sparta grew in confidence, forcing several corners. From one Jiri Novotny brought out an instinctive from David Seaman with a header, but shortly after the half-hour a piece of Brazilian brilliance changed the direction of the match.

There seemed no route to goal when Silvinho picked up a pass from Robert Pires near the left-hand edge of the penalty area. But the full-back expertly flicked the ball through his legs, manoeuvred it on to his favoured left foot and, after weaving past a couple of de fenders, he lifted a shot over the advancing Postulka, the ball creeping in via a post.

If his goal against Chelsea was spectacularly explosive this effort was memorable for balance and skill. It gave the 26-year-old his third goal in as many matches and continued an impressive rate of scoring by Arsenal left-backs after Ashley Cole's strike at Bradford on Saturday. So much for the multimillion-pound strikers.

Soon afterwards Nwankwo Kanu worked room on the edge of the area for a shot which Postulka palmed away. Although Arsenal occasionally looked unconvincing at the back, their grip on proceedings began to grow.

A Jiri Movotany header, which drifted wide of the far post early in the second half, offered a reminder to Arsenal that the game was far from won and also provided the sig nal for a sustained spell of Sparta pressure which left Arsenal looking increasingly vulnerable. When Papousek's cross from the right found Kincl unmarked with only Seaman to beat, Wenger must have been grateful that the striker was again ponderous and that Martin Keown's strong challenge was deemed fair by the French referee.

Vieira lunged to make an im portant block when a Seaman punch was returned by Joses Obajdin from the edge of the area, and then Papousek summed up Sparta's weakness by shooting into the side netting when Pavel Novotny allowed him a clear sight of goal. Sparta Prague (4-4-2): Postulka; Mynar (Flachbart, 85min), Bolf, J Novotny, Grygera; Papousek (Prohaszka, 79), Z Svoboda, P Novotny, Rosicky; Kincl (Siegl, 62), Obajdin.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Luzhny, Silvinho; Ljungberg (Vivas, 80), Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry (Wiltord, 77). Referee: G Veissière (France).

webTitle: Let's save the race card for real racism

fields.headline: Let's save the race card for real racism
fields.standfirst: Work unlimited
fields.trailText: The way we work
fields.body:
The states of America are united by at least one characteristic: an obsession with race. White suburbanites bemoan the loss of their cities to crime, drugs and - by extension - black neighbourhoods. When they say, "It's a jungle down there", you're supposed to know what they mean. Black community leaders wonder out loud why the shops in their areas are owned by recently arrived Koreans. US cities are divided cleanly along ethnic axes - an enduring American apartheid.

George W Bush put almost all the black members of the Republican party on the stage at his convention to prove his open-mindedness. Al Gore argues that there needs to be a greater national awareness of racism before any progress is possible.

Actually, the awareness of race as an issue could not be higher. What might be needed, conversely, is to take the race issue down the agenda - and take some of the political heat out of a debate which has become distorted by party political point-scoring, white guilt and overzealous legal action.

Nowhere is a new approach more needed than in the workplace. Racism in any form stains the working environment, and has to be stamped out. But hypersensitivity about colour or religious affiliation can be counterproductive. A friend of mine is a senior civil servant in the US government. He is an ultra-progressive, humane, open-minded white man. (Oh, and he's gay. In America, where group membership is minutely calibrated, that probably matters). He is currently under investigation for anti-semitic and racist behaviour.

A Jewish woman has accused him of overlooking her for a position because of her faith. The process entails interviews with equal opportunities officers and rigorous questioning of his own beliefs. The fact that he was unaware she was Jewish makes no difference. And an African-American man has accused him of racism after being suspended for sexual harassment. (This is where workplace politics get really sticky.) The man in question placed his hand on a female colleague's bottom and squeezed, in full view of a dozen people, in the office canteen. (Oh, she's black, too. In America that definitely matters.)

US managers say that it is many more times more difficult to fire, discipline or warn a non-white employee for fear of lawsuits and bad PR. This is crazy. An equal society is one in which people are treated on the basis of their abilities and effort, not colour or creed. This must work both ways - in firing as well as hiring. Otherwise, firms will be reluctant to hire people from ethnic minorities in the first place - not because they are racist, but because they are afraid of being labelled as such if the recruit is not up to the job and has to be dismissed.

The problem is that a whole industry of lawyers, lobbyists, politicians, equal opportunities officers and human resources specialists has been built on the premise that US citizens are incapable of acting in an enlightened fashion. And few are prepared to take this lobby on, for fear of being accused of racism themselves.

None of which is to say that racism is over and done with. Far from it. Or that there should not be the strictest sanctions for those who act in discriminatory ways. But America needs a dose of the optimism about human nature enshrined in its constitution, and echoed by leaders such as Martin Luther King. Real racism is bad enough: there's no need to see it lurking everywhere.

Strangely, there is one form of prejudice that the US endorses enthusiastically - ageism. At a conference in New York last week, the convenor asked all the "young people, whose enthusiasm, energy and ability to think outside the box are so needed" to stand up. This being America, a few dozen eager youths leapt to their feet to receive a ripple of applause. At a stroke the convenor therefore insulted anybody not defined as "young" and patronised those who were.

In a separate session, a speaker invited his 12-year-old son, who spent the entire time playing a handheld computer game (and it was difficult to blame him), to tell the audience about his concerns for the future. On hearing his name, the young man in question looked up, startled, and said: "Well, if an asteroid hit us, that would be really really bad, wouldn't it?" At times like this, an asteroid strike seems like the least we deserve.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk

fields.headline: Nasdaq is no white knight
fields.standfirst:
Cruickshank ditches London-Frankfurt merger in attempt to see off OM

Leader
fields.trailText: Nasdaq, the US hi-tech stock market, has ruled out bidding for the London Stock Exchange which yesterday abandoned its unpopular merger with the City's German rival.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Nasdaq, the US hi-tech stock market, has ruled out bidding for the London Stock Exchange which yesterday abandoned its unpopular merger with the City's German rival.

Sources close to Nasdaq, which had been cited as a potential "white knight" to rescue London from the clutches of OM of Sweden, said yesterday that the US exchange would press for a "pan-European transatlantic partnership". It may, however, be prepared to back a bid by a wider range of European exchanges for London.

Confusion about the future of the 200-year-old London exchange mounted last night when Don Cruickshank, the chairman, said that he would talk to anyone about a potential bid. Mr Cruickshank insisted he would "see off" the £808m offer by OM and carve an alternative route to the creation of a pan-European stock exchange in which London would play a leading role.

He said that to put up a credible defence the London exchange needed to withdraw its merger plan with the Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt - which might yet mount its own bid for the London exchange.

"London is going to take the initiative," Mr Cruickshank said, indicating that he would resume talks with the Germans if OM's bid was defeated.

Failure to cement the German merger continues to deny Mr Cruickshank and his fellow directors stock options linked to the deal. The exchange's shares yesterday closed just below £30, almost double the level at which they started traded a month ago.

The chairman of OM, the owner of the Stockholm exchange which derailed the plan by bidding for London, stands to increase his bonus by £500,000 a year if the audacious ploy is successful.

According to the OM offer document posted to shareholders in the London exchange yesterday, Olof Stenhammar, the chairman, has a profit-related deal under which he receives 1% of the group's income. This would grow by £50m if OM took over the London exchange.

The decision by the London exchange to end its merger with the Deutsche Börse clears the way for the Frankfurt institution to launch its own bid for London, a move which was not ruled out in some City circles last night. Other potential bidders were cited as Euronext, the exchange made up of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels bourses, or Liffe, the London International Financial Futures Exchange, which last night ruled out such a move.

The Deutsche Börse was understood to be disappointed by London's decision to pull out. Its chief executive, Werner Seifert, said he would "examine alternative action".

Smaller stockbrokers greeted the London exchange's decision with relief. Brian Winterflood, chairman of Winterflood Securities which has staged a vocal anti-merger campaign, said the London exchange now had its work cut out to "rebuild a lot of bridges".

The London exchange is expected to use tomorrow's annual general meeting to set out its new strategic course.


Changing tune

"The iX proposals are driven not by politics or patriotism but by hard-headed business logic ... there will be more choice for investors and more investors for companies"

Don Cruickshank, Sept 4

"A bog-standard, medium-sized hostile takeover bid"

Don Cruickshank on the OM bid, Sept 2

"I am really quite confident that the vote will go through, which means the merger will be completed by November ..."

Don Cruickshank, Aug 11

"It is good news that the fragmentation and bickering about who is going to be champion of Europe is going away"

Investment banker, May 4

The exchange's shares yesterday closed just below £30, almost double the level at which they started traded a month ago. The chairman of OM, the owner of the Stockholm exchange which derailed the plan by bidding for London, stands to increase his bonus by £500,000 a year if the audacious ploy is successful. According to the OM offer document posted to shareholders in the London exchange yesterday, Olof Stenhammar, the chairman, has a profit-related deal under which he receives 1% of the group's income. This would grow by £50m if OM took over the London exchange. The decision by the London exchange to end its merger with the Deutsche Börse clears the way for the Frankfurt institution to launch its own bid for London, a move which was not ruled out in some City circles last night. Other potential bidders were cited as Euronext, the exchange made up of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels bourses, or Liffe, the London International Financial Futures Exchange, which last night ruled out such a move. The Deutsche Börse was understood to be disappointed by London's decision to pull out. Its chief executive, Werner Seifert, said he would "examine alternative action". Smaller stockbrokers greeted the London exchange's decision with relief. Brian Winterflood, chairman of Winterflood Securities which has staged a vocal anti-merger campaign, said the London exchange now had its work cut out to "rebuild a lot of bridges". The London exchange is expected to use tomorrow's annual general meeting to set out its new strategic course. webTitle: Byers gets tough on PO bank

fields.headline: Byers gets tough on PO bank
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the secretary of state for trade and industry, last night told the big banks they should participate in the establishment of the Post Office-based "universal" bank to provide accounts for the poor.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the secretary of state for trade and industry, last night told the big banks they should participate in the establishment of the Post Office-based "universal" bank to provide accounts for the poor.

In a summit with the chairmen and chief executives of the banking groups, Mr Byers was believed to have made it clear government money would be made available to help with set-up costs.

Some operators have been critical of the "universal" bank, which is at the core of the government's aim to provide a lifeline to the PO network.

The banks' concerns are based on the potential set-up costs and the operation of the new entity.

They feel it duplicates efforts led by the Treasury to create basic accounts for people without them.

Mr Byers was believed to have used yesterday's meeting as an opportunity to provide details of how the bank would work, using the business plan drawn up by the PO as the basis for his presentation.

The PO wants to set up the bank under a new brand name to try to address some of the banks' concerns about its reputation in the industry.

It also understood that the PO expects the government to inject some cash into the creation of the operation.

The banks last night insisted that they had attended the meeting with an open mind, but the British Bankers' Association has warned that the so-called universal bank could carry the stigma of being a poor people's bank.

webTitle: Sterling follows euro's record breaking fall

fields.headline: Sterling follows euro's record breaking fall
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Sterling caught the backlash yesterday from the euro's record breaking fall on the foreign exchanges when the pound was dragged down to a 14-year low against the dollar.
fields.body:
Sterling caught the backlash yesterday from the euro's record breaking fall on the foreign exchanges when the pound was dragged down to a 14-year low against the dollar.

It dropped below $1.40 for the first time since it was ejected from the ERM in 1993, at one point falling as far as $1.3953, its lowest level since early 1986. It recovered slightly to close in London at $1.4058.

Analysts said the pound had been the victim of renewed euro weakness as the single currency plumbed fresh lows against the dollar for the second day. "The market had been looking at sterling as a serious safe haven within the European Union as opposed to the euro zone," said Steven Saywell, currency analyst at Fuji Bank. "But with UK growth and interest rates close to peaking, the attractiveness of the UK against the euro zone has been diminished at a time of renewed confidence in the US economy."

Nick Parsons, currency strategist at Commerzbank, said the pound had been one of the worst performing currencies in the world in the past month, even falling against emerging market currencies like the Hungarian forint, Czech crown and Romanian leu. Some analysts said the pound was falling into step with the euro as traders detect more enthusiasm from the government for an early referendum on euro membership.

"The diversification argument of sterling against the euro is starting to go away with the government assuming more commitment to membership or at least driving towards a referendum at some point in the next few years," said Jake Moore, currency strategist at Barclays Capital in London.

The euro reached a record low of 85.53 cents against the dollar, before clambering back above 86 cents ahead of a speech from the governor of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg.

Mr Duisenberg insisted that the euro's slump defied economic fundamentals.

fields.headline: Southern fried boogie
fields.standfirst:
Little Feat
Forum, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Little Feat
Forum, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
There were three groups who vividly chronicled life in post-Woodstock America. The Band sought refuge from the psychedelic intensity of the period in the country's roots. Steely Dan had at least one eye on the future. Then there were Little Feat, who seemed to be the most comfortable in the here and now, making a new kind of party music out of blues, country, funk, R&B and rock'n'roll.

Their good-time boogie was offset by the idiosyncratic vision of mainman and former art-rocker Lowell George. Without Lowell (he died in 1979 from a heart attack), however, Little Feat are a headless Southern-fried chicken of a group - an exemplary bar band, no more, no less. Here to promote their latest album Chinese Work Songs, there is no denying the technical excellence of the six experts in their chosen field (keyboards, two guitars, bass, drums, percussion, plus gutsy, ballsy vocalist Shaun Murphy - a woman, by the way), five of whom have been playing with the band for almost three decades. But singer, guitarist and de facto leader Paul Barrere, who joined the Feat for their highly regarded third album, Dixie Chicken, doesn't have George's eccentric sensibility. Instead, he simply acts as cheerleader for a two-hour display of dexterous musicianship.

If only they could ally their polish and professionalism to the sort of succinct melodies they used to knock out during their heyday. Tonight, the titles merely provide parentheses within which each player solos to the best of his ability. There is a studied, scientific precision to this sloppy, loose music, and yet the audience clearly finds it all quite tasty.

Barrere and bassist Kenny Gradney do some formation strutting. Barrere and Tackett contort their faces. Shaun Murphy hollers and whoops like Bonnie Raitt. A touch of slide geetar here and honky tonk piano there unleashes the spirit of the Grand Ol' Opry. It's all very impressive. Still, you can't help feeling they are playing more for each other than for us, intricate cross-rhythms, slap bass, duelling lead guitars and all. This ain't communication, it's masturbation.

fields.headline: An ache at heart
fields.standfirst:
Navy Pier
Soho Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Navy Pier
Soho Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
They are rare, those people who are so comfortable in their own skin that they can swear they have never pretended to be something that they are not. Conmen and fugitives take impersonation to the limits, stealing other people's lives. But what about writers? They steal others' feelings and experiences and put them to their own use, and they live other lives through the creation of their characters. They are not quite themselves.

But in American John Corwin's absorbing little play, Kurt and Martin - one a successful writer, the other an apparent failure - go much further. Through treachery and circumstance they end up effectively living what might have been the life of the other.

The conundrum at the heart of this slow burn of an evening that unravels like an intellectual thriller is too crucial to the plot to give away. But Corwin uses it brilliantly to consider the slipperiness of truth, the nature of storytelling, the creative fictions we all weave and the authenticity of our own experience- indeed, to ask whether being acknowledged as a writer may actually turn you into one.

By rights this shouldn't work as theatre at all. Corwin's script takes the form of a series of intercut speeches from the four protagonists that only make a complete story when put together like a complicated jigsaw puzzle. Abigail Morris's brave production keeps it simple, with the four sitting in a line in comfy chairs and communicating more with the audience than with each other.

The dislocated effect is utterly compelling with overtones of both the therapist's consulting room and a more sedate version of the Jerry Springer Show. It creates a portrait of a vast, competitive, modern America where one big city is interchangeable with another and people lead fragmented, isolated lives. Friendship, love and companionship are disposable, only success is valued. Nobody connects.

The writing is clever and smart but has an ache at the heart of each laugh, and the stunning young cast don't miss a trick bringing out every nuance in the text. Not a huge play, but one to send you out into the night arguing about the rights and wrongs of Martin, Kurt, Iris and Liv's behaviour as if they were real people, not just figments of a writer's imagination.

Until October 7. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

fields.headline: Tasteful whispers
fields.standfirst:
Arco
New End Theatre, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Arco
New End Theatre, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
Their name says it all. Arco, when written in a musical score, tells string players to use their bow rather than pluck with their fingers. To be gentle, not heavy-handed. So there will be no guitar smashing tonight, then. Not that the trio that takes to the odd surroundings of this tiny theatre look capable of such rock'n'roll behaviour. In fact Chris Healey, his identical twin Nick and Dave Milligan look more likely to refuse that overdraft you wanted.

They wear quizzical expressions as they look about. The stage still bears traces of the play that is currently being performed on other weeknights: there are reflecting stars dangling from the ceiling and a metallic Polaris missile in one corner.

"Thanks for coming to this truly bizarre setting," Chris Healey says chirpily. "I hope it won't be a bizarre evening." He settles in a chair, picks up his acoustic guitar and begins Speak, the opening track from Arco's upcoming debut album Coming to Terms, without any fuss. Chris sings this melancholy tale of failing love in a startlingly direct voice of uncomplicated woe. "How can I speak, you've taken all the words, nothing to say, when you know you can't be heard," he sighs, as Milligan's McCartney-esque bass plods and Nick Healey barely taps the drums.

This is low lo-fi: whispers of songs that are overheard for two minutes then fade away. But their brevity only adds to their power. The crowd - all 60 of us - wait for each note to disappear before daring to breathe and interrupt the awed silence. Which is strange considering the workmanlike approach the band themselves take. As they swap instruments and roam around the stage, Milligan with his bare feet and bowl haircut, Nick wearing his permanently glum expression, Chris jokes with the crowd and eases the intense atmosphere. "Do you want the downbeat one or the really downbeat one?" he smiles, gently playing another ode to heartbreak while his cohorts watch respectfully.

He is very much in control of events, but a less likely frontman would be hard to find. Or a finer observer of human frailities, capturing that moment just before the sun comes up and the big questions get asked. But while the lyrics are sharp, the music floats, inducing a calm sleepiness as it flows. An hour in Arco's company is the aural equivalent of a day in a flotation tank. It may take a bit of getting used to but you will feel better in the end.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Inflation means a £2 pension rise
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's disgruntled pensioners are likely to receive a £2 increase in the basic state pension next year as a result of the increase in the rate of inflation over the past year, according to figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's disgruntled pensioners are likely to receive a £2 increase in the basic state pension next year as a result of the increase in the rate of inflation over the past year, according to figures released yesterday.

Next April's rise will be around three times as high as last year's 75p-a-week adjustment - decried as miserly and insulting by pensioners' lobbying groups.

Although the latest data from the office for national statistics showed that last month's petrol price war shaved the annual inflation rate from 3.3% to 3%, the increase in energy costs over the past year will help to give the elderly a slightly bigger weekly increase.

State pensions are uprated each year in line with the September rise in headline inflation. Although that figure will not be known until next month, the recent jump in oil prices should help to keep inflation at around its current level.

Last month's fall in the head line rate was accompanied by an easing in the underlying rate - which excludes mortgage interest payments - to 1.9%, equalling its lowest level since the series began in 1975.

Ferocious competitive pressures in the high street meant that the government's preferred measure on inflation came in below its 2.5% target for the 17th successive month. Analysts said that the benign state of cost pressures shortened the odds on the next move in interest rates being down, though some warned that the Bank of England might be concerned at the inflationary implications of sterling's fall to a 14-year-low against the dollar.

Using the European Union's method for calculating the cost of living - the harmonised index of consumer prices - Britain's inflation rate remains comfortably the lowest in the EU.

Britain has an HICP inflation rate of 0.6%, compared to 1.3% for the next lowest country, Sweden, 2.2% for the EU on average and 5.9% for the worst performing country, Ireland.

webTitle: Four ways to avoid football's transfer meltdown

fields.headline: Four ways to avoid transfer meltdown and the clock is now ticking
fields.standfirst: Taskforce seeks a system balancing movement and money
fields.trailText: Work begins in earnest today to find a replacement for the transfer fee and avoid the doomsday scenario of total abolition. Martin Thorpe and Nick Tsatsas outlines the options.
fields.body:
Work begins in earnest today to find a replacement for the transfer fee and avoid the doomsday scenario of total abolition.

A six-man panel called the Transfer Taskforce, with the European Commission breathing down their necks, will set about devising an alternative to the current system acceptable to Brussels.

It will not be easy. The task force wants a formula which retains the benefits of of paying transfer fees for players under contract moving between clubs - redistribution of funds, contract stability and incentives for clubs to develop younger players - while avoiding the flaw: restriction of the free movement of labour required under European Union law.

The deadline for proposals is October 31 and there will be further opportunity for discussions until the end of the year.

Today in Brussels a taskforce delegation meets EC representatives to discuss the terms of engagement - broadly what will be acceptable and what will not.

Tomorrow the whole taskforce will hold its first meeting at Uefa's headquarters in Nyon, near Geneva, to discuss options and strategies.

Gordon Taylor, a member of the taskforce as head of the European players' union Fipro, is particularly concerned about youth development. He wants to end all international transfers of players under 18 and a compensation system set up for the movement of players under 24.

Hope is based on the encouraging signals from the EC recently that it is willing to treat sport as a special case under the Treaty of Rome.

So what alternatives do the taskforce have to play with? Here are four possibilities.

Compensation

A rigid formula, similar to that proposed for players aged under 24, to set compensation to be paid by the buying club for a player instead of a transfer fee. The formula, written into the player's contract, would take into account elements such as the player's salary, the term remaining on his contract, time he has been with the club, age, experience (ie, international caps, first-team appearances, etc).

Buy-out clauses

A common practice on the continent, particularly in Spain. A player's contract will contain a clause stipulating the fee (agreed between player and club at the time that contract is signed) payable if another club wishes to recruit him. If that fee is met, then he is free to move - as in the case of Luis Figo when he recently moved from Barcelona to Real Madrid.

Two difficulties arise: a player will want a buy-out fee that is as small as possible so it might be easily met and in some cases so there is more money available to raise his salary. But his club will want a high fee in the hope of deterring prospective purchasers or to maximise the player's value.

This system is not, however, a solution to the problem of ensuring free movement.

For instance, Rivaldo recently renegotiated his Barcelona contract, agreeing to a buy-out clause setting his next transfer at £106m.

It is ludicrous to suggest this clause does anything other than restrict his freedom of movement; the fact he agreed to it does nothing to alter that proposition.

So buy-outs would have to be capped or regulated, raising their own problems.

Loyalty bonus

One of the best ways to ensure loyalty is to buy it. Clubs could offer bonuses on top of salary, determined by length of service.

For instance, executives in the City are often awarded substantial bonuses under "long-term incentive plans" whose payment is deferred for a set period of time. If the individual ceases employment, the bonus will not be paid.

Such arrangements are a disincentive to move. The reality, however, is that, if the player is sufficiently in demand, then the prospective employer will often agree to compensate him for a lost bonus.

Central pot

The football associations of each European country would place a levy on their clubs, based perhaps on a proportion of each club's annual turnover. This central pot would then be used to compensate clubs who have lost players during the season based on an agreed formula. As a solution, however, this is an outsider, not least because of the inherent problems in administrating it.

Nick Tsatsas is an employment lawyer with Clifford Chance Limited Liability Partnership

But his club will want a high fee in the hope of deterring prospective purchasers or to maximise the player's value. This system is not, however, a solution to the problem of ensuring free movement. For instance, Rivaldo recently renegotiated his Barcelona contract, agreeing to a buy-out clause setting his next transfer at £106m. It is ludicrous to suggest this clause does anything other than restrict his freedom of movement; the fact he agreed to it does nothing to alter that proposition. So buy-outs would have to be capped or regulated, raising their own problems. Loyalty bonus One of the best ways to ensure loyalty is to buy it. Clubs could offer bonuses on top of salary, determined by length of service. For instance, executives in the City are often awarded substantial bonuses under "long-term incentive plans" whose payment is deferred for a set period of time. If the individual ceases employment, the bonus will not be paid. Such arrangements are a disincentive to move. The reality, however, is that, if the player is sufficiently in demand, then the prospective employer will often agree to compensate him for a lost bonus. Central pot The football associations of each European country would place a levy on their clubs, based perhaps on a proportion of each club's annual turnover. This central pot would then be used to compensate clubs who have lost players during the season based on an agreed formula. As a solution, however, this is an outsider, not least because of the inherent problems in administrating it. Nick Tsatsas is an employment lawyer with Clifford Chance Limited Liability Partnership

webTitle: Defiant Ellis wins vote and digs in his heels

fields.headline: Defiant Ellis wins vote and digs in his heels
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis has told dissident shareholders he has no intention of leaving the club after an attempt to remove him from the board of directors was quashed yesterday.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis has told dissident shareholders he has no intention of leaving the club after an attempt to remove him from the board of directors was quashed yesterday.

Ellis, Villa chairman for the past 18 years, had to call a second ballot after the vote to re-elect him to the board at Friday's annual general meeting went against him.

The 77-year-old Ellis's position of being Villa's major shareholder with a 37% holding meant there was never any danger of the second ballot mirroring the first.

The voting figures confirmed as much. Of the 5,662,262 votes cast 5,580,976 were in favour of his re-election and 81,286 were against. Leaving aside Ellis's personal shareholding, there were 20 votes in favour of his re-election for every one against.

Friday's vote of no confidence had been masterminded by the newly formed Aston Villa Independent Suporters Association (AVISA) and Ellis used his re-election to condemn the group for its actions.

"It is regrettable that, having had an opportunity to have their voices heard, a small minority should still put the club to the extra time and expense of a ballot and another meeting when the outcome was a foregone conclusion," he said.

"I do not intend to leave this club which I have served for over 30 years and in which I continue to have a significant financial interest. In the final analysis myself and the supporters want the same thing - a successful team and long-term stability. I will continue to work to achieve that goal and would ask that we all get behind the manager and the team to help them fulfil our dream."

AVISA, however, is insistent it does not want Ellis to stand down as chairman but is seeking a reduction in his roles.

"There should be a clear division at the head of a company to ensure there is a balance of power," said a spokesman Jonathan Collett. "But, with Mr Ellis being chairman, chief executive and director of football, that is clearly not the case."

The former Wales and Everton goalkeeper Neville Southall, meanwhile, has confirmed that he has applied for the vacant manager's job at the Icelandic Second Division club Fram Reykjavik.

fields.headline: Campbell shows his worth
fields.trailText: Sol Campbell's future at Tottenham has been in doubt for months now as the England defender continually refuses to pledge his future to the club. But last night he helped bring them closer to the sort of success that might persuade him to stay with a second-half winner that returned Spurs to the top five in the Premiership.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Sol Campbell's future at Tottenham has been in doubt for months now as the England defender continually refuses to pledge his future to the club. But last night he helped bring them closer to the sort of success that might persuade him to stay with a second-half winner that returned Spurs to the top five in the Premiership.

West Ham are still without a victory this season, and though they fought hard and created chances, they remain rooted firmly to the bottom.

It would be a shame if they were eventually to go down, not least because of their adherence to the passing game and Harry Redknapp's endearing and enduring belief in the sort of maverick player who can be a bit of trouble but can't half play football.

In the youngsters Joe Cole, Michael Carrick and Rio Ferdinand West Ham also arguably possess three key members of a future England XI for whom the drop to First Division football would be less than ideal.

But while Redknapp reckons this is the best squad he has ever assembled, injury has hit badly and they came into the game having suffered their worst start to a season in the top flight since 1991-2 when they were relegated.

A groin strain deprived them of Davor Suker last night while suspension did for Igor Stimac. However the return from injury of Frederic Kanoute and Ferdinand compensated and the way West Ham set about their task suggested a team eager to avoid excuses and get on with the task of putting points on the board. Prompted by Cole's willingness to take players on and find space with eagle-eyed passes, West Ham created three scoreable chances in the first 20 minutes.

First Paolo di Canio, despite being under pressure on the left, deftly played in Kanoute, but the striker could only di rect his first-time shot straight at Neil Sullivan. A trademark 25-yard blast from Stuart Pearce also flew too close to the keeper while Carrick conjured an 18-yard shot which Sullivan did well to get down to.

Tottenham, with the regular defenders Chris Perry (injured) and Ben Thatcher (chest complaint) absent, were finding it hard to contain the visitors' ebullience and also create chances themselves, especially without their long-term injury victim Darren Anderton.

Les Ferdinand went close with a couple of headers and Tim Sherwood fired a tapped free-kick straight at Shaka Hislop before almost catching the keeper off his line with a header as Spurs pressed towards half-time.

But as the break beckoned, West Ham came even closer, Di Canio brilliantly playing Trevor Sinclair into the Tottenham area only for the wing-back to see his goal-bound shot saved by Sullivan's legs.

Spurs' plans were further disrupted 17 seconds after the restart when Luke Young was injured in a challenge with Cole and replaced by Ramon Vega. But Tottenham soon asserted themselves. In the space of a minute Pearce then Steve Lomas were forced to make crucial tackles in their own six-yard box. Oyvind Leonhardsen then just failed to get his head to Vega's cross from the right before blasting Ferdinand's nod-down over the bar from 12 yards.

West Ham took the onslaught in their stride and soon hit back, Joe Cole directing his narrow-angled shot straight at Hislop.

However Spurs continued to press and a goal duly arrived on 66 minutes, Leonhardsen swinging in a corner from the right. Campbell jumped above Kanoute and fired in a header from six yards which hit the bar, bounced down, hit Hislop on the back and rebounded over the line.

fields.headline: Anxious Advocaat joins in the mind games
fields.trailText: Sturm Graz touched down in Glasgow yesterday with their coach Ivica Osim all but dismissing his team's chances in their Group D match against Rangers.
fields.body:
A strange pyschology appears to be at work in Group D of the Champions League. Sturm Graz, the Austrian club who face Rangers in the opening match at Ibrox tonight, touched down in Glasgow yesterday with their coach Ivica Osim all but dismissing his team's chances. The only voice more imposing in terms of gloom has been that of Dick Advocaat, his opposite number at Rangers.

Fretting over failure, and ever under pressure from club chairmen, perhaps managers feel compelled to highlight their own teams' deficiencies. Certainly Advocaat has been busy in recent days talking up the Austrians' experience in this arena; for a previously unsung club this is Sturm's third successive outing in the Champions League.

Osim, by the same token, has lamented his inability to add to his squad before last month's European deadline. "Rangers should have much more quality than us," he said, outdoing even Scottish pessimism.

Despite some forlorn times in Europe which have helped Rangers keep their hubris in check, the truth is that the Scottish club should still have enough qualities to win.

Anything less than victory will be a severe blow for a proud club who are already five points behind Celtic in the championship and saved only by leaky Montrose from having the worst defensive record in Scotland. After unremitting success Advocaat is facing his rockiest period since arriving at Rangers from PSV two years ago.

"Our preparations have not been ideal," said Advocaat. "We've had to bring players back, such as Michael Mols and Artur Numan, who has only played two games so far, while Ronald de Boer has just joined us from Barcelona. Last season I'd say we were definitely better prepared because we had all our players who knew all their positions. We've been working hard on our routines."

In the longer term Advocaat's chances rest upon some fragile ligaments. Mols, their prized Dutch striker who has been out for a year since injuring a knee against Bayern Munich, is restored to the squad though still feeling creaky after returning in the 1-1 draw against Dundee on Saturday.

Mols is an exceptional player but the news yesterday that some fresh fluid has resurfaced on his knee will only add to suspicions about his fitness.

Jorg Albertz, Bert Konterman and Barry Ferguson, who has been suspended from domestic duty, have all been added to the squad.

 Kaiserslautern scored three late goals in seven minutes to secure a 3-1 victory over Bohemians in Dublin. Trevor Molloy almost started the evening in style, when he came close to scoring for the home side after 16 seconds, but he ended the evening in disgrace after a 43rd-minute red card for retaliation.

fields.headline: Chelsea sack Vialli
fields.standfirst: Who'll follow Vialli
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli has been sensationally sacked as manager of Chelsea - because of mounting player unrest at Stamford Bridge.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli has been sensationally sacked as manager of Chelsea - because of mounting player unrest at Stamford Bridge.

Shortly after 6pm, the club confirmed that Vialli had been "released from his duties" with immediate effect.

The club refused to elaborate, but according to reports, Vialli was told the news at a 5pm meeting with chairman Ken Bates and managing director Colin Hutchinson.

During the meeting Bates and Hutchinson expressed their "admiration" for the Italian's achievements during his two-and-a-half-year reign - but they concluded that "in a wider context it is in our best interests to seek a change of direction".

No successor has yet been appointed and "for the immediate future" the current staff, led by coach Graham Rix, will take charge of the team. Chairman Ken Bates is due to make a fuller statement at 7pm.

Vialli had been under increasing pressure after an unconvincing start to the season which had brought Chelsea just one win in their last five games. But it was the rumours of his falling out with several big-name players - including Gianfranco Zola, Frank Leboeuf and Albert Ferrer - which seems to have finally finished him off.

Vialli took over the job after Ruud Gullit fell out with Bates over a new contract in February 1998. And he achieved success in cup competitions - including the Coca-Cola Cup, the Cup Winners' Cup, and the FA Cup.

But despite victory in the Charity Shield against Manchester United being followed by an opening Premiership win against West Ham, Chelsea failed to win any of their following four league games - against Bradford, Aston Villa, Arsenal and Newcastle.

And with the Blues having only ever won the title once - back in 1955 - and with £23m invested in the squad over the summer and increasing rumours of unrest, Vialli was given no time in which to resurrect that faltering start.

webTitle: Who'll be the Luca man to follow be Vialli?

fields.headline: Who'll be the Luca man to follow be Vialli?
fields.trailText: The days when Chelsea appointed a relative unknown are long gone. So perhaps are the days of the player-coach. Ken Bates appears to believe the time has come for a tried and tested manager to take over at Stamford Bridge. Watch out for a low-risk, high-cost, well-known mover and shaker.
fields.body:
The days when Chelsea appointed a relative unknown are long gone. So perhaps are the days of the player-coach. Ken Bates appears to believe the time has come for a tried and tested manager to take over at Stamford Bridge. Watch out for a low-risk, high-cost, well-known mover and shaker.

Gianfranco Zola

The bookmakers' favourite, but could be seen as too risky by Bates. One of Vialli's problems was a lack of faith from senior players and the appointment of Zola or Dennis Wise could throw up the same obstacle.

George Graham

The Stamford Bridge rumour machine has him prepared to ditch White Hart Lane, where he his tenure has not been a bed of roses. Would enjoy the freedom to spend.

Terry Venables

Top notch credentials, but a dodgy financial history that may not endear him to the Stamford Bridge boardroom.

Sven-Goran Eriksson

The manager of Serie A champions Lazio has been linked to Chelsea in the past and has hinted that he would like to try his hand in England.

Johann Cruyff

Proven pedigree, took Barcelona to European Cup triumph in 1992.

Dino Zoff

Former Italy and Lazio coach would keep alive the Italian bloodline.

Frank Rijkaard

Former Holland coach but perhaps too close to Ruud Gullit in style and the player-manager tradition. Known to not rate Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Graham Rix

Temporary manager after Vialli's sacking. Criminal sex life and too risky an appointment.

Ray Wilkins

Already a club faithful but his managerial record hardly shines. Too risky.

fields.headline: Five steps to the sack
fields.standfirst: How Stamford Bridge fell down on Gianluca Vialli
fields.trailText: How Stamford Bridge fell down on Gianluca Vialli
fields.body:
1. The rotation system

Ruud Gullit introduced the concept of rotation to Stamford Bridge, but Vialli pursued it with vigour. The idea was to keep players fresh throughout a long season, but some players seemed to need more rest than others. While Marcel Desailly was almost ever-present in defence, players like Gianfranco Zola and Dan Petrescu were in and out of the side and Tore Andre Flo barely got a game. Not the best way to foster team spirit.

2. Last season's Premiership performance

Much was expected of Chelsea last season, following another summer of sizeable investment. But, aside from a 5-0 victory over Man Utd at Stamford Bridge, Luca's Blues never fired, and the failure of major signings like Chris Sutton and Didier Deschamps called Vialli's judgement into question.

3. The spat with Frank Leboeuf

Another summer of spending had left Chelsea many people's favourites for the title. But when Leboeuf described Vialli as "having problems with everybody" at the club, the shine began to come off. Leboeuf said he was disappointed with the way he was treated by his manager, and claimed that he was not alone. It seems he may have been right

4. Losing to Bradford

Following last season's disappointment, much was made in the press of the Blues' new resolve, mainly based on the quality of their performance in the Charity Shield against United. But Bradford at Valley Parade was the kind of fixture to put this theory to the test, and test it it did. Goals from Dean Windass and Benito Carbone beat the Blues, but in truth they were never in the game.

5. Dropping Gianfranco Zola against Newcastle

Saturday's visit to St James' Park resulted in another disappointing draw for Vialli's men following on from the 2-2 stalemate with Arsenal in midweek. But more disappointing for many was the absence of Gianfranco Zola from the starting XI, after what was considered his best performance for some time against the Gunners. It proved to be the last tactical mystery in Vialli's Stamford Bridge reign.

fields.headline: Vialli's factfile
fields.trailText: 1964 Born Cremona, Italy, July 9. The son of a millionaire, he is brought up in a castle.
fields.body:
1964 Born Cremona, Italy, July 9. The son of a millionaire, he is brought up in a castle.

1980 Signs for local club Cremonese, but his first full season is unspectacular with just five goals in 31 appearances.

1984 After scoring 10 goals for Cremonese, he is signed by Sampdoria. Makes it into double figures for six out of eight seasons at the Genoa-based side.

1985 Wins Italian Cup with Sampdoria. Repeats feat in 1988 and 1989. Makes debut for Italy, against Poland.

1986 Included in Italy squad for Mexico World Cup finals.

1990 Sampdoria win European Cup Winners' Cup with Vialli scoring twice. Plays in Italian team who finish third in World Cup.

1991 Sampdoria win Italian championship. Vialli is Serie A's top scorer with 16 goals.

1992 Plays in European Cup Final, but finishes on losing side against Barcelona at Wembley. Juventus pay a world record £12.5million to bring him to Turin.

1993 Wins Uefa Cup with Juventus, beating Borussia Dortmund in final.

1994 Left out of Italy's 1994 World Cup squad by Arrigo Sacchi.

1995 Juventus win League and Cup double with 16 goals from Vialli. Scores spectacular goal in second leg of Uefa Cup final against Parma, but Juventus lose. Voted World Player of the Year.

1996 Skippers Juventus to victory in the 1996 European Cup final in his last game for the club. Joins Chelsea on a free transfer in the summer for £1million a year after rejecting offer from Rangers. Makes Premiership debut in goalless draw with Southampton. Scores first goal for Chelsea against Coventry.

1997 Feud develops with Ruud Gullit as he is regularly left out of the starting line-up. Wins FA Cup winners' medal after coming on as 89th minute substitute in 2-0 final victory over Middlesbrough. Promises to give up smoking in a bid to win a regular place in the Chelsea line-up. Scores four goals in 6-0 drubbing of Barnsley, but starts only four of the first 10 games of the season. Sent off against Blackburn in Coca-Cola Cup after elbowing Stephane Henchoz. Scores hat-trick against Norwegian side Tromso in European Cup Winners' Cup, but does not play in next three games.

1998 Installed as Chelsea's new player-manager following Gullit's shock departure. Takes Chelsea to victory in the Coca-Cup Final against Middlesbrough at Wembley and in the European Cup Winners' Cup against Stuttgart in Stockholm.

2000 Misses out on qualification for the Champions League but guides the Blues to an FA Cup Final victory over Aston Villa.

Honours Serie A championships: 1991 and 1995. Italian Cups: 1985, 1988 and 1989. European Cup: 1996. European Cup Winners' Cup: 1990, 1998. UEFA Cup: 1993. FA Cup: 1997. Coca-Cola Cup: 1998.

The son of a millionaire, he is brought up in a castle. 1980 Signs for local club Cremonese, but his first full season is unspectacular with just five goals in 31 appearances. 1984 After scoring 10 goals for Cremonese, he is signed by Sampdoria. Makes it into double figures for six out of eight seasons at the Genoa-based side. 1985 Wins Italian Cup with Sampdoria. Repeats feat in 1988 and 1989. Makes debut for Italy, against Poland. 1986 Included in Italy squad for Mexico World Cup finals. 1990 Sampdoria win European Cup Winners' Cup with Vialli scoring twice. Plays in Italian team who finish third in World Cup. 1991 Sampdoria win Italian championship. Vialli is Serie A's top scorer with 16 goals. 1992 Plays in European Cup Final, but finishes on losing side against Barcelona at Wembley. Juventus pay a world record £12.5million to bring him to Turin. 1993 Wins Uefa Cup with Juventus, beating Borussia Dortmund in final. 1994 Left out of Italy's 1994 World Cup squad by Arrigo Sacchi. 1995 Juventus win League and Cup double with 16 goals from Vialli. Scores spectacular goal in second leg of Uefa Cup final against Parma, but Juventus lose. Voted World Player of the Year. 1996 Skippers Juventus to victory in the 1996 European Cup final in his last game for the club. Joins Chelsea on a free transfer in the summer for £1million a year after rejecting offer from Rangers. Makes Premiership debut in goalless draw with Southampton. Scores first goal for Chelsea against Coventry. 1997 Feud develops with Ruud Gullit as he is regularly left out of the starting line-up. Wins FA Cup winners' medal after coming on as 89th minute substitute in 2-0 final victory over Middlesbrough. Promises to give up smoking in a bid to win a regular place in the Chelsea line-up. Scores four goals in 6-0 drubbing of Barnsley, but starts only four of the first 10 games of the season. Sent off against Blackburn in Coca-Cola Cup after elbowing Stephane Henchoz. Scores hat-trick against Norwegian side Tromso in European Cup Winners' Cup, but does not play in next three games. 1998 Installed as Chelsea's new player-manager following Gullit's shock departure. Takes Chelsea to victory in the Coca-Cup Final against Middlesbrough at Wembley and in the European Cup Winners' Cup against Stuttgart in Stockholm. 2000 Misses out on qualification for the Champions League but guides the Blues to an FA Cup Final victory over Aston Villa. Honours Serie A championships: 1991 and 1995. Italian Cups: 1985, 1988 and 1989. European Cup: 1996. European Cup Winners' Cup: 1990, 1998. UEFA Cup: 1993. FA Cup: 1997. Coca-Cola Cup: 1998.

fields.headline: Unionist assembly member is arrested
fields.trailText: The RUC yesterday arrested Billy Hutchinson, a member of the Northern Ireland assembly, after a car avoided a vehicle checkpoint in the Shankill Road in Belfast.
fields.body:
The RUC yesterday arrested Billy Hutchinson, a member of the Northern Ireland assembly, after a car avoided a vehicle checkpoint in the Shankill Road in Belfast.

The car was later found abandoned. Mr Hutchinson, who represents the Progressive Unionist Party, linked to the Ulster Volunteer Force, is believed to have been one of four men who got into the vehicle as police watched. He refused to allow himself to be searched, and was held for obstruction before being released pending inquiries.

He was later at Stormont, where the first assembly meeting for the summer was suspended after a protest in the public gallery led by Gina Adair, wife of the notorious Ulster Freedom Fighters commander Johnny Adair. Mr Hutchinson was among those at whom Ms Adair and other women screamed abuse.

She had protested at Downing Street on Saturday, demanding that her husband be freed after being rearrested three weeks ago, on the orders of the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, when a loyalist feud erupted in which three men were murdered. A meeting on Friday was unable to establish a truce.

fields.headline: Honesty hurts
fields.trailText: Honesty hurts
fields.body:
Honesty hurts

Many academics and university administrators will be appalled at the decision of the Higher Education Funding Council that there will be no formal investigation of the "inaccurate" submission to the 1996 Research Assessment Exercise by the Department of East Asian Studies at Sheffield University (Bright Sparks, Education, September 5). In effect more deserving departments at other universities have been deprived of the £900,000 of public funding which has gone to the perpetrators.

That a former member of one of the assessment panels believes the case to be "one of hundreds" indicates that a less-than-scrupulous minority amongst vice-chancellors and heads of department already treats the exercise less as a measure of the quality of research than as an opportunity for its smoke-and-mirrors inflation. This tendency can only be encouraged by a failure to investigate such abuses as come to light.

Honesty in the reporting of research, as in its performance, may be its own reward, but it would also be prudent to remove what amounts to a tax upon it.

Peter Armstrong
Professor of Management
Keele University

webTitle: More money,  Less petrol, and  Bigger Cup

fields.headline: More money,  Less petrol, and  Bigger Cup
fields.trailText: PAOLO CAN YOU GO?
fields.body:
PAOLO CAN YOU GO?

Yesterday, the Fiver suggested that Gianluca Vialli was like a teenager with a trust fund (not unheard of round West London way), resolving all his problems with a wave of a credit card. Today, we would like to take back that suggestion, as it is becoming increasingly apparent that Luca doesn't actually need a reason to go and splash the cash.

According to reports, West Ham (they of bottom-of-the-table fame) are this afternoon in talks with Paolo Di Canio in an attempt to persuade the temperamental/magical/balding Italian not to sign for fashionable West London boutique Chelsea's of Chelsea. This follows a few hours of uncertainty after the Hammers announced they had rejected a £4m bid from the Blues for their star striker. Vialli is said to see Di Canio - and not Eidur Gudjohnsen, Gianfranco Zola, Tore Andre Flo, or anybody else he's already got - as the perfect partner for Jimbo Hasselbaink.

The Hammers would only profess ignorance about the current state of play when the Fiver spoke to them this afternoon. Which wasn't a denial (if you think about it). And while they are said to be desperate to hold onto Di Canio, the cheeky cockneys have been known to turn a profit on their players before, and are unlikely to get a better offer for a 32-year-old they signed for only £1.7m last year.

Vialli and Di Canio know each other from their days at Juventus, and Paolo has a framed photo of the pair on his mantelpiece if our memory of Football's Foreign Legion serves us right. What's more, the top wage at the top boutique is three times that of the luvable East End rogues. We really aren't sure what's going to happen, but we're confident that Luca doesn't have a clue either.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FUEL FOR THOUGHT

Glug! Glug! Glug! Glug! Glug! Glug! Gl- oh, hello there. Do excuse us, there's a perfectly rational explanation as to why we're drinking thousands of gallons of petrol, and it's this: we want to annoy as many people in Middle England as possible by forcing them to catch the bus or, God forbid, walk. Mind you, our amusing little prank looks like backfiring on us because The Fuel Crisis Sweeping The Nation - to use its official Government-approved title - is starting to affect the footer.

Only a day after Middlesbrough's Paul Ince was forced to miss training when the tank in his Guvmobile ran dry, things have taken a more serious turn. Tonight's match between Bristol City and Brentford has been called off, despite the Football League's earlier announcement that no games would be cancelled due to The Fuel Crisis Sweeping The Nation. Brentford had enough juice to get themselves down the M4 and back, but City were worried their stewards wouldn't be able to turn up and so they cancelled the fixture with safety uppermost in mind.

One cancellation we can live with, but if this The Fuel Crisis Sweeping The Nation continues, the entire football season could grind to a halt. Maggie Thatcher, bless her, would have dealt with such blatant militancy by sending in the army, thus nipping the problem in the bud and eroding the very fabric of working-class British society at a stroke. But she's long gone, so what should we do? The Fiver can only think of one suggestion: to conserve energy, supporters could watch a team from a nearby town instead of jetting off to Lancashire for their footy fix. Actually, that's not very realistic, is it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If you are a top actor you can earn £10m for one movie - but I never see people saying that is too much money. I am not saying it isn't hard being an actor, but I think it is a lot harder to be a footballer" - David Ginola, whose masterful performance in the Renault Laguna and L'Oreal ads garnered him praise from around the world.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S BIG AND BACK

And so Big Cup is back, giving the Imperial Lord Ferg the opportunity to blame injuries for any defeat and David O'Leary O'Leeds the chance to enjoy Milan and Barcelona (although probably not Istanbul) before getting another shot at Euro-Vase. Arsene Wenger and Dick Advocaat however will be rubbing their hands so hard they could start a small bonfire - because, after much European failure, both have a fantastic chance of qualifying for the second group stage.

However, you wouldn't know it listening to Arsene's Arsenal Wenger. Earlier today, Arsenal was ruing the time he invited ageing Czech footballer called Ivan Hasek to come to Highbury to study his training methods - only for Hasek to transform into the Sparta Prague manager he faces tonight! "I have some small regrets now about letting him observe our methods," said an understated Wenger like a Sixties TV baddie. "I have known Hasek for a long time. I didn't know that he would become Sparta's coach and that we would meet [in Big Cup]. He has obviously learned well, but I hope not too well," he added sinisterly, as some lackey prepared the words 'Kapow' and 'Biff' to be flashed on screen.

The Pope's Rangers, who start their Big Cup campaign tonight against Sturm Graz, seem in more confident mood. The Austrian side are in somewhat of a pickle, having lost their last three games and, though the Fiver's no Cracker, the mood can't have been helped when their chairman told the press today that manager Ivica Osim can't stand up to his players. "He is scared to take a risk and axe some of his players from his team," Hannes Kartnig whined, "but he has to find a way out of this mess and I don't know if he can do that tonight in Glasgow." Maybe not, but on recent form we're sure Bert Konterman and Fernando Ricksen will do all they can to help.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

English clubs have been offered Nigerian international defender Taribo West for free after AC Milan cancelled his contract with the club, according to reports.

Newcastle have made an official approach for £1m-rated Colchester striker Lomana Lua Lua.

Celtic defender Alan Stubbs is angling for a move to Everton. "One day I would love to play for Everton", he said. "That's the team I grew up supporting."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leeds winger Jason Wilcox will be out for eight weeks after breaking his left ankle in a training ground accident. Wilcox had only just returned to the first team on Saturday after two knee operations had kept him out of Leeds' squad for the entire summer.

Gerry Taggart has signed a new three-year contract with Leicester City which will keep him at the club until the summer of 2003.

Unsettled Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu is to have more talks with John Gregory over his future at the club. "The situation with [Gregory] is the same as it's always been," Ehiogu said. "There isn't much contact, which I'm going to try to address today. I'm going to try to get one or two things cleared up because I think it's gone on long enough."

Ipswich have agreed terms with NK Maribor for the transfer of Slovenian international defender Amir Karic for an undisclosed fee.

Newcastle have rewarded 18-year-old striker Shola Ameobi with a four-year contract after he impressed on his Premiership debut.

Ashley Westwood has completed his £150,000 move from Bradford to Sheffield Wednesday.

Everton's hopes of signing Israeli international Idan Tal have been dashed after the player was refused a work permit.

Hibernian have announced a massive £1.9m increase in turnover over the past season, their first back in the Scottish Premier League.

Mark Lillis has been sacked as manager of Halifax Town after just 15 months in the job. His former assistant Peter Butler and goalkeeping coach Tony Parks will take temporary charge of the team at Cardiff tonight.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10pm) Arsenal and Rangers' latest Big Cup disasters - the highlights.

Uefa Football Gala 2000 (1.05am) Arsenal and Rangers' latest Big Cup disasters - the celebration.

The Big Match (2.05am) Arsenal and Rangers' latest Big Cup disasters - the whole thing.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm, 2am) If you don't want to watch Rangers' latest Big Cup disaster, you could always watch their latest Scottish league disaster instead.

Soccer Special (7.30pm) Jeff Stelling - still better than Des.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) McCaff - still better than no, scrap that.

Sky Sports 2: First Division Football - Live (7.30pm) Will Wimbledon be on telly more now they're in the Nationwide?

World Football Show (10pm, 12midnight SS1) As if anyone would bother watching a highlights package showing teams from Belgium and France. They'll be asking us to sit through that sort of thing live next.

British Eurosport: K Lierse SK v Bordeaux - Live (5pm) Ah.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) A radio programme about football.

Talksport: Adrian Durham and Alvin Martin (7pm) As above, but with Adrian Durham and Alvin Martin.
