fields.headline: Telegraph revamp targets younger readers
fields.standfirst: Review by the Guardian's head of design
fields.trailText: The Telegraph is trying to be trendy, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The first thing that strikes you about the new-look Daily Telegraph is the much tidier front page.

The radical decision to move the flannel panel to above the masthead and ditch the blue background strip is a huge - yet disputable - step-change for the Telegraph.

Many stalwarts are divided about its benefits. The only other broadsheet to have its flannel panel above its masthead is the Independent, but then the Independent still has the conventional blue strip, while the Telegraph has opted for an all-white background.

The new colour, a kind of beige, bears an uncanny resemblance to the one The Guardian uses on its flannel panel. The index strip down the left-hand side of page two could also be said to be inspired by the Guardian, except for the fact that the Telegraph's index does not have a tint.

Other changes are more subtle. While it looks like there are a hell of a lot more picture bylines, a quick count reveals there are the same amount. The difference is that they are more scattered throughout the paper. And the first one appears on page 10, as opposed to page 18 last week.

The overall impression is that the Telegraph is trying to be trendy and appeal to younger audiences. But, as seen with the wide array of fonts used on the front page, it is not entirely consistent.

The mixture of serif and sans serif fonts makes the paper look a little confused, to say the least. The look is not dissimilar to the one it revealed a few months back when Dotcom.telegraph was launched.

The only other broadsheet to have its flannel panel above its masthead is the Independent, but then the Independent still has the conventional blue strip, while the Telegraph has opted for an all-white background. The new colour, a kind of beige, bears an uncanny resemblance to the one The Guardian uses on its flannel panel. The index strip down the left-hand side of page two could also be said to be inspired by the Guardian, except for the fact that the Telegraph's index does not have a tint. Other changes are more subtle. While it looks like there are a hell of a lot more picture bylines, a quick count reveals there are the same amount. The difference is that they are more scattered throughout the paper. And the first one appears on page 10, as opposed to page 18 last week. The overall impression is that the Telegraph is trying to be trendy and appeal to younger audiences. But, as seen with the wide array of fonts used on the front page, it is not entirely consistent. The mixture of serif and sans serif fonts makes the paper look a little confused, to say the least. The look is not dissimilar to the one it revealed a few months back when Dotcom.telegraph was launched.

fields.headline: It's Friday, it's five to five, and it's... Disney?
fields.trailText: Children's programmes did not make a great showing in this week's BFI list of television's top 100. While drama series managed 26 entries and comedy 22 of the nation's favourite 20th-century shows, children's programming scraped together a measly 11.
fields.body:
Not a great showing for children's programmes in this week's BFI list of television's top 100. While drama series managed 26 entries and comedy 22 of the nation's favourite twentieth-century programmes, children's programming scraped together a measly 11 - with Teletubbies stealing in at no 97 and such eternal classics as Crackerjack and Jackanory nowhere to be seen. I was devastated to see that Andy Pandy never even made it to the children's top 20.

Still, help in rectifying the apparently parlous state of children's television is claimed to be at hand. In just under three weeks' time, Walt Disney Television International is launching three new digital satellite channels to complement its existing subscription-based Disney Channel.

There will be a pre-school channel, available for 15 hours a day from 5.30 in the morning, a 24-hour cartoon channel, and a channel that replicates the Disney Channel, but time-shifted by one hour.

Opinion is divided on whether parents will be flocking to sign up for digital satellite or rushing to dismantle their television sets.

Unlike some parents, I have few objections to Disney and have spent many happy hours (with my children as an excuse) watching virtually every single Disney movie - most of them at least three times. The more choice of children's entertainment the better, and for those who want and can afford to pay the digital satellite subscription fees, Mickey Mouse is an excellent babysitter.

Unfortunately, Paul Robinson, managing director of Disney's British television operation, appears to be less sanguine about the prospect of more choice. He has taken great exception to the announcement by Greg Dyke that the BBC will also be launching two new children's channels as part of its expanding digital strategy. Robinson wrote to last week's Broadcast magazine as follows: 'There are already 10 children's channels in the UK and five terrestrials providing children's programming... It is not acceptable to siphon off part of the licence fee into new channels when the market is already providing a more than adequate range.'

The implicit assumption that Walt Disney can and will replicate any creative output from the new BBC channels will strike many parents as - how does one put this politely? - about as intelligent as Donald Duck with a lobotomy.

There is a growing tendency among commercial broadcasters to follow the Kelvin MacKenzie school of special pleading in any debate about the BBC and its services. The argument goes something like this: 'Of course, I believe passionately in the role of public service broadcasting and the BBC to make programmes the market can't provide, but we don't need subsidised competition in...' Take your choice from sports radio (TalkSport); 24-hour news channels (Sky News); pop music (Capital); factual programmes (Discovery); entertainment (every-body) and so on. Put them all together, and you end up with a BBC that consists of obscure opera, roller-skating from Little Hadham and extended editions of Songs of Praise .

Of course the BBC's presence in these specialist markets makes it more difficult for the burgeoning number of commercial channels to make money. But the question is rather more complex than a simple equation of corporate profit (or even survival) versus licence-payers' money. It is a cultural issue which - in children's television - is about the kind of values that infuse programmes and about the trust parents have in programme-makers.

The question is this: given the opportunities being offered by digital broadcasting, should room be made for a specialist children's channel dedicated to homegrown British programmes that will be universally available on every digital platform, does not require subscription fees, does not take advertising or sponsorship, and does not regard children as valuable commercial commodities? I suspect most British parents may take issue with Robinson's antipathy.

This is not an argument for an omnipresent BBC, and Dyke made it clear in his McTaggart lecture that the BBC should not have tanks on every lawn. That begs the question of whose lawns and what size tanks, and the next few years will see the BBC condemned for activities in almost every sphere of programming. Its arguments will no doubt be scrutinised in minuscule detail by those whose commercial income depends on eroding the non-commercial share of viewing.

In the meantime, I wish Disney much luck in trying to match the range and quality of BBC information, factual, arts, science, drama and animation programmes specially created - not imported - for our children.

The day they come up with the top five children's programmes - as the BBC did in the BFI poll - while making their channels free to every digital subscriber and scrapping their ads is the day they can talk with a straight face about the BBC getting out of children's channels.

Until then, they should carry on making their excellent cartoons and stop talking out of Goofy's backside.

fields.headline: New business boosts Aegis
fields.trailText: Aegis has posted a rise in profits on the back of soaring new business billings, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Advertising and marketing group Aegis has posted a rise in profits on the back of soaring new business billings.

The company, which counts Lycos, BMW and Bank of Scotland among its clients, said half-year pre-tax profits increased from £29.1m to £34.7m, a rise of 19%.

But the figure that stands out is for new business billings, which climbed 28% to £727m, with the European market contributing £461.5m.

Aegis's chief executive, Douglas Flynn, said the results were severely hampered by currency fluctuations, although the business was sheltered from the Easter dot.com crash because internet companies provided only 5% of revenues.

Aegis is not shying away from start-ups altogether, however, as shown by its internet incubator venture, eVerger. The business, developed with investment bank Warburg Pincus, will help Aegis to build its online marketing service.

"To an extent, it is an outsourcing venture," said Mr Flynn. "We have taken a lot of difficult developments off our plate and taken away the risk element, so we can integrate the successful parts, such as email marketing, into Aegis."

The group's market research arm produced revenues of £64.3m, boosted by the March acquisition of Asia Market Intelligence - the region's second largest custom research network.

webTitle: Endemol to set up permanent base in the US

fields.headline: Endemol looks to US for permanent base
fields.trailText: Endemol, the Dutch production company behind Big Brother, is looking to set up a permanent base in the US. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Endemol, the Dutch production company behind global phenomenon Big Brother, is looking to set up a permanent base in the US.

Endemol chairman and chief executive officer, John de Mol, is currently in the US with a number of Endemol acquisition executives, talking to several medium-sized production houses about acquisitions.

Endemol spokesman, Thomas Notermans, confirmed that Endemol would buy into an established firm, but suggested that it would be more of a strategic stake rather than an outright 100% acquisition. He declined to say whether or not Evolution, the production house Endemol worked with on Big Brother USA, was one of the companies it was talking to.

"Business is going well for us. We're selling over in the US but we recognise that we need production capacity to make headway in the market," said Notermans, pointing out that it was a logical move for the company to make.

An announcement is expected shortly about which company Endemol will partner and who will run the new company.

Meanwhile, Endemol this week announced the appointment of Ronald Goes as chief operating officer of Endemol Entertainment, who joins on January 1.

Goes, who is one of the founders of SBS Broadcasting, is to be responsible for all TV operating offshoots within the Endemol group.

fields.headline: Bragg attacks 'foolish senior citizens of culture'
fields.trailText: Melvyn Bragg today mounted a stinging attack on "the foolish senior citizens of culture" such as VS Naipaul and John Tusa for complaining about populist film and literature without any experience of what they criticise.
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg today mounted a stinging attack on "the foolish senior citizens of culture" such as VS Naipaul and John Tusa for complaining about populist film and literature without any experience of what they criticise.

Launching the 24th series of the South Bank Show, Lord Bragg likened such commentators to Mary Whitehouse, the anti-smut campaigner who attacked almost anything remotely controversial. "I do not believe they know of what they speak, and in my book that's a crime," he said.

Recently Naipaul, Tusa and the former Radio 3 controller Sir John Drummond have all attacked the "dumbing down" of modern British culture. But Lord Bragg said they were misguided. "Videos and film and CD have given popular culture the ticket to posterity and only a fool would rush in to say that today's, or rather yesterday's, hierarchies will live forever. Mind you, we are not short of foolish senior citizens of culture puff-puffing in."

He said Naipaul could not be trusted as a commentator on popular culture because he was "on record" as saying he did not read contemporary novels, and probably did not go to the theatre or watch television; the experience of Drummond did not extend far beyond opera and classical music; and Tusa was "the same".

In the future, the voice of the young Elvis Presley would be treasured over the young Luciano Pavarotti, Lord Bragg suggested. "You don't know what is going to turn up; these guys are not looking hard enough to find it."

Lord Bragg, the controller of arts and features at LWT, went on to say that ITV should not be tempted to specialise as a purely entertainment-based channel as digital competition intensifies. "We must and can do what we do better than the mono-channels and be the button of choice, as well as the channel of the nation."

This season's South Bank Show includes a profile of Marilyn Monroe by the novelist Joyce Carol Oates, and programmes on the singer Tom Jones, choreographer Mark Morris, novelist George MacDonald Fraser, artist Marc Quinn and organist Gillian Weir.

webTitle: Are good nurseries too much to ask?

fields.headline: Baby boom
fields.standfirst: We want more nurseries, and we want them now (but we want them to be good, too). Is that really too much to ask?
fields.trailText: We want more nurseries, and we want them now (but we want them to be good, too). Is that really too much to ask?
fields.body:
The hunt for an appropriate nursery is often an emotional assault course for parents - not least because of the ambivalence that frequently surrounds the decision. "Will he/she be happy here?" sabotaged by the unspoken question, "Should he/she be here at all?" An issue you thought you'd addressed satisfactorily until you reach the threshold of the first nursery under inspection.

It is then that the sight of a toddler crying unattended in the corner, however briefly, triggers images of your own child wandering unstimulated for hours, or worse still, treated cruelly, unable to ask for rescue because he or she lacks the vocabulary. But then, eventually, if you're lucky, you may come across a nursery that clearly looks as if the prime purpose of the enterprise is not warehousing children while mothers and fathers clock up the hours in work but fostering each individual child's happiness and well-being. You may well have struck gold.

Nursery provision - especially for the under threes - is in trouble. On Thursday, the Professional Association of Nursery Nurses (Pann), will chair a conference, attended by a number of national childcare organisations, to discuss their deep concerns about the regulation of the industry (now inspected by Ofsted using, say critics, inspectors with little childcare experience); recruitment and the new government proposals on national care standards.

Tricia Pritchard, professional officer at Pann, says: "The government should be investing in training, developing a career ladder, improving salaries, tightening regulations and attracting the right quality of person into childcare. Instead, it is dropping standards and implying from its present recruitment campaign that virtually anyone can do the job. All that's required is to "like children". That view wipes clean our years of effort to make the profession much more than an option, alongside hairdressing, for low achievers with no aspiration. What we want to say to the government is that you've got it wrong. If children really matter, think again."

Meanwhile in Scotland, 5,000 nursery nurses, members of the trade union Unison, have been on strike over pay. The majority of nursery nurses are women - add to that the disgracefully low value attached to all employment concerned with the business of care, and the result is a low salary and a non-existent career structure so there is little opportunity, no matter how well qualified, to earn more. Barbara Foubister, for instance, has been a nursery nurse for 32 years. She works in an Edinburgh school nursery and earns £12,100. Salaries in the private sector in the rest of the UK are just as low - between £9,000 and £15,000.

This matters to parents because it translates into high turnover of staff (up to 30%) and little motivation to develop skills - over half childcare staff are unqualified. Professionals hoped that the government would push for all staff to be qualified, within a five-year target, the majority up to the equivalent of an NNEB (a two-year course). Instead, under the government's proposals (the consultation period ends next month - time for parents to lobby their MPs), it suggests that only half the staff have NVQ level 2, (acquired in a matter of months); the remainder may be unqualified while a manager requires no experience. "That means an 18-year-old could run a nursery," says one nursery owner. "Is that what we really want for our children? The implications are frightening."

While the debate about whether it's "good", or at least not "bad", for a baby to go into daycare is unresolved, what have been established are the factors that contribute to high-quality nursery provision for the under-fours. A report for the Thomas Coram Research Unit established that what matters is the childcare workers' education, training and working conditions; sensitive and responsive adult-child interactions; stability and continuity of care; strong regulation and the adult-to-child ratios. Very little of which will be achieved if the new proposals are accepted.

The government is in a difficult dilemma. To its credit, Labour has made childcare a public and political issue - offering, for instance, financial support through the Working Family Tax Credit and funding after-school clubs. It has also required local authorities to conduct annual audits of childcare requirements and establish 150 Early Years Development and Childcare Partnerships, bringing together public, private and voluntary sectors.

A wide range of childcare and early learning facilities - nurseries offering day care from three months to five; nursery schools for three- to five-year-olds; childminders, nannies - is, of course, crucial to Labour's determination to reduce the benefits bill and tackle poverty. Its goal has accelerated the influx of mothers into the workplace . Now, 55% of mothers with a youngest child under five are economically active while two-thirds of those on maternity leave return to work within six months. Two out of three rely on informal childcare but the demand for paid care is set to expand hugely.

The country has 1.8m under-threes and a chronic shortage of provision. It is rumoured that the government will shortly set up a fund for under-threes to establish nurseries in areas where the childcare entrepreneurs can see no potential for profit. The private sector has already grown at a phenomenal 400% in the past decade. Still it only meets 2% of demand. At the same time, the number of community and local authority nurseries is shrinking. In June, the government launched a recruitment campaign to attract 83,000 childcarers into the profession by 2003. The concern is whether enough will have a genuine commitment to children. Or will they simply be in search of a wage?

The opportunities to make a mint are obvious. Bad practitioners will ignore the challenge of how to boost salaries and professionalism while dealing with a skills shortage and the inability of many parents to pay more by providing what amounts to indifferent security guards for the young. Tragedies will occur and thousands of children will be made miserable. Other entrepreneurs, however, are more enlightened. They, too, are depressed by the government's proposals .

John Woodward is a director of Busy Bees, a chain of 35 nurseries that trains its own staff . "We could see 10 years ago that we were heading for a massive skills shortage," Woodward explains. "It requires a long-term strategy - but what politician thinks in the long term?"

Child Base, also praised for good practice, has 24 nurseries (charging between £130 and £180 a week) and a turnover of over £7m. Michael Thompson, the company's founder and chairman of the National Day Nurseries Association, says that in order to retain good-quality staff and instill a sense of vocation, the company offers training and a proper career structure. A regional director earns £30,000-plus. The company has also introduced a pension scheme. All of which adds to the cost. So far, however, it's mainly parents and taxpayers who are meeting the bills. Should the employers do more?

Some 80% of parents believe they should, and 75% of the UK's top 500 companies agree there is a recognised business case for family-friendly policies. HSBC, for instance, lost £18m a year before the introduction of its childcare project. Still, only 3% offer workplace nurseries and 2% provide a voucher scheme (exempt from National Insurance) or a cash allowance. Few have been active in the Early Years Development and Childcare Partnerships.

Employers need a shake-up. The Daycare Trust, the childcare campaigning charity, advocates that parents (especially those such as nurses, doctors and engineers who have clout because they have sought-after skills) should exert pressure. It also wants the government, for instance, to set targets for improved employer contributions to childcare costs. Mike Thompson also suggests the removal of VAT on the acquisition of new sites; a fresh look at business rates and childcare costs treated as a non-taxable benefit (disliked by the Treasury.)

High-quality nursery care gives a child a positive start in life regardless of whether parents are in work or at home. We have yet to learn the consequences of exposing thousands to care that is truly dire. "The ideal is a decent nursery in every community just as we expect a primary school and a GP," says Collette Kelleher of The Daycare Trust. "The government has invested an enormous amount but the real danger now is that it may see childcare as a ticked box, when the task has only just begun. The momentum must be maintained."

How to choose a nursery

1 Ask how many of the staff are qualified - and to what level. Is the manager qualified?

2 Ask to see the last Ofsted report (they should have all been inspected at least twice by now).

3 What is staff turnover and the average length of stay for members of staff?

4 How long has the nursery been open, and how long has the manager been in post?

5 Are there planning charts on the walls; signs of recent activities that the children have been involved in?

6 Speak to other parents. Is there a parents' committee? Ask how the nursery involves parents.

7 Ask if you can drop in as and when you choose. If visits are restricted, be suspicious.

8 Trust your gut reaction

It is rumoured that the government will shortly set up a fund for under-threes to establish nurseries in areas where the childcare entrepreneurs can see no potential for profit. The private sector has already grown at a phenomenal 400% in the past decade. Still it only meets 2% of demand. At the same time, the number of community and local authority nurseries is shrinking. In June, the government launched a recruitment campaign to attract 83,000 childcarers into the profession by 2003. The concern is whether enough will have a genuine commitment to children. Or will they simply be in search of a wage? The opportunities to make a mint are obvious. Bad practitioners will ignore the challenge of how to boost salaries and professionalism while dealing with a skills shortage and the inability of many parents to pay more by providing what amounts to indifferent security guards for the young. Tragedies will occur and thousands of children will be made miserable. Other entrepreneurs, however, are more enlightened. They, too, are depressed by the government's proposals . John Woodward is a director of Busy Bees, a chain of 35 nurseries that trains its own staff . "We could see 10 years ago that we were heading for a massive skills shortage," Woodward explains. "It requires a long-term strategy - but what politician thinks in the long term?" Child Base, also praised for good practice, has 24 nurseries (charging between £130 and £180 a week) and a turnover of over £7m. Michael Thompson, the company's founder and chairman of the National Day Nurseries Association, says that in order to retain good-quality staff and instill a sense of vocation, the company offers training and a proper career structure. A regional director earns £30,000-plus. The company has also introduced a pension scheme. All of which adds to the cost. So far, however, it's mainly parents and taxpayers who are meeting the bills. Should the employers do more? Some 80% of parents believe they should, and 75% of the UK's top 500 companies agree there is a recognised business case for family-friendly policies. HSBC, for instance, lost £18m a year before the introduction of its childcare project. Still, only 3% offer workplace nurseries and 2% provide a voucher scheme (exempt from National Insurance) or a cash allowance. Few have been active in the Early Years Development and Childcare Partnerships. Employers need a shake-up. The Daycare Trust, the childcare campaigning charity, advocates that parents (especially those such as nurses, doctors and engineers who have clout because they have sought-after skills) should exert pressure. It also wants the government, for instance, to set targets for improved employer contributions to childcare costs. Mike Thompson also suggests the removal of VAT on the acquisition of new sites; a fresh look at business rates and childcare costs treated as a non-taxable benefit (disliked by the Treasury.) High-quality nursery care gives a child a positive start in life regardless of whether parents are in work or at home. We have yet to learn the consequences of exposing thousands to care that is truly dire. "The ideal is a decent nursery in every community just as we expect a primary school and a GP," says Collette Kelleher of The Daycare Trust. "The government has invested an enormous amount but the real danger now is that it may see childcare as a ticked box, when the task has only just begun. The momentum must be maintained." How to choose a nursery 1 Ask how many of the staff are qualified - and to what level. Is the manager qualified? 2 Ask to see the last Ofsted report (they should have all been inspected at least twice by now). 3 What is staff turnover and the average length of stay for members of staff? 4 How long has the nursery been open, and how long has the manager been in post? 5 Are there planning charts on the walls; signs of recent activities that the children have been involved in? 6 Speak to other parents. Is there a parents' committee? Ask how the nursery involves parents. 7 Ask if you can drop in as and when you choose. If visits are restricted, be suspicious. 8 Trust your gut reaction

fields.headline: Joseph H Lewis
fields.standfirst: Film director whose key masterpieces led to a positive reassessment of his B-movie output
fields.trailText: The highly regarded B-movie film director, Joseph H Lewis, who has died aged 100, was born in New York. The year? However, the later date has gained credibility, with the suggestion that Lewis added years to his age on entering the movie business in the hope of gaining a more senior post.
fields.body:
The highly regarded B-movie film director, Joseph H Lewis, who has died aged 100, was born in New York. The year? It was either 1900 or 1907, with the earlier date most favoured by reference books, the American Film Institute and British Film Institute. However, the later date has gained credibility, with the suggestion that Lewis added years to his age on entering the movie business in the hope of gaining a more senior post.

In fact, he joined MGM as a camera loader in the early 1920s, either as a teenager or aged 23. He stayed in the business until the late 1960s, latterly working in television. His career as a movie director lasted just 21 years from 1937, and, during that period, he also served in the US Army Signal Corps. He directed more than 40 films.

All except one of these were B-movies, often destined for the lower half of double bills. As his career progressed, Lewis moved to bigger budgets, but still directed genre flicks, considered at the time to be run-of-the-mill thrillers or westerns. His film career ended in 1958, as Hollywood, battling the inroads of television, turned increasingly to the wide screen and blockbusters, and the double bill became obsolete.

The style of film at which Lewis had excelled became the staple diet of television - action and genre pieces to fill the greedy air waves instead of local cinemas. For 10 years, he joined the enemy, working on the Lloyd Bridges Show, the Zane Grey Theatre and A Man Called Shenandoah. He directed the pilot of Branded in 1965, and episodes of such popular series as Gunsmoke, The Big Valley, Law Of The Plainsman and The Rifleman. His television work remains a coda to his busy, central years as a film director.

After his retirement, Lewis, like other B-directors, was lionised by the French, and later by American, British and other critics. Many of his quickly-made works were reassessed. In the US, Paul Schrader helped influence his new-found reputation - largely based on one classic - and there were retrospectives of his career mounted, not least at the National Film Theatre, where Lewis also took part in a Guardian lecture. He proved himself exactly the amiable, tough, no-nonsense professional that his works suggest.

Over the years, the works have resurfaced on television, on 16mm and in various retrospectives. Those on view confirm that there are indeed a handful of memorable films, plus a whole series of intelligent, entertaining works - mainly westerns. The rest remain in decent obscurity, although contemporary reviews invariably praise their originality, economy and ingenious camerawork. Lewis was no slouch.

But, as the critic and film historian David Thomson remarked, "There is no point in overpraising Lewis." He worked with limited resources, often with middling actors, on series product offering mundane scripts. He transcended the material - but his liveliness and technical skill only highlight the paucity of the material with which he worked.

Still, we do not need to overpraise him to realise that, on occasion, he created small, beautifully crafted cinema. And a handful of these films are complex works that stand up infinitely better than the grandiose, over-blown epics that were the result of his fellow directors' move into A-features. The often flabby films of the 1960s and 1970s were a riposte to the undernourished budgets of television. At the time, they seemed a valid alternative; today, less so.

After Lewis entered the studios, he stayed there for some 16 years in a variety of jobs. He worked as an assistant editor, second unit director and supervising editor on many films, including In Old Santa Fé (1934) and Ladies Crave Excitement (1935), as well as on popular 12- or 15-episode serials, such as Undersea Kingdom (1936). In that year, he also edited The Devil On Horseback, directed by Crane Wilbur, and, in 1937, co-directed Navy Spy, with Wilbur. After years of sturdy, invaluable experience, Lewis had graduated and, again in 1937, directed his début, Courage Of The West, quickly followed by Singing Outlaw.

He made three films in 1938, including Border Wolves, described as a "visual treat". Within the next three years, he had notched up another dozen B-movies, mainly westerns such as The Man From Tumbleweeds (1940), and three films from the East End Kids series - Boys Of The City, That Gang Of Mine and Pride Of The Bowery. This busy pattern continued with product from studios more interested in quota than quality. The titles tell most of the story - such as Bombs Over Burma and Criminals Within. Among these mainly action pictures was an odd biopic, Minstrel Man (1944), about and starring Benny Fields. The following year, he directed a lively offering in the detective series, The Falcon, in San Francisco.

Also in 1945, Lewis made his real breakthrough. My Name Is Julia Ross was his 25th directorial credit, and probably his best movie to that date. It is a brisk, slightly loopy example of film noir about a secretary (Nina Foch) who is kidnapped and held in a remote mansion by a demented boy (George Macready) and his mother (Dame May Whitty). It is not too fanciful to view this little chiller as a precursor to Hitchcock's masterly Psycho.

Lewis followed this with another melodramatic thriller, So Dark The Night. He was now working for Columbia, the least of the major studios, but still more prestigious than his earlier employers. They gave him the task (probably because of Minstrel Man) of directing the musical numbers for the highly successful biopic, The Jolson Story. But the main credit went to Alfred E Green, and Lewis returned to B-pictures, working with the star of Jolson, Larry Parks, on The Swordsman.

In 1948, he made The Return Of October, before returning to better form with a stylish and stylised crime story, Undercover Alan (1949), which led on to one of two acknowledged masterworks, Gun Crazy (1949). This is often compared favourably with Bonnie And Clyde, although in truth it is a noir gem best ranked with Nicholas Ray's They Live By Night. The story, of a doomed couple, plunged headlong into crime by an obsessional amour fou , is completely unsentimental. It is distinguished by fluid camera work, two brilliant set-piece robberies, and the driven performances of the young leads, John Dall and Peggy Cummins. The tragic ending closes the circular narrative as the non-violent hero fires blindly at the police and dies by the guns he has coveted as a small boy.

The acclaim that turned Gun Crazy into a cult movie came much later, and Lewis continued with B-movies, although with technicians and actors of a higher calibre. His next work was an excellent melodrama, Lady With A Passport (1950), starring Hedy Lamarr, followed by the Korean-set war film, Retreat Hell! and Desperate Search (both 1952) and Cry Of The Hunted (1953).

His subsequent film, The Big Combo (1954) has less of a reputation than Gun Crazy, but boasts even more distinguished camerawork (by the great John Alton) and a remarkable trio of heavyweight actors - Richard Conte, Brian Donleavy and Cornel Wilde. This claustrophobic, violent movie is superbly structured, and remains today a dark and cynical work. It is probably Lewis's most achieved and complex film.

Apart from a short, Man On A Bus (1955), made for the United Jewish Appeal Fund, Lewis made only four more feature films before moving into television. Of these, 7th Cavalry (1956) is a modest western, starring Randolph Scott. Although not in the same league as the Scott-Boetticher westerns, it is an attractive, melancholy work.

The remaining trio are rather more notable. A Lawless Street (1955) is distinguished by characteristically agile camerawork and a brisk narrative. The Halliday Brand (1957) is a psychological western with a dark tone, offering themes of racism, humiliation and an obsessive family. As usual, Lewis transcends his limited budget with visual flair and energy.

T he following year, he directed Terror In A Texas Town, an attempt at an artistic wilful example of the genre. This odd western boasts an almost surreal climax as the hero, Sterling Hayden, seeks revenge, using his dead father's harpoon as a weapon of destruction. It was a flamboyant end to a film career that led to him becoming one of the most discussed of all B-movie directors.

His best work stands alongside that of Edgar Ulmer, Budd Boetticher and Jacques Tourneur, as well as the earlier, better films of Edward Dmytryk, Blake Edwards and Richard Fleischer - before they and others allowed inflated budgets to inflate their egos and bank balances whilst deflating their talents. And while agreeing with Thomson that we should not overrate Lewis, we certainly need never underrate him and his like. There was an integrity, energy and skill that makes such craftsmen key figures in the history of popular crime films.

He is survived by his wife Buena, and a daughter, Candy.

 Joseph H Lewis, film and television director, born April 6 1900; died August 30 2000

webTitle: School resource: Vietato fumare, sigarette addio!

fields.headline: Vietato fumare, sigarette addio!
fields.standfirst: Italy's health minister wants to ban smoking in public places. What do people think of this radical idea?
fields.trailText: Italy's health minister wants to ban smoking in public places. What do people think of this radical idea?
fields.body:
Il fumo "in pubblico", diventa illegale in Italia. Un disegno di legge, già approvato dal governo, prevede il divieto di fumare in ogni luogo pubblico: ristoranti, bar, negozi, mezzi di trasporto, stazioni, porti, aeroporti, uffici, circoli ricreativi, scuole, ospedali e persino nelle carceri. Le sigarette saranno proibite anche negli uffici privati dove convivono fumatori e non fumatori. Il fumo verrà consentito solo in aree riservate opportunamente ventilate e chi non rispetterà il divieto, o non lo farà rispettare, incorrerà in pesanti multe i cui proventi saranno utilizzati per finanziare campagne di informazione sugli effetti nocivi del tabacco.

"Bisogna salvare 44 milioni di italiani; il cancro ai polmoni è la malattia peggiore", ha detto il ministro della sanità Umberto Veronesi, noto oncologo, riferendosi al numero dei non fumatori.

Contro il divieto insorgono ora sia i commercianti, che trovano assurdo doversi trasformare in poliziotti anti-fumo inimicandosi i clienti, che coloro che giudicano la legge proibizionista.

Abbiamo chiesto a quattro giovani quale sia il loro rapporto col fumo e come giudichino la legge.

Quale rapporto hai con il fumo? Manuela, ex-fumatrice - Fumavo almeno un pacchetto al giorno. Ho smesso a malincuore, spinta dagli altri. Quando mi sono decisa è stato durissimo. Mi sentivo suonata come una tossica in crisi di astinenza, non riuscivo a concentrarmi! Mi ha aiutato una seduta di agopuntura, che ha segnato l'inizio di questo percorso. Ora sono contentissima.

Marco, non-fumatore tollerante - Non fumo, ma non condanno il fumo. Inizia a darmi fastidio solo quando sono "costretto" a subire quello degli altri.

Massimo, fumatore incallito - Sono un fumatore da stress, nel senso che se dovessi calcolare quante delle venti sigarette al giorno che fumo mi dà effettivo piacere, dovrei limitarmi a tre o quattro. Le altre vanno per stress, infatti le fumo sul lavoro.

Alessio, igienista - Non fumo e non ci ho mai provato anche perché ritengo che sia una cosa nociva per la salute.

Come ti senti negli ambienti pieni di fumo? Manuela - Il fumo ora mi dà un fastidio fisico. Mi pare che i fumatori siano maleducatissimi, come del resto lo ero io. Forse sono maleducati senza accorgersene. Riempiono i locali di fumo, buttano le cicche per terra, sono invadenti e poco rispettosi!

Marco - Dove lavoro fumano in molti, ma in genere rispettano la "mia" zona, anche perché ci sono computer e macchine sofisticate ed è necessaria un'atmosfera pulita. Solo a volte ho difficoltà con persone estranee all'ufficio, che trovano naturale fumare senza chiedere il permesso. I fumatori sono una categoria a volte egoista. Quando siamo al ristorante insieme e gli amici fumano - ad esempio - mi chiedo perché non aspettino che io abbia finito di mangiare. Il rispetto nei confronti di chi non fuma è molto raro, mentre dovrebbe essere alla base di un rapporto corretto di convivenza.

Massimo - Spesso e volentieri il piacere di fumare una sigaretta mi impedisce di tener conto delle esigenze dei non fumatori. Faccio il cafone. Questo succede soprattutto nelle situazioni in cui chi non fuma è in minoranza e non agguerrito.

Alessio - Mi sento decisamente a disagio. La nuvola di fumo nei locali chiusi mi dà fastidio. Nel liceo dove studio è vietato fumare, ma gli studenti fumano nei bagni ogni volta che possono uscire dalla classe, trasformandoli in camere a gas!

Cosa pensi della legge che vieterà il fumo in tutti i luoghi pubblici? Manuela - Se l'avessero proposta quando fumavo, l'avrei presa malissimo! Ma visto che le persone non hanno il buon senso di comportarsi più educatamente, allora approvo il divieto.

Marco - Egoisticamente penso sia una legge giusta. Capisco però che possa essere una pena per chi fuma. Se ci fosse una "cultura" di rispetto reciproco, la legge potrebbe essere evitata. Vietare un piacere è una cosa negativa, ha un sapore proibizionista. Diciamo che è un provvedimento eticamente scorretto, ma a mio vantaggio!

Massimo - Il primo impatto è una forte preoccupazione per la limitazione della mia libertà. Poi, pensandoci bene, mi pare una cosa giusta. Il fumo dovrebbe essere vietato nei luoghi pubblici. Sarebbe però anche bene dotare questi luoghi di uno spazio fumatori e non arrivare ad eccessi di colpevolizzazione, di tipo americano, per intenderci. C'è anche il pericolo che l'area fumatori diventi uno spazio invivibile, come lo sono le carrozze per fumatori sui treni. Io stesso viaggio in quelle non fumatori e mi sposto solo quando voglio accendere una sigaretta . . .

Alessio - La ritengo valida. La decisione di fumare è individuale, ma non deve mettere di mezzo gli altri. Ci vogliono regole precise con limiti di tolleranza da entrambe le parti.

Glossario/Glossary

a malincuore - reluctantly

il cafone - (coll) lout

la cicca - (coll) cigarette end

incallito - unwilling to give up

la multa - a fine

mettere di mezzo - (coll) to involve

per intenderci - that is

prendere (qualcosa) male - (coll) to get angry

i proventi - proceeds

spesso e volentieri - very often

suonato - (coll) stoned

il tossico - (coll) drug addict

visto che - (coll) since

Marco - Dove lavoro fumano in molti, ma in genere rispettano la "mia" zona, anche perché ci sono computer e macchine sofisticate ed è necessaria un'atmosfera pulita. Solo a volte ho difficoltà con persone estranee all'ufficio, che trovano naturale fumare senza chiedere il permesso. I fumatori sono una categoria a volte egoista. Quando siamo al ristorante insieme e gli amici fumano - ad esempio - mi chiedo perché non aspettino che io abbia finito di mangiare. Il rispetto nei confronti di chi non fuma è molto raro, mentre dovrebbe essere alla base di un rapporto corretto di convivenza. Massimo - Spesso e volentieri il piacere di fumare una sigaretta mi impedisce di tener conto delle esigenze dei non fumatori. Faccio il cafone. Questo succede soprattutto nelle situazioni in cui chi non fuma è in minoranza e non agguerrito. Alessio - Mi sento decisamente a disagio. La nuvola di fumo nei locali chiusi mi dà fastidio. Nel liceo dove studio è vietato fumare, ma gli studenti fumano nei bagni ogni volta che possono uscire dalla classe, trasformandoli in camere a gas! Cosa pensi della legge che vieterà il fumo in tutti i luoghi pubblici? Manuela - Se l'avessero proposta quando fumavo, l'avrei presa malissimo! Ma visto che le persone non hanno il buon senso di comportarsi più educatamente, allora approvo il divieto. Marco - Egoisticamente penso sia una legge giusta. Capisco però che possa essere una pena per chi fuma. Se ci fosse una "cultura" di rispetto reciproco, la legge potrebbe essere evitata. Vietare un piacere è una cosa negativa, ha un sapore proibizionista. Diciamo che è un provvedimento eticamente scorretto, ma a mio vantaggio! Massimo - Il primo impatto è una forte preoccupazione per la limitazione della mia libertà. Poi, pensandoci bene, mi pare una cosa giusta. Il fumo dovrebbe essere vietato nei luoghi pubblici. Sarebbe però anche bene dotare questi luoghi di uno spazio fumatori e non arrivare ad eccessi di colpevolizzazione, di tipo americano, per intenderci. C'è anche il pericolo che l'area fumatori diventi uno spazio invivibile, come lo sono le carrozze per fumatori sui treni. Io stesso viaggio in quelle non fumatori e mi sposto solo quando voglio accendere una sigaretta . . . Alessio - La ritengo valida. La decisione di fumare è individuale, ma non deve mettere di mezzo gli altri. Ci vogliono regole precise con limiti di tolleranza da entrambe le parti. fields.headline: Van Outen's return to Big Breakfast fails to boost viewers
fields.trailText: Denise Van Outen's well-publicised return to Channel 4's Big Breakfast (there were two Pope-shagging gags before 7.30am) brought the show no extra viewers on Monday morning.
fields.body:
Denise Van Outen's well-publicised return to Channel 4's Big Breakfast (there were two Pope-shagging gags before 7.30am) brought the show no extra viewers on Monday morning.

The dream team combo of Van Outen and Johnny Vaughan was hoped by the channel to provide a ratings boost through the autumn until Vaughan's contract expires at the end of the year.

But with an average of 0.4m viewers - almost exactly the same as two weeks ago, when Lisa Rogers was standing in - the Big Breakfast garnered just a 10% share of viewing, by some way the lowest breakfast time audience and less than half the viewers of GMTV.

Unofficial overnight ratings reveal that Channel 4's Big Brother continues to provide problems for the main networks in its final week.

Monday early evening was dominated by Coronation Street, EastEnders and Millionaire which all won their slots without controversy. Millionaire continues to average around 9m viewers rather than its previous dizzy heights, but an ITV spokeswoman said yesterday that the show's role is now to beat the BBC in its timeslot rather than dominate the schedules as before.

By 9pm, the schedule carve-up became a battle of dramas. A Likeness in Stone (BBC1, 9.30pm) was the first of a two-part thriller, but only achieved 5.5m viewers, a 25% share. It failed to hold on to a massive inherited audience from the 9pm news which won 7.5m viewers and a 32% share. Instead of its published schedule, ITV screened Frost at 9pm which reliably filled 90 minutes with 5.9m viewers, an average 29% share.

Channel 4's final week hour-long Big Brother made 5.3m, a 23% share. For the half-hour between 9.30pm and 10pm when all three were on together, Big Brother averaged 1m less than Frost, and 1m ahead of Likeness. The channel had to pull its 10pm documentary on Benji the binman Pell, story supplier to Fleet Street, due to legal problems, but a third outing for Sex, Lies and Aliens, a behind the scenes look at the Daily Sport, failed to impress Big Brother's viewers

fields.headline: Scoot files 'dirty tricks' dossier
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Scoot is understood to be preparing to hand over to regulators a legal dossier containing allegations of a long-running smear campaign.
fields.body:
Scoot is understood to be preparing to hand over to regulators a legal dossier containing allegations of a long-running smear campaign.

The document, which has been prepared by City law firm Charles Russell over the past five months, is believed to have identified a disgruntled former employee as the source of negative stories that have dogged the internet directory firm since the start of the year.

Many of the reports stemmed from a file that contains allegations about the company and was circulated anonymously to newspapers. When the allegations first surfaced, Scoot chief executive Robert Bonnier said they would be investigated fully and, although he was not interested in a "witch-hunt", the authorities would be informed of the result.

It is thought that the document is likely to be passed to the serious fraud office and financial services authority, and could result in a criminal investigation.

The Guardian has learned that lawyers from Charles Russell were in the high court last Monday on behalf of Scoot, attempting to extract information from potential witnesses to the smear campaign.

During those proceedings the law firm told the court that its client was in "advanced takeover talks", just hours before Scoot issued a stock exchange statement denying reports of a takeover bid.

Charles Russell said yesterday that the information was wrong and issued in error.

"An incorrect statement was made in court proceedings," a spokesman said. "The court has been informed and the statement corrected. The UK listing authorities have been informed accordingly."

Scoot last night denied reports that the FSA planned to investigate the circumstances surrounding the takeover story and the legal mix-up, although Charles Russell said it would cooperate fully if asked to take part in any further inquiries.

Mr Bonnier said: "This has been a major embarrassment on Charles Russell's behalf and they have tried to rectify it as soon as possible. We just want to get on with building this business, which goes from strength to strength.

"People are going to see some incredible things in the future which will be value-creating."

Dealers have complained that last week's rumours that a French conglomerate was about to take over Scoot and the subsequent 60% jump in the company's share price created a false market before the story was denied.

Mr Bonnier insisted that Scoot and its advisers had done their best to clarify the situation as soon as possible. "If anyone adheres to regulatory and fiduciary duties it's Scoot." Mr Bonnier had hired private detectives to track down the source of a series of price-sensitive leaks.

Shares in Scoot fell 12.25p to 148p yesterday after a weekend of negative press reports. There were claims that some investors have been aggressively selling the stock short and that individuals offshore have been conducting a campaign against Scoot.

A spokesman for the FSA confirmed it had received a complaint about the events surrounding last week's share price movement.

"We have received a letter and, in general, if there's evidence of a breach of the listing rules we would look into it," he said.

When asked if the allegations against Scoot had been dismissed by the FSA, he said: "We have not discussed in public whether we are reviewing the circumstances surrounding Scoot and therefore can't comment on any action we might be taking."

webTitle: Case at No 1 in New Establishment

fields.headline: Case at No 1 in New Establishment
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Steve Case may have built the most successful internet business in the world through his stewardship of America Online, but it took good old-fashioned media glamour for him to gain genuine acceptance.
fields.body:
Steve Case may have built the most successful internet business in the world through his stewardship of America Online, but it took good old-fashioned media glamour for him to gain genuine acceptance.

After a slow climb in the New Establishment rankings of glossy magazine Vanity Fair, Mr Case has finally reached top spot after agreeing to merge AOL with Time Warner.

This year's survey, published in the current edition, lifts him from sixth to overtake Microsoft founder Bill Gates, still hanging on in second despite his bruising encounter with the US justice department.

Gerald Levin, 18 years the senior of Mr Case and chief executive-designate of the combined group, is stuck at number four. Ted Turner, vice-chairman-designate, is at number 14.

Mr Case, 42, started his career in the marketing department of Procter & Gamble. He stumbled across the net while in charge of development for Pizza Hut.

AOL was established in 1985 via a company run ning an online service for users of Atari computer games but it was 1997's takeover of Netscape which cemented Mr Case's reputation. Vanity Fair waxes lyrical: "Once obscure, he's become a celebrity: Hollywood legend Tony Curtis recently interrupted Case and his second wife, Jean, at a Washington DC restaurant to have his picture taken with them."

Third is Sumner Redstone, chief executive of Viacom, and fifth is Rupert Murdoch, whose attempts to play catch-up in new media failed to prevent him losing second place.

The highest-ranked woman, at 40, is chat show host Oprah Winfrey, whose interests range from a cable TV channel to TV production and magazines.

fields.headline: Computer, name that tune
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Sony has come up with an answer for those infuriating moments when you hear a song on the radio that you like, but wait in vain for the DJ to name the band.
fields.body:
Sony has come up with an answer for those infuriating moments when you hear a song on the radio that you like, but wait in vain for the DJ to name the band.

The eMarker is a tiny electronic device wrapped in an orange plastic oval and designed to hang from a keyring.

When its owner hears a mystery tune, he or she clicks a button and the eMarker notes the time, just like a stop watch. When the device is plugged into a PC, it launches the eMarker website, and all that remains to do is to key in the name of the radio station, and up comes the title of the tune.

The website also offers information about the song, audio clips, and samples of other songs from the album. There are also links to retailers to buy the album, with the site receiving a commission for every sale. Up to 10 songs from a variety of stations can be stored by the eMarker to be looked up at leisure.

It is the first product of a new Sony subsidiary, eMarker.com, whose purpose is to create products that link the old media with the new. Future versions will work with music video channels, and advertisements.

However, British music fans will have to wait to get their hands on the new toy. It is at present only available in the US (at $19.99), where the eMarker website obtains playlist information from Broadcast Data Systems, the company that supplies radio airplay data to Billboard magazine for its charts.

No decision has been taken on offering it in Britain.

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Jacky Furet's bar was used on August 30 to give first aid to victims of a train derailment
fields.trailText: Jacky Furet's bar was used on August 30 to give first aid to victims of a train derailment
fields.body:
Il était environ 13 h 20 lorsque la première voiture d'une rame de métro s'est renversée à la station Notre-Dame-de-Lorette qui se trouve juste en face de mon bar. Quelques secondes plus tard, une employée de la RATP s'est précipitée dans mon établissement pour appeler la police. On ne savait pas encore s'il s'agissait d'un accident ou d'un attentat.

Les secours sont arrivés très rapidement. Le plan rouge a été déclenché et toutes les rues avoisinantes ont été barrées. On se serait cru dans un tremblement de terre tellement il y avait de monde : police, pompiers, Samu, Croix-Rouge, psychologues, j'avais rarement vu un tel remue-ménage.

Mon café a été réquisitionné comme hôpital de premiers secours. C'est ici que les premiers soins ont été donnés. Heureusement, il n'y avait pas de blessés graves. Uniquement quelques égratignures superficielles et des fractures. En fait, il y a eu plus de peur que de mal. Les voyageurs étaient choqués, affolés, ébahis.

Nous leur avons servi des rafrachissements. Nous avons essayé de les réconforter. On a fait ce qu'on a pu pour les aider. Et puis, il fallait répondre au téléphone qui n'arrêtait pas de sonner ! Un périmètre de sécurité empêchait les journalistes de passer, donc ils nous appelaient pour savoir ce qui s'était passé. Mais nous avions autre chose à faire à ce moment-là !

À aucun moment je n'ai paniqué. Il ne faut pas s'affoler. Il faut garder les pieds sur terre et son sang-froid, pour être en mesure d'aider ceux qui en ont besoin.

Malgré tout, j'ai toujours confiance dans le métro parisien, les accidents sont si rares ! Les victimes aussi s'en remettront car quoi qu'il arrive, la vie continue.

Glossaire/Glossary

ils étaient affolés: they were scared out of their wits

tre ébahi: to be astounded

une égratignure: a scratch

se précipiter: to rush

premiers secours, soin: first aid

se remettre de: to recover from

un remue-ménage: a hubbub

fields.headline: Lastminute lock-up
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Shares in online retailer Lastminute.com went into reverse yesterday as the six-month lock-up period, in which management and certain institutional investors were not allowed to sell their shares, came to an end.
fields.body:
Shares in online retailer Lastminute.com went into reverse yesterday as the six-month lock-up period, in which management and certain institutional investors were not allowed to sell their shares, came to an end.

The shares, which closed 9p, or 4.89%, lower at 175p could mount a recovery today.

A statement released after the market closed dislcosed that co-founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox and certain institutional investors have voluntarily agreed to extend their lock-up agreements with the company's broker, Morgan Stanley.

Together with the holdings of Mr Hoberman and Ms Lane Fox, this represents around 90% of the shares that were locked-up at the time of Lastminute's initial public offering back in March.

Investors should note that the extension to the lock-up period is only a further three months.

fields.trailText: Jens Nowotny is the man Arsenal want as the long-term successor to Tony Adams, claims the Daily Mail. Bayer Leverkusen have already turned down a bid that would have allowed the German international to play in the latter stages of this season's Champions League - Arsene Wenger will return in the summer to land his man.

Jens Nowotny is the man Arsenal want as the long-term successor to Tony Adams, claims the Daily Mail. Bayer Leverkusen have already turned down a bid that would have allowed the German international to play in the latter stages of this season's Champions League - Arsene Wenger will return in the summer to land his man.

Gianfranco Zola could be the next boss of Chelsea. Current manager Gianluca Vialli is under pressure after a poor start to the season and could either walk or be sacked, according to an exclusive in The Sun. They claim Vialli's precarious position is the reason Zola was not sold to Napoli in the summer.

Albert Ferrer, meanwhile, could be on his way to Manchester City, according to the Mirror. The former Barcelona player is now third-choice right-back at Stamford Bridge - Joe Royle is about to lodge a £1.2m offer.

Bradford, Aston Villa and Manchester City are all interested in Liverpool's 31-year-old left-back Steve Staunton.

West Ham have joined Spurs and Newcastle in the hunt for £1m Colchester striker Lomana Lua Lua. The Star also claims that the Hammers have been given first option on the player.

Ipswich have offered £2m for Tirol Innsbruck's Slovenian international defender Aleksander Knavs.

Crystal Palace will sign Latvian keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko today from Skonto Riga for £500,000.

Planet Football report that Dundee will offer a permanent deal to 28-year-old Argentinian international Beto Carranza if the midfielder impresses in a trial game tonight.

fields.headline: FTC slams Hollywood for inappropriate targeting of teenagers
fields.trailText: The US Federal Trade Commission has slammed Hollywood studios for marketing violent and adult-oriented films to teenagers.
fields.body:
The US Federal Trade Commission has slammed Hollywood studios for marketing violent and adult-oriented films to teenagers.

The FTC's report on the marketing of violent films, games and music was unveiled yesterday, following a year-long study.

It lambasts Hollywood for targeting young people with films, music and computer games that are inappropriate to their age and accuses studios of promoting products aimed at adults in venues where children are likely to be.

FTC chairman Bob Pitofsky said he would prefer marketers to take voluntary action to limit where their advertisements are run.

However, he added that the FTC is investigating whether it has the authority to take action against marketers who rate their products for over-18s, then advertise them to teenagers.

The investigation was ordered by president Bill Clinton in the wake of last year's Columbine high school massacre in Littleton, Colorado. In April 1999, 15 students died when two of their classmates opened fire. The classroom massacre was the worst in US history and prompted intense political debate about the effects of screen violence.

webTitle: News in brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: News in brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: No more the loyal sidekick as Dana 'Garth' Carvey turns on Mike 'Wayne' Myers, Luc Besson parts company with 20th Century Fox, old broads Joan Collins and Elizabeth Taylor demand new bodies, pop princess Kylie to shrug off acting hiatus to be a fairy, John Malkovich continues his run of nefarious roles, and Scary Spice to star in kung-fu movie
fields.body:
 It seems that everyone has got it in for Mike Myers (pictured) at the moment. After the recent legal wranglings with Fox over the Dieter film (see earlier story), Myers has now been accused of stealing character ideas from his former co-star Dana Carvey. Carvey, who played Myers' loyal sidekick Garth Elgar in Wayne's World, claims HE created a character based on Saturday Night Live producer Lorne Michaels which was subsequently incarnated as Dr Evil in the Austin Powers films. In a statement to Vanity Fair magazine, Myers denies the charges, saying, "Austin Powers and Dr Evil were born out of my love for James Bond movies, and Dr Evil is a homage to the great characters created by Donald Pleasance, mixed in with a bit of Lorne."

 French film director Luc Besson has parted company with 20th Century Fox after two years of partnership. The collaboration between Seaside, Besson's production company, and 20th Century Fox was set to be renewed in December but so far no film has come out of this cooperation. Rumours were circulating last month that Seaside would produce the film WW3.com, with Fox distributing, but a source at Fox now confirms, "The partnership between Seaside and Fox will cease in December. We don't know what's the future of WW3.com."

 Hollywood old gals Joan Collins and Elizabeth Taylor are both demanding body-doubles 40 years their junior for their new film These Old Broads. The film, which also stars Shirley MacLaine, Debbie Reynolds and June Allyson, is set for release in 2001. It also stars 75-year-old Tony Curtis, who is reportedly more than happy to perform his closeups himself. He proudly stated: "I'm not in bad shape for my age."

 Rumours are that diminutive pop princess Kylie Minogue is set to appear as a fairy in Baz Lurhman's new movie musical Moulin Rouge. The film stars Ewan McGregor as a young poet who sets off for bohemian Paris in 1899, where he encounters a sultry courtesan played by Nicole Kidman. Apparently, the film ran into trouble when test screenings showed that the audience was confused by the somewhat anachronistic musical. Luhrman has therefore written in the new character of the fairy - who only Kidman's character can see - to make the film more intelligible.

 John Malkovich is apparently considering the role of the Green Goblin in the big screen adaptation of Spider-Man, says Yahoo.com. Insiders claim that Malkovich looks likely to take the dual role of the Goblin, who by day is the next-door neighbour of nice guy Peter Parker/Spiderman (to be played by Tobey Maguire) but by night is his mortal nemesis.

 Patsy Kensit and Mel B, aka Scary Spice, are set to star in a British martial arts movie called Razor, which will feature glamorous women performing kung-fu stunts.

webTitle: Mountaineer's son fights to ban story of failed South Pole trek

fields.headline: Mountaineer's son fights to ban story of failed South Pole trek
fields.trailText: Peter Hillary, the explorer son of Sir Edmund Hillary - who conquered Everest in 1953 - is trying to ban a book about his failed expedition to the South Pole and back because it could ruin his mountaineering reputation.
fields.body:
Peter Hillary, the explorer son of Sir Edmund Hillary - who conquered Everest in 1953 - is trying to ban a book about his failed expedition to the South Pole and back because it could ruin his mountaineering reputation.

Hillary, a New Zealander, who took part in an ill-fated trip to the South Pole last year with fellow explorers Australians Eric Philips and Jon Muir, is trying to prevent publication of the book which gives a detailed account of the gruelling 84-day journey. He claims the account, written by Philips, makes him look bungling and inept.

The publicity material for the book, Ice Trek, a journey to the South Pole, describes how the trio set out to complete the 3,000-kilometre journey from Ross Island to the South Pole and back, further than anyone had traversed Antarctica.

"This is Eric Philips's account of a very public journey and a very public falling out on the ice," say publishers HarperCollins.

"The journey across Antarctica was conducted in a blaze of publicity which included regular phone calls live to a television show and an internet site through which the public could follow the team's progress.

"The venture was hampered by appalling weather, which kept the men tent-bound for longer than they had anticipated. Soon illness stalked the team. Despite this they reached the pole but never completed the return journey. On their return, the tensions between the team members erupted in a very public falling out, mainly between Eric and Peter."

The expedition, called Ice Trek, was sponsored by the now bankrupt satellite phone company Iridium. It ended when the trio reached the South Pole in January 26 last year.

Already delayed by illness and bad weather, they were airlifted back to McMurdo Sound instead of walking as planned.

Disagreements between the camp were made public on their return when Philips criticised Hillary and Muir, saying they lacked the necessary skills to fly special kites that were to have towed their sleds for much of the journey.

Hillary said he had read an advance copy of Philips's book and described it as a "jaundiced and self-centred" personal account devoted to "revealing Hillary".

"We didn't get on. It was a lonely expedition," Hillary said, adding: "It [the book] is an assault on me. It is certainly a slap in the face, there's no doubt about it."

Hillary added that he wanted an official account of the trip to be published, not a "weirdly obsessive book" such as that written by Philips. He claims it breaches a contract between the trio not to publish anything within three years of the expedition ending.

"Personal accounts of the expedition were not to be published until three years after the end of the expedition. Obviously Eric has gone ahead and done this and I don't think he is standing by his word."

Hillary said he was writing his own book but would wait until the agreed three-year term was up before publishing it.

But author Philips and fellow explorer Muir say they have no idea why Hillary is claiming the book breaks a legal agreement signed by the three adventurers.

Backing Philips, Muir added that it was clear to him and should be to Hillary that the book did not break the contract at all. Speaking from Australia, he added that the contract made it quite clear a book would be written.

He had even provided journal extracts to Philips to help him write the book but was not due to share in any of the author's profits.

Asked if the book was an unflattering account of Hillary, Muir said it showed the strengths and weaknesses of the team.

Philips said that while Hillary might not like the way he was portrayed in parts of the book, at issue was that Philips had described it as an official record of the expedition.

A HarperCollins spokeswoman said she could not say what the legal wrangle over Philips's book involved, but added: "We are confident it will be resolved."

webTitle: Court rules UK drivers must pay toll VAT

fields.headline: Court rules UK drivers must pay toll VAT
fields.standfirst: European court of justice
fields.trailText: British motorists must pay VAT on road toll charges, the European Court of Justice ruled today.
fields.body:
British motorists must pay VAT on road toll charges, the European Court of Justice ruled today.

The Luxembourg judges backed a European Commission case that such charges are subject to VAT - a share of which is passed to Brussels as a major contribution to the EU budget.

The extra cost will now apply to all bridge and tunnel tolls in the UK to comply with EU VAT laws.

Under a 23-year old EU rule, VAT must be levied on "taxable persons" - but the rules say public authorities are not considered to be "taxable persons" and governments need not impose VAT on services provided by public authorities.

The Government says only three UK toll crossings - the Dartford Crossing, the Severn Bridge and the Skye Bridge - are operated by private businesses.

The Erskine Bridge over the River Clyde is owned by the Secretary of State for Scotland and operated by him in his role as the "roads authority".

The Tyne and Mersey Tunnels, the Tay, Tamar, Humber, Cleddau, Forth Road and Clifton Suspension Bridges are all owned and operated by public authorities.

But the Commission argues the "taxable persons" being targeted are the paying motorists and not the toll operators.

Not only private motorists will be hit - the Treasury also faces a hefty back-payment running into millions of pounds because a share of all national VAT receipts must be passed to Brussels to help finance the European budget. Brussels can seek retrospective payments as far back as 1994.

Liberal Democrat MEP Chris Davies said motorists using the Mersey Tunnels as well as major crossings such as the Humber and Severn bridges would be hardest hit. The cost of using the Hawkshead ferry across Windermere in the Lake District could also be affected.

Mr Davies, a member of the European Parliament's transport committee, said the Government could opt to abolish tolls for estuary crossings.

webTitle: A short interview with Jennifer Lopez

fields.headline: My five minutes with Jennifer
fields.standfirst: Emma Brockes  thought she had an interview with superstar actress Jennifer Lopez. What she ended up with was a classic example of PR farce
fields.trailText: Emma Brockes thought she had an interview with superstar actress Jennifer Lopez. What she ended up with was a classic example of PR farce
fields.body:
It is 2.45pm on a hot Monday afternoon and the mood on the first floor of London's Dorchester Hotel is getting ugly. Jennifer Lopez, actress, singer, girlfriend of rap star Puff Daddy, is somewhere not far away, deep within the marshmallow furnishings of her hotel suite while an assembly of journalists waits to interview her. There have been some last minute "adjustments" to the schedule and the question on everybody's mind is, how long will we get with her and who do we have to kill to get longer?

The time allowance for these sorts of interviews, when an actor holds court in a hotel room and parcels out dreary half-hour slots to plug her latest movie, are negotiated down to the last minute. But even by the absurd standards of the Hollywood PR machine, there is an air of surrealism to the afternoon's itinerary. According to the publicist's schedule, I am down to hobnob with Lopez for a quarter of an hour, between the minutes of 2.46 and 3.01. And I am one of the lucky ones.

The holding room into which the journalists are herded is provided with refreshments and a television tuned to Sky news. It is hot and the mood is fractious. Two radio journalists have just been told that their time with Lopez has been axed from 13 minutes to 11 and they speculate on how much of that they will have to give over to talking about her new film. Called The Cell, it is a truly appalling sci-fi flick directed by Tarsem, winner of the 1991 MTV best video award for his direction of the video for REM's Losing My Religion. The Cell, his debut film - featuring Vince Vaughn and an uncomfortable looking Marianne Jean-Baptiste - is like one long music video with a serial killer subplot. "We'll lose at least five minutes while she goes on about that," says the radio journalist, rolling his eyes.

Meanwhile, on the mustard-coloured sofa across the room, the television contingent are checking their watches and trying to salvage some kind of continuity from a mini-script Lopez has agreed to read from and which they have had to slash at the last minute. They have just been told they have 10 minutes with her. "Long enough to show us what a great acting talent she is," says one, oozing sarcasm.

Into this unhappy atmosphere comes a publicist, manfully holding up a clipboard and trying to inject some kind of professionalism into the mounting farce, by talking in sharp, I-mean-business tones. "Independent on Sunday?" he raps, and after waiting for a second follows it up with, "No? OK, Guardian? Guardian? Come with me." It is quite possible that the reporter from the Independent on Sunday has gone to the loo and not only missed his cue, but missed the entire span of his interview. "Wait in here," says an American PR. "You've got five minutes." So, here are my five minutes with Jennifer Lopez.

Lopez, a 31-year-old American of Puerto Rican parentage, backs into the room, sharing a joke with an unseen flunky on the other side of the door. She laughs all the way to the sofa and turns round at the last minute, gliding into place and fixing me with a bright smile. "Hi." She is pretty, with gold eyeshadow and perfect teeth. I have five questions for her and am confident of extracting the maximum amount of cliches in the time allowed. Luckily, she talks quickly.

Minute one: What was it about the script of The Cell that appealed to you?

"It was kinda like Silence of the Lambs, which I had read years before. It just seemed like it had a lot of room for creative licence, you know what I mean? I mean, with the right director I thought it could be something really special, which is what it turned out to be. It's just a great, scary movie. I think what art is about is the expression of different opinions and different things and different artists are inspired by different things and sometimes that's not positive, it's negative."

Minute two: Did you do any research for your role as Catherine Deane, a psychologist who through the medium of "transcendental science" experiences what is going on in other people's psyches?

"I do research for all my roles. Yeees. For this one, since I was playing a therapist, I went kinda undercover to see a therapist, you know, used a different name and kinda just wanted to see how a female therapist interacted with a patient. I wasn't recognised. I don't think she knew who I was."

Minute three: To what extent did you empathise with the character you were playing?

"Um, a lot. I mean, she's very passionate, and very driven to help these people in her job, you know what I mean? But what was interesting to me, was the fact that it was almost to her own detriment, so that she was sacrificing herself. Like a sacrificial lamb in a way, especially when it came to going into the killer's mind not once or twice, but three times."

(At this stage the publicist quietly opens the door and holds up two fingers to indicate that I have two minutes left).

Minute four: What do you think is your greatest achievement as an actress so far?

(Big sigh) "I don't know. Maybe a movie I just did called Angel Eyes. I'm not sure, I'll have to see it first. I'm so focused when I'm working, you know what I mean, I don't go outside of my head and think, 'I'm really achieving now.' I kinda really just try to stay focused on what I'm doing that day and who I am and stuff like that. I think when you start examining yourself like that you get into a little bit of trouble."

Minute five: Can you give me five words to describe yourself?

"Loving, strong, passionate, sensitive. [Long pause.] Um, caring."

And five words to describe Puffy?

"Yeah, I could. I would say he is powerful, charismatic, caring, dynamic. [Long pause.] Sweet."

This time there is a proper knock at the door and the publicist enters, head cocked to one side in an "Isn't this just crazy?" apologetic pose. I wish Lopez good luck for the premiere tonight. "Thanks," she says. "Are you coming?" I shake my head and walk down the corridor, where a set of gold-backed chairs has been lined up to accommodate the next five interviewers.

fields.headline: Club coaches face refuelling problems
fields.trailText: Refuelling problems have largely disappeared from the sporting lexicon since Graham Taylor questioned Paul Gascoigne's eating and drinking habits during his tenure as England manager. But the petrol shortages which have led to panic buying across many parts of England and Wales have prompted several clubs and organisations to make contingency plans.
fields.body:
Refuelling problems have largely disappeared from the sporting lexicon since Graham Taylor questioned Paul Gascoigne's eating and drinking habits during his tenure as England manager. But the petrol shortages which have led to panic buying across many parts of England and Wales have prompted several clubs and organisations to make contingency plans.

Rochdale, who go to York in tonight's extensive Nationwide League programme and host Torquay on Saturday, have urged their Merseyside-based players to "keep a careful eye on their fuel tanks and phone in if there are any problems". Their manager Steve Parkin, who lives in Worksop, says he is "even considering staying in Rochdale".

Cricket has also been affected. Glamorgan, who have a match with Middlesex starting in Cardiff tomorrow, have made provisional arrangements for their West Walians, such as Robert Croft and Steve Watkin, to stay in the Welsh capital all week.

With only four petrol stations in Cardiff selling unleaded fuel yesterday afternoon, Middlesex have been advised to ensure their team coach has a full tank for the return.

Football fans have also been warned, with John Nagle of the Football League saying: "Supporters may like to consider car-sharing or perhaps club transport."

Paul Ince has already become a petrol-crisis victim, although it spared him another rollicking from Bryan Robson, still fuming at the performance of his captain and many other Middlesbrough players in the home defeat by Everton.

Ince yesterday failed to make it for training on Teesside from his Merseyside home because he ran out of fuel.

According to Robson, Ince needs more drive anyway. "Paul knows he can step up his work rate," he said.
