But the petrol shortages which have led to panic buying across many parts of England and Wales have prompted several clubs and organisations to make contingency plans. Rochdale, who go to York in tonight's extensive Nationwide League programme and host Torquay on Saturday, have urged their Merseyside-based players to "keep a careful eye on their fuel tanks and phone in if there are any problems". Their manager Steve Parkin, who lives in Worksop, says he is "even considering staying in Rochdale". Cricket has also been affected. Glamorgan, who have a match with Middlesex starting in Cardiff tomorrow, have made provisional arrangements for their West Walians, such as Robert Croft and Steve Watkin, to stay in the Welsh capital all week. With only four petrol stations in Cardiff selling unleaded fuel yesterday afternoon, Middlesex have been advised to ensure their team coach has a full tank for the return. Football fans have also been warned, with John Nagle of the Football League saying: "Supporters may like to consider car-sharing or perhaps club transport." Paul Ince has already become a petrol-crisis victim, although it spared him another rollicking from Bryan Robson, still fuming at the performance of his captain and many other Middlesbrough players in the home defeat by Everton. Ince yesterday failed to make it for training on Teesside from his Merseyside home because he ran out of fuel. According to Robson, Ince needs more drive anyway. "Paul knows he can step up his work rate," he said.

webTitle: Who will replace Allen as head of UK Online?

fields.headline: Who will take the helm of UK Online?
fields.trailText: Following the resignation of Alex Allen, the government's e-envoy, who will oversee the setting up of new initiatives for UK Online?
fields.body:
With £1bn being invested by the government in setting up UK Online, attention is now being shifted to who will oversee the setting up of the new initiatives following the resignation last week of Alex Allen, the government's e-envoy.

Allen, who is to step down in October and return to Australia, said his reason for leaving the post at such a crucial time was because he needed to spend more time with his family.

The search is now on for who will replace him, and the government has opened it up to the industry as well as other government ministers.

Top of the list is Ann Steward, director of e-government for the Cabinet Office, who is said to be the most obvious choice if the government chooses to make an internal appointment. A story on Silicon.com suggested a number of other alternatives including Rene Carayol, currently chairman at ePhotomail and former founder of IPC Electric, who has always said it's his long-term ambition to move into politics. Jim Norton, head of e-commerce policy at the Institute of Directors, who is believed to have only narrowly missed the appointment last year, has publicly declared his interest, as has Margaret Smith, director of business technology and delivery at Legal & General.

Last time around it took the government more than six months to make the appointment. After interviewing a number of top industry candidates Many ruled themselves out in the first stage, not wanting to become a scapegoat for the government's e-policy or take a hefty pay cut. This time around the government's e-policy is much clearer, albeit very wide-ranging. However, given the time it takes to shortlist and interview suitable candidates, it is unlikely that the government will be able to find a replacement until the new year.

fields.headline: Publicis reveals agency's balance of power
fields.trailText: The Publicis Group has disclosed how voting rights will be allocated following its acquisition of Saatchi & Saatchi.
fields.body:
The recently enlarged Publicis Group has disclosed how voting rights will be allocated following its acquisition of Saatchi & Saatchi.

The move comes as shares in the new Publicis Group today begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange as American Depositary Receipts.

The greatest voting power will be wielded by the family of Publicis founder Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, which holds 36.63% of the voting rights and 22.84% of the shares.

An additional 9.19% of the voting rights will be held by Elisabeth Badinter, chairman of the Publicis Groupe's supervisory board.

Former Saatchi shareholders will hold 24.4% of the voting rights, while public shareholders will control 26.72%.

Publicis chairman Maurice Levy said yesterday that the company was aiming for 12-15% organic growth over the next few years. He added that there were no plans for further acquisitions in Europe or the US, but that the group was still aiming to reinforce its presence in Japan.

webTitle: England strike it rich on the lottery

fields.headline: England strike it rich on the lottery
fields.trailText: The England women's team are celebrating a triple-orange jackpot on the slot machines: they have been awarded a £94,625 grant from the lottery. It's not the largest sum in the world - it would barely cover the Millennium Dome's tea bill - but it was all that the ECB had asked, or hoped for. "We are absolutely delighted with the amount," said Andrea Wiggins, media relations officer.
fields.body:
The England women's team are celebrating a triple-orange jackpot on the slot machines: they have been awarded a £94,625 grant from the lottery. It's not the largest sum in the world - it would barely cover the Millennium Dome's tea bill - but it was all that the ECB had asked, or hoped for. "We are absolutely delighted with the amount," said Andrea Wiggins, media relations officer.

The sum will be divided between the 18 members of the provisional World Cup squad, which was also announced yesterday. (Karen Smithies, who resigned as England captain halfway through last winter's disastrous tour of Australia and New Zealand, has not been selected. It means that she has almost certainly played her last game for England.)

And it will make a big difference to the way the team are able to live and train, allowing players to take the odd day off to work on their game when they feel the need. It also means that players can use local facilities and local specialists if they need to, rather than grinning and bearing things until the squad meet at Lilleshall, Shropshire, for coaching weekends.

A team which used to have to scrape around the country, paying for their own meals, their own train tickets, and their own kit will now be almost fully funded. The players remain unpaid, but the ECB hope that the grant will give them "the training and preparation they need whilst balancing their working and family lives".

The bid was a freestanding one, but it forms part of a further proposal from the ECB, for lottery funding of a ten-year development plan.

The lottery is not England Women's only source of cash. They, like the men, are sponsored by Vodafone, and the World Cup itself is being sponsored by CricInfo, which will ensure that hotel rooms and flights are paid for.

The final World Cup squad of 14 will be announced in mid-October. They will depart for New Zealand on November 12, fitter, healthier, and richer than ever before. Unfortunately the other eight teams will be too.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read last week's column, in which Catherine Hanley writes an open letter to Channel 4's Cricket Roadshow, click here

webTitle: Catholics to root out paedophile priests

fields.headline: Catholics to root out paedophile priests
fields.trailText: One of the most senior figures in the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales has announced an initiative aimed at rooting out paedophile Catholic priests.
fields.body:
One of the most senior figures in the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales has announced an initiative aimed at rooting out paedophile Catholic priests.

Archbishop Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the Archbishop of Westminster, is to the set up a national inquiry - likely to be chaired by a Catholic judge or peer - aimed at rooting out paedophile priests.

He is also to outline new guidelines and codes of practice on child abuse at a news conference in London. The archbishop came under fire in July, just four months after his installation at Westminster, over the case of Father Michael Hill. Hill, who was released last week, served three-and-a-half years of a five-year prison sentence imposed in 1997 for nine sex attacks - which included one on a boy with learning difficulties he met at the Gatwick Airport chapel after the youngster missed his flight.

The archbishop faced calls to resign when it emerged that he was responsible for appointing Hill as chaplain to the airport even though concerns had been raised about his behaviour.

Hill had been a priest in the archbishop's former diocese of Arundel and Brighton in West Sussex.

The archbishop admitted he had made a mistake but resisted calls to step down. Hill, whose parish was Heathfield in East Sussex, was permanently suspended from priestly ministry after his conviction. In 1985 he had been allowed back to work after earlier having his licence revoked.

In July, the Most Rev Murphy-O'Connor said about Hill: "It is true to say that if the strict procedures for child protection that are now in place (in the Diocese of Arundel and Brighton) had been in operation in 1985, then (Hill's) situation would have been handled differently.

"I maintain that with the facts then known to me the decisions made at that time in his regard were not irresponsible."

fields.trailText:
The Independent
Media section
Conrad Black has put the Jerusalem Post up for sale, Phil Reeves says he has rejected an offer of $20m, because he wants $80m.
fields.body:
The Independent
Media section
Conrad Black has put the Jerusalem Post up for sale, Phil Reeves says he has rejected an offer of $20m, because he wants $80m.

Naomi Marks compiles a report on how hard it is for the press at major sporting events such as the Olympics.

Michael Davies, the happiest man in US TV, tells Damian Fowler how delighted he is to be single-handedly responsible for the rise of UK reality TV in the US.

Liza Kliman, radio producer, is fed up with the review of Radio 4 suppliers.

Lorraine Butler, new editor of Cosmopolitan, says she won't change the tone of the magazine but will be cleverer and work a bit harder.

In the diary: David Elstein, the chairman of Channel 5, is said to be on his way out following network owner RTL*s decision that the network should be less sleazy, and head of programming Dawn Airey could be off to ITV.

The Mirror
Changing Rooms designer Laura McCree burst into tears after homeowner Heather Cairns said her debut design was "absolute crap". Mrs Cairns' guest room was given a modernist makeover, much to her disdain.

The BBC has apologised to Prince Phillip after Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed called the royal a "German Nazi" in the dire Nick Hancock chatshow You Only Live Once.

A Norfolk shopowner has claimed that struggling retailer Marks & Spencer stole her ideas for its recent advertising revamp.

The Star
Extensive Emmys coverage focuses mainly on celebrity cleavage (Heather Locklear) and a still-skinny Calista Flockhart.

The Changing Rooms disaster reported in all the tabloids gets a full page ("Changing Glooms") with designer Laura McCree in tears after her minimalist revamp was deemed "crap" by its owners.

The Mail
Ronnie Barker laid into Reeves and Mortimer at a party to celebrate the 40th anniversary of TV Centre. Seems Barker took offence at their remaking a Morecambe and Wise sketch with Tom Jones.

Jane McDonald - star of docu-soap the Cruise - got 6m viewers for talent show Star for a Night while Cilla Black's Moment of Truth got 5.7m.

The battle to replace Boris Johnson continues. According to Ephraim Hardcastle, Telegraph editor Charles Moore is pushing for columnist Alice Thomson to be the next editor of the Spectator. Conrad Black (proprietor of the group) wants Sunday Telegraph deputy editor Matthew d'Ancona.

The Times
Reports from New York that the six remaining US contestants on Big Brother are plotting to spoil the party by walking out on air together. Mutiny.

The Guardian
Electronics giant Sony is to launch a device called eMarker, which marks down any unidentified song you hear on the radio and names it for you.

Tony Blair has pledged to get all of Britain online by 2005, by spending £1bn on 6,000 computer centres.

The Financial Times
Shai Schiller has resigned as chief executive of video-over-the-internet company and stock market darling Geo Interactive Media, with analysts saying it had damaged the company's image.

The rush to capture the online "pink pound" is gathering pace with the launch next month of Queer Company, an internet portal aimed at the gay and lesbian community.

Wall Street Journal
Publicis has closed its acquisition of Saatchi & Saatchi, making it a global company with more than Euro 2.1bn in annual revenue.

Publisher Gannett has told its operating divisions to keep a tight rein on their 2001 budgets, after it spent $4.5bn on new publications and publishers.

Car manufacturer Mercedes is to adopt a lighter, hipper image, shedding its stuffy image.

Tabloid scoop of the day:
The Star seems to have sent three ex-SAS men to break into the Big Brother house armed with just a copy of the paper and a box of Milk Tray. It claims to have the pictures to prove it, but a C4 spokeswoman insists the break-in could not have happened.

Apparently one of C5's Jailbreak inmates has already tried to escape after just 12 hours. The series launches tonight.

fields.headline: Big Brother computer game launched
fields.trailText: The makers of Channel 4s cult series Big Brother are to give fans a chance to stop gossiping around Britains water coolers and pit their wits against "Nasty" Nick Bateman and his fellow housemates in a computer version of the game show.
fields.body:
The makers of Channel 4s cult series Big Brother are to give fans a chance to stop gossiping around Britains water coolers and pit their wits against "Nasty" Nick Bateman and his fellow housemates in a computer version of the game show.

Taking on the role of their favourite contestant, players will have to complete an assortment of domestic tasks, including stacking crockery in the kitchen and stocking up the pantry, before being rewarded with a visit to the diary room. But if they fail in their tasks, of course, they will be evicted from the house.

Visits to the diary room allow the shows fans to pore over clips of the most memorable moments from the series  the first week's body painting, Sadas song, or the dastardly dealings of Nick. They can then enter their top score on an internet-based league table.

The final and most challenging level of the game tracks the housemates after eviction as they confront the paparazzi. Players assume the role of unscrupulous photographers hunting down contestants and snapping them as many times as they can before the clock runs out.

While some will consider the £9.99 virtual simulation of the Channel 4 show akin to George Orwells Room 101, a hard core of obsessives will be delighted when the game is launched on Friday, the final day of the televised show.

Infogrames, the games publisher, said: The game will be a must-have antidote for all sufferers of the Big Brother withdrawal symptoms that will set in when the series finishes.

But Paul Benjamin, who is supervising the its launch, admitted the Big Brother phenomenon was expanding at an alarming rate and taking over peoples lives. Ratings have gone up to 4m, the internet hits are massive, a CD of the shows music is in top 10 and climbing, and we expect the same of our computer game, he said. It is taking over peoples lives.

The finale of the television show will be held over two hour-long slots on Friday night when viewers will vote for the eight-week long contest's winner. They will decide which of Anna Nolan, Darren Ramsey or Craig Phillips wins the shows top prize of £70,000.

fields.headline: It's official - anti-smoking ads really work
fields.trailText: Anti-smoking ads really do help people to kick the habit, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Anti-smoking ads really do help people to kick the habit, according to research published today.

Smokers in regions where anti-smoking ads were broadcast were more than 50% more likely to succeed in giving up than those in areas where there was no campaign, according to a study by the journal Tobacco Control.

Researchers assessed the impact of an 18-month TV campaign conducted by the now-defunct Health Education Authority between 1992 and 1994. The ads, which starred John Cleese, were designed to motivate people to stop smoking and were broadcast in the Tyne Tees, Yorkshire and Granada regions.

The researchers then compared the rate of quitting smoking in those regions with the Central area, where the campaign was not broadcast. They found that in areas where the ads ran, 7.45% of smokers quit the habit, and only 3.3% of ex-smokers lapsed, while in the Central region 5% quit and 5% of ex-smokers relapsed over an 18-month period.

The net effect of the campaign, which cost £12.5 million, was to reduce adult smoking by about 1.2%. The researchers concluded that TV campaigns were "highly cost-effective" compared with the huge burden placed on the NHS by smoking-related diseases.

webTitle: Granada buys 45% stake in Ireland's fast-growing TV3

fields.headline: Granada buys 45% stake in Ireland's fast-growing TV3
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday took a 45% stake in TV3, Ireland's only free-to-air commercial television channel, and said it hoped the deal would prove a blueprint for future partnerships across Europe.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday took a 45% stake in TV3, Ireland's only free-to-air commercial television channel, and said it hoped the deal would prove a blueprint for future partnerships across Europe.

As a key part of the agreement Ireland's top rated programme, Granada soap Coronation Street, will move to TV3 from state-owned RTE at the beginning of next year.

TV3 will also begin showing another Granada favourite, Emmerdale.

The deal is part of Granada's ambition to begin building a presence across Europe after securing dominance of the ITV network at home. Charles Allen, Granada chairman described the TV3 deal as "a significant first step" in achieving its aims.

Granada will pay £18.7m in cash for the stake and will be an equal shareholder with Canada's CanWest Global Communications.

The remainder is held by the founders of TV3 led by chairman James Morris who also runs Ireland's biggest independent production group Windmill Lane Pictures.

TV3 launched two years ago against Ireland's three state-owned channels. Its broad mix of entertainment, films, drama, sport and news has built an audience share of just under 10%.

fields.headline: On paper
fields.standfirst:
Elisabeth Murdoch joins magazine publisher

mediaguardian
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Murdoch, who quit her father's News Corporation media empire in May, yesterday took her first directorship since leaving the family firm.
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch, who quit her father's News Corporation media empire in May, yesterday took her first directorship since leaving the family firm.

Ms Murdoch, 32, is joining the board of Future Publishing, the consumer and business magazine group, as a non-executive director, with immediate effect.

Chris Anderson, Future's chairman said he expected her experience to "add hugely" to the business which owns titles including the official PlayStation magazine, Business 2.0 and Total Film. "She's a very smart media thinker and will help us to raise the bar and realise how big this business can be."

Ms Murdoch was introduced to Future when she agreed to sit on the advisory board of the internet magazine Business 2.0.

Future also reported a 29% increase in revenues to £111m for the first half of the year. Record investment in new titles caused pre-tax losses to rise from £9.1m to £13.5m.

webTitle: Carlton Productions picks up nineties commission from ITV2

fields.headline: Carlton Productions wins 30-hour commission from ITV2
fields.trailText: Carlton Productions has landed a 30-hour commission from ITV2 covering the highlights of the past decade.
fields.body:
Carlton Productions has landed a 30-hour commission from ITV2 covering the highlights of the past decade.

The Total Nineties, three hours of themed programming a night, will run for 10 weeks on Saturday nights on ITV2. A mixture of entertainment programmes, archive Coronation Street episodes, news montages and the theme nights aim to build an audience.

Previous ITV2 theme nights such as Abba Night and those built around ITV shows including Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and Coronation Street have been one-offs but the new commission is part of a strategy to extend themes for longer periods.

It includes an opportunity for ITV to exploit its archive. ITV programmes usually receive just one network showing, so the 90s theme nights will include entertainment and comedy shows from the last decade.

Brian Barwick, director of programmes for ITV2, described the commission as "consolidating ITV2's theme night strategy".

fields.headline: Bush campaign gaffe forces ad withdrawal
fields.trailText: George W Bush's campaign has withdrawn a television ad after the Democrats claimed it included subliminal messages attacking his opponent.
fields.body:
George W Bush's campaign has withdrawn a television ad after the Democrats claimed it included subliminal messages attacking his opponent.

In the ad an image of Al Gore appears on screen followed by the word "rats", which flashes up in capital letters for a split-second before the word "bureaucrats" appears.

Bush said he was convinced the word had not been used intentionally, adding that he did not need to rely on subliminal messages to get his message across. But he admitted that the ad had now been taken out of circulation.

The gaffe was the second by the Bush campaign in a week. Last week, Bush was overheard describing a New York Times reporter as a "major league asshole" in a remark that was caught on a live microphone.

fields.headline: Blair wants the tankers moving
fields.trailText: 6.15pm: Everything is in place to get fuel tankers moving within the next 24-hours, Tony Blair said this evening
fields.body:
Everything is in place to get fuel tankers moving within the next 24-hours, Tony Blair said this evening.

Speaking at an emergency press conference in Downing Street, the prime minister said that oil companies had agreed to do everything they could to get supplies to filling stations as the nation faced widespread and severe shortages.

Mr Blair said he refused to cave in to fuel price protesters and announced that the government could not "possibly, responsibly" introduce an emergency budget to alter taxes on fuel.

"We have made the necessary emergency order of council. The oil companies are agreed that they must move supplies."

The prime minister said the police had agreed to do "all that is necessary" to protect against intimidation.

fields.headline: 'We are going for complete blockage, for as long as it takes'
fields.standfirst: As the pumps continue to run slowly dry, the many sides in the petrol dispute continuing blaming one another. Here's what they have to say.
fields.trailText: Conservative shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo: "This situation is entirely of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's making by increasing taxes. Mr Blair is trying to sound like Winston Churchill when what he should be doing is sorting the country out."
fields.body:
Conservative shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo: "This situation is entirely of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's making by increasing taxes. Mr Blair is trying to sound like Winston Churchill when what he should be doing is sorting the country out."

Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott: "We are making it clear to the oil companies and we have been briefed by the police that is possible to distribute the oil. It is their responsibility and that is what we are making clear to them."

National Farmers' Union president Ben Gill: "We have said over and over again to the Treasury that it was only a matter of time before farmers' patience on fuel taxes ran out."

Royal College of Nursing General Secretary, Christine Hancock: "Nurses are having real difficulty reaching sick patients with many, particularly those working in the community, unable to make even basic house calls. "

Davey Howie, self-employed haulage contractor, demonstrating at Grangemouth refinery in Scotland: "We are going for complete blockage for as long as it takes."

Petrol Retailers Association (PRA) director Ray Holloway: "The politicians are to blame for this."

Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson: "One thing the government cannot do is to start capitulating in the face of unlawful protests and blockades of this nature which will very quickly harm peoples' lives and bring life-saving services to a halt."

Andy Gilchrist, general secretary, Fire Brigades' Union: "We want to know what the government is planning to do to make sure that fire-engines continue to run."

Mike Salmon, Road Haulage Association: "We have been fighting for two years to try and get the Government to listen and this is what it has come to."

fields.headline: Privy to history
fields.standfirst: The petrol crisis has pushed the privy council from dusty obscurity and onto the front pages. But exactly what does it do, asks Julian Glover?
fields.trailText: The petrol crisis has pushed the privy council from dusty obscurity and onto the front pages. But exactly what does it do, asks Julian Glover?
fields.body:
When the privy council launched its website at the end of August, it can hardly have expected that a fortnight later the body would end up at the centre of a political and economic storm. Normally its role is simply ceremonial. Described as the oldest form of legislature still operating, its roots lie in the Norman Kings' Court and, with the monarch, it once formed the government of the country.

Today its role is limited to advising the Queen, acting as a judicial body in certain cases and authorising the use of reserve powers - such as the regulations, activated at a meeting yesterday, which allow the government to use force to get fuel supplies through to key services.

It was this constitutional quirk which made yesterday's meeting of the privy council so significant. At 12.30pm two ministers, Helen Liddell and Richard Caborn, met the Queen at her current residence Balmoral Castle for a special session of the council. There they agreed to allow ministers to invoke "contingency powers" under the 1976 Energy Act.

In a sense the meeting was a formality since there was no likelihood that the council would decide against the government's wish to use the powers. But the fact that it had to take place at all helped make clear the very substantial powers that, nominally at least, remain in the Queen's hands rather than the government's.

On the rare occasions the privy council does make the news it is because of its judicial section, rather than its political secretariat. A committee of senior judges continues to act as a court of final appeal for certain former colonies, mainly in the West Indies, and have attracted notoriety for allowing several countries to resume executions.

Separate from this judicial role are the 400 or so members of the privy council - among them all cabinet ministers and many members of former governments. Many of them never attend meetings, which tend to be small, like yesterday's.

But membership is still prized by those who have been made members (either by default because of their job or because of the prime minister's favour) because it allows them to call themselves Rt. Hon.- marking them out as parliamentary big cheeses.

Junior ministers accorded membership are marked as a potential cabinet stars: in the current parliament the Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney and Women's minister Tessa Jowell are among those to have won the title.

fields.headline: Fuelling the climate of protest
fields.standfirst: While the fuel crisis continues to deepen in the UK, protests across Europe also show no sign of a let-up. Claire Porter casts an eye across the continent
fields.trailText: While the fuel crisis continues to deepen in the UK, protests across Europe also show no sign of a let-up. Claire Porter casts an eye across the continent.
fields.body:
Holland: Dutch truck drivers have blocked two main highway tunnels in Amsterdam and Rotterdam. In Amsterdam, two trucks temporarily blocked the Velsertunnel, resulting in a five-km (three-mile) traffic jam. Another highway was blocked near the southern city of Nijmegen. Smaller blockades occurred close to the villages of Nieuwleusen and Wezep, although no major traffic backups were caused.

Belgium: Belgian truckers have embarked on a third day of blockades, vowing to stay put for weeks if the government refuses to meet their demands. They sealed off key streets leading to Brussels' historic centre and another main route into the capital. Blockades were also set up in the southern cities of Charleroi and Nivelles.

Germany: German truckers have threatened to disrupt the country's transport network from Thursday.

Ireland: Irish lorry drivers have vowed to take action from Friday if their demands for lower duty are not met.

Spain: Farmers are planning a series of protests after talks with the Madrid government failed to reach a deal on how to compensate for swelling transport costs. The Spanish farmers' group COAG has estimated that farm diesel prices have doubled since May 1999, costing farmers more than $500m in lost earnings.

France Road blockades which crippled France last week had all but ended today after the government reached deals on tax cuts over the past few days with truck owners, taxi and ambulance drivers. The only remaining protests were by shopkeepers who were blocking a main road near the central town of Roanne and another road in the eastern Doubs region.

Slovenia: Truck drivers have vowed to block some main roads from 18 September unless the government meets their demands for cuts in petrol and road taxes.

fields.headline: Panic as oil blockade bites
fields.standfirst:
Ministers warned Britain faces paralysis in days as police and firms are urged to break protests

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Ministers were last night pressing police and oil companies to break the blockade of refineries and fuel distribution depots by road hauliers and farmers as Britain faced its worst picketing crisis since the miners' strike 15 years ago.
fields.byline: Peter Hetherington, Patrick Wintour  and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Ministers were last night pressing police and oil companies to break the blockade of refineries and fuel distribution depots by road hauliers and farmers as Britain faced its worst picketing crisis since the miners' strike 15 years ago.

With panic-buying closing hundreds of filling stations around Britain, rationing in force in many areas and emergency services restricting all but essential calls, Tony Blair hardened his line by calling on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to ensure that extra police will be available.

Rejecting calls from petrol retailers for a reduction in fuel duty, Downing Street made clear that additional forces were necessary to protect delivery drivers from intimidation and keep supplies running to station forecourts.

But hopes that the world price of oil would soon fall were dealt a blow last night. Even higher prices could be in store soon after world markets ignored a weekend promise by oil producers to pump more crude oil into the system.

As the big oil companies warned that Britain faced paralysis within a few days, the prime minister set his face against meeting militant farmers, drivers, or their lobbying organisations. He is determined not to follow his French counterpart Lionel Jospin, who has caved in to protests.

Mr Blair believes that with vigorous policing there are sufficient refineries and exits from them to overcome the blockades. Ministers seem to believe that in practice fewer refineries are being blocked that reported in the media.

But Roy Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers' Association, warned last night that the government's hard line is playing into the hands of the protesters. "It is in danger of getting the motorist to fall in behind the protesters," he said. "I think politicians saying they are not going to do anything about the problem is really very likely to swing public opinion firmly behind the protests."

He warned that in the next 48 hours ministers would have to make some positive moves to restore supplies, particularly for emergency supplies "because the industry was not prepared for this crisis".

He joined Downing Street in calling for the oil companies to consider taking legal action against protesters, but the large producers - notably Shell, and BP - appeared cool about escalating the dispute. Shell, first hit by the blockade at its Stanlow refinery in Cheshire, said it would not resort to the law.

Police have a variety of powers - but none under the last government's trade union laws because this is not classed as a union dispute. Nevertheless, under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act of 1994 they could arrest individuals causing harm to people and property or unlawfully blocking the highway. And under the Public Order Act of 1986 they have the power to arrest protesters for threatening or abusive behaviour or harassment.

Around the country, from Scotland to Cornwall, motorists formed long queues at filling stations. Many were turned away. Police had to be called to disperse angry motorists at one filling station in Derby which had doubled the price of fuel.

Repercussions spread far beyond the forecourt. Liverpool taxi drivers brought the city to a standstill. Anglesey council in North Wales said rubbish collections will stop today because fuel has dried up. West Sussex had stopped all non-emergency use of fire engines.

Matthew Aitkin, a haulage contractor protesting outside BP's Grangemouth refinery in Scotland summed up the mood of defiance. "We would like to stop all the tankers coming out of Grangemouth so I'm afraid Joe Public is going suffer - the only thing that will move the government is Joe Public suffering."

The CBI, meanwhile, urged the Government to cut duty on diesel. "They have an opportunity to demonstrate to business that it recognises the pressure business is under."

Union leaders at the TUC in Glasgow showed signs of supporting the protesters. Roger Lyons, of the MSF, said: "The inaction of Opec is unsatisfactory and given the action of the French government last week in making concessions on fuel duty, when the French rates were lower than in Britain, the increasing cost in Britain of oil based products is looking more and more like highway robbery."
Running on empty:
 Texaco A third of 957 garages nationwide are close to empty or dry. Four of its 12 oil terminals (Avonmouth, Cardiff, Manchester and Poole) are at a standstill

 Esso 350 out of its 1,600 outlets are dry. There are protests at four depots (Manchester, Bristol, Hythe, near Southampton, and Purfleet, Essex)

 BP 600 out of 1,500 filling stations are empty or close to empty. All garages in Wales are dry. Protesters are trying to close Scotland's only oil refinery in Grangemouth, near Falkirk

 Shell 350 out of 1,100 garages have run out of fuel or are running dry. Refinery at Kingsbury, Warwickshire, closed but ones at Buncefield in Hertfordshire and Plymouth still operating

 TotalFinaElf 30-40% of its 1,400 petrol stations close to empty or dry. Both refineries, at Milford Haven, in Pembrokeshire and Killingholme in north Lincolnshire, are closed

 Sainsbury's 20% of its 223 petrol stations have now run dry

webTitle: Prescott to oil companies: it's your responsibility

fields.headline: Prescott to oil companies: it's your responsibility
fields.standfirst:
Cartoon: Steve Bell
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Deputy prime minister John Prescott today told oil companies it was their responsibility to deliver petrol to the forecourts. Breaking away from crisis talks in Downing Street, Mr Prescott sais the government "are not prepared to break" over the situation.
fields.body:
Deputy prime minister John Prescott today told oil companies it was their responsibility to deliver petrol to the forecourts. Breaking away from crisis talks in Downing Street, Mr Prescott sais the government "are not prepared to break" over the situation.

"We are making it absolutely clear to the oil companies that it's down to them. It is their responsibility to deliver the oil resources and we have made that very clear."

His comments came as petrol companies warned they had less than 24 hours-worth of supplies left.

Earlier, prime minister Tony Blair cancelled a regional tour of Yorkshire and returned to London for emergency meetings with ministers to discuss the fuel crisis.

Meanwhile, the government was considering the use of special contingency powers to stop the country's roads and public services coming to a standstill. Esso and Shell say that 50% of their stations have now been totally depleted of supplies, with Total Fina warning that 90% of its forecourts will be emptied within 24 hours.

Fuel shortages also began to affect public transport for the first time today. South West Trains has been forced to terminate its twice-daily London Waterloo to Paignton, south Devon, service around 30 miles short at Exeter. Its five-times daily Brighton to Reading was also to be cut short at Basingstoke.

A spokesman for the Association of Train Operating Companies said that though two-thirds of the national network runs of diesel fuel, there had been no significant problems as yet.

"We are monitoring the situation and we are perfectly okay until the weekend when we will review the position," she said.

Mr Blair has decided to cancel planned visits to a school in Sheffield to launch the next phase of the government's education policy and a factory in South Yorkshire and Leeds, where he was due to give a major speech on the economy.

"Legitimate protest is one thing but we have to look now at the disruption that is being caused," said a Downing Street spokesman.

"The prime minister took a series of phone calls last night and this morning and he is going back to London to talk to ministers."

Thousands of petrol stations across Britain were shut today as hauliers and farmers continued to picket oil refineries and fuel depots in protest at high pump prices.

Police this morning began to take action against protesters, restoring access to a fuel depot in Norfolk. But tanker fleets remained at a standstill across the country with oil companies telling their drivers not to defy the protesters for safety reasons.

Motorists throughout the country were besieging filling stations to fill up before the pumps ran dry as the crisis entered its sixth day. Up to 3,000 petrol stations have already run out of petrol and the major retailers have warned as many again are expected to close today.

Protesters at the Shell oil refinery in Stanlow, Cheshire, where the protest began last Thursday, today warned Mr Blair not to aggravate peaceful blockades by ordering police to act. Farmers' and hauliers' spokesman Brynle Williams told protesters who gathered around his red Land Rover outside the Stanlow depot that Mr Blair had made a "gross mistake" by not bowing to the overwhelming public response.

He said: "Tony Blair hasÄ grossly underestimated the will of the country. He had the power to call an emergency Cabinet meeting today, to put pen to paper and put a stop to this. Will we back down? Never."

However, around 40 police officers arrived at the Wymondham oil terminal in Norfolk early today to clear the route to the site. Shortly afterwards, hauliers began moving the 30 trucks that had blocked off the site, which supplies diesel and heating oil but no forecourt fuel.

Last night the government confirmed that the Privy Council and the Queen had sanctioned the use of emergency powers to break the deadlock if considered necessary. Mr Blair said yesterday: "We cannot and we will not alter government policy on petrol through blockades and pickets."

But Conservative shadow chancellor Michael Portillo told Sky News today: "It is the basic job of the government to make sure that the country runs and right now the country is not running.

He continued: "The government has created this situation because it has imposed taxes upon people that people are now protesting aboutÄ It is no good Tony Blair simply making speeches with a Churchillian tone to them. He actually has to show now that he can get the right supplies where people want them."

Elsewhere some hospital patients face cancelled operations as ambulances were put on an emergency-only footing in a bid to conserve fuel, while hauliers warned that diesel shortages could hit deliveries to supermarkets and shops.

fields.headline: Farming militants behind the action
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: A committee of 12 militant farmers is one of the driving forces behind the nationwide picketing of refineries and fuel depots propelling Britain towards a fuel crisis.
fields.body:
A committee of 12 militant farmers is one of the driving forces behind the nationwide picketing of refineries and fuel depots propelling Britain towards a fuel crisis.

Called Farmers for Action, it was launched at a service station on the M5 near Birmingham earlier this year amid growing disenchantment over the reluctance of the National Farmers' Union and the Country Landowners' Association to confront ministers with tougher tactics in defence of the beleaguered industry.

Another, looser alliance in north Wales was partly responsible for the more spontaneous protest which launched the nationwide action at Stanlow oil refinery in Cheshire five days ago.

Away from the public gaze the FFA, which claims 5,500 supporters, has been organising pickets of supermarket distribution depots and dairies for much of the year in protest at the falling price of milk - down 50% in three years - which is forcing more farmers towards bankruptcy.

"We don't have a designated leader because that's the best way to operate," said Tom Houghton, one of the militant 12, who rears cattle and sheep on 130 acres in Cheshire, and helped organise the picket which triggered at Stanlow. "We started in a small way, but now this has snowballed to an extent where you don't know what will happen next. You take things day by day. Everyone now seems to be joining in."

FFA says action took off following an informal meeting at Ruthin auction mart in north Wales a week ago. Hard-pressed farmers, who first launched French-style protests in Britain late in 1997 by tipping Irish beefburgers into Holyhead docks, called for blockades over rising fuel prices. They were joined by hauliers, whose own protests of slow-moving convoys earlier this year came to nothing and were ridiculed by ministers.

It is clear that the looser alliance of Welsh farmers also played a significant part. Led by Brynle Williams, from Cilcain, near Mold, and a farming neighbour, Clive Swann, they regard themselves as the vanguard of the militant farming army.

Swann, one of the organisers of the late '97 protests - which led to mass-picketing of supermarket distribution depots in the Midlands and North - maintains his loose alliance has no formal organisation. "We had a meeting and we said the only way we are going to achieve anything is to head straight for Stanlow - for the artery, not the veins - and we asked anyone who wasn't with us to leave," said Swann, who has 300 cattle at Mold, near the border.

Militants range from small-scale farmers to businessmen with much larger holdings. Derek Mead, who chaired the motorway meeting which launched Farmers for Action, has a 1,600-acre arable and dairy farm in Somerset with 380 cows. He says he has learned a lot from tactics across the Channel. "I know quite a few French farmers. Their union is far more in touch with everyday problems than the NFU, which is useless. They have a very tight network."

Mr Mead says Tony Blair has failed to understand the strength of feeling about fuel costs. "They did it in France, forcing their government to bring down prices, and Blair has to realise we will not give in. If they think they can sweep this under the carpet they've got another think coming."

fields.headline: The pumps run dry
fields.standfirst:
But the chancellor must not be coerced
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Across much of north-west England the pumps have ceased to flow. On the other side of the Pennines, York and Wetherby have run dry: Leeds fears it may soon follow. Now panic buyers are draining London dry too. Tempers are getting heated. Lorry drivers going about their business, though plainly in no way to blame either for Opec's pricing policy or for Gordon Brown's rates of taxation, find themselves under attack. Conservative politicians and newspapers, normally first in the queue to denounce coercive action, ooze sympathy for decent people driven to these extreme measures because their livelihoods are under attack. Unlike our own home-made dump the pump campaign a few weeks before, which got nowhere, these copycat French-style protests against the high price of petrol have begun to cause serious trouble.
fields.body:
Across much of north-west England the pumps have ceased to flow. On the other side of the Pennines, York and Wetherby have run dry: Leeds fears it may soon follow. Now panic buyers are draining London dry too. Tempers are getting heated. Lorry drivers going about their business, though plainly in no way to blame either for Opec's pricing policy or for Gordon Brown's rates of taxation, find themselves under attack. Conservative politicians and newspapers, normally first in the queue to denounce coercive action, ooze sympathy for decent people driven to these extreme measures because their livelihoods are under attack. Unlike our own home-made dump the pump campaign a few weeks before, which got nowhere, these copycat French-style protests against the high price of petrol have begun to cause serious trouble.

In Downing Street, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, in this matter at least, stand shoulder to shoulder. They will not be moved. There are two calculations here for the chancellor. Are these protests an embarrassment for the government and a serious disruption of the productive economy? Certainly. Has the hike in the oil price gone further than that, reaching a point where, even after Opec's weekend decision to bump up production, there is now a possibility that Britain might be forced into recession? The answer to that, so far at least, must be no. If that outcome threatened, Mr Brown would have to act. As it is, he is right to stand firm. Street protest may influence taxation policy but it cannot be allowed to dictate it. And these protests ought to be policed no less firmly than other disruptive activities, on behalf of sectional interests less congenial to the Daily Mail, were policed in the past.

That is not to endorse some of the government responses offered so far. The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, interviewed on radio yesterday morning, repeated over and over again that the Treasury's percentage take from each litre sold at the pump was higher under the Tories than it is now. Well, fascinating - but hardly relevant to this dispute, since oil prices then were much lower and not imposing the strains they do now. Ministers cannot succeed in allaying public discontent by hiding behind that sort of party political point-scoring.

There is also the uncomfortable issue of the windfall which the Treasury gets as VAT rises along with petrol prices - an estimated £1bn-plus since March. Even as normally loyal a government supporter as the engineering union leader Ken Jackson argues that this money should fund a cut in the tax on petrol which would bring pump prices down. But that is to look at the issue too narrowly - and also to forget that this government, like the one before it (though the Conservatives prefer not to remember what they did not so long ago when in office) has made a firm commitment to use taxation on petrol as a device to benefit the environment by pegging back vehicle use. It would make more sense to use the windfall not to reduce the burden on essential and inessential users alike but, selectively, to pay for programmes designed to reduce dependence on road transport and to boost alternative sources of energy. To roll back Margaret Thatcher's "great car economy" will be easier in some places than others: easier, especially, in the towns than in the countryside. But it is still essential to make the attempt.

Sunday's Opec agreement is no guarantee of stability, but it should stop prices racing up through the winter. It is a breathing space - and one that needs to be put to constructive use.

fields.headline: The dilemma - economic and legal
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Questions and answers
fields.body:
Why are British motorists paying more in petrol taxes than drivers anywhere else in Europe?

When Norman Lamont was Chancellor he introduced the practice of increasing duties on petrol faster than inflation. The justification for the so-called fuel "escalator" was environmental: the government wants to discourage us from using cars and adding to global warming.

Do higher petrol costs deter people from driving?

The number of miles driven in Britain has risen by 12% since the start of the decade. However, the government believes that had fuel duties not risen so fast people would have driven even more miles. That is why Gordon Brown increased the fuel escalator from 5% over inflation to 6% when Labour came to power. Green considerations aside, it has also been a handy source of funds for Treasury.

What happened to the fuel escalator?

Mr Brown scrapped it in November last year, and promised future above-inflation increases in fuel duties would be spent on measures to improve public transport and the road network.

How much is the tax worth to the government?

The Treasury takes 71p in every pound spent on petrol. Last year, motorists contributed £36bn to the government's coffers.

Is blockading refineries legal?

No, but if the French experience is anything to go by it's a lot more effective at grabbing political attention than the dump the pump campaign's rather feeble attempts to persuade people to stop filling up their cars. In France, fishermen and farmers wrung promises out of government ministers to cut fuel duties after they brought cross channel traffic to a standstill.

Could the organisers face legal action?

It is not an industrial dispute, so the organisers are not protected by legal exemptions which cover industrial pickets. In theory they could be sued by the oil companies for loss of revenue or moved on by the police for blocking a public highway.

What powers do police have to break blockades?

Individual chief constables have the responsibility for deciding what action will be taken in response to local circumstances. Powers under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1994 could be used to arrest individuals causing harm to people or property or unlawfully obstructing the highway. Common law powers allow police to make arrests to prevent a breach of the peace. Under the Public Order Act 1986 they have the power to arrest individual protesters for threatening or abusive behaviour or harassment.

Could the Chancellor cut petrol taxes?

Excise duty and VAT on fuel could theoretically be decreased by statutory order, without the need for primary legislation. This mechanism is used each year on Budget day to ensure that changes in taxation on consumer goods come into effect at midnight that day. Normally Parliament has to be sitting for a statutory order to come into effect, but it is possible for the Government to seek the agreement of the lord chancellor and the speaker for it to be put into immediate effect in the absence of MPs during recess.

Can he afford to do it?

Cutting fuel taxes by 2p a litre would cost the treasury about £1bn which ministers say would have to be found elsewhere, either in spending cuts or tax hikes. However, there will be more money in the Chancellor's coffers than he initially expected this year, and rising oil prices is one of reasons. Analysts say it has boosted Treasury revenues by an extra £1bn this year, which could be given back to drivers in tax cuts. However, that would contradict the government's environmental goals and in any case, Mr Brown would prefer to save any tax cuts for the maximum political impact in the run up to the election expected early next year.

Will the announcement that oil exporting countries are going to increase production help prices?

Not in the short term. Petrol prices are already set to rise, because of the high prices of crude over the last month. The production increase is not expected to bring the price of crude oil down below $30 a barrel, and if oil prices stay at that level petrol prices could reach £4 a gallon.

Could the blockades damage the economy?

Business leaders are warning that the blockades are causing problems. They support calls for lower fuel duties but want protests to end.

webTitle: Protests and panic spread as pumps run dry

fields.headline: Protests and panic spread as pumps run dry
fields.standfirst:
Hauliers, farmers and fishermen plan more blockades of roads and refineries as petrol stations shut down
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Reports from around Britain
fields.body:
Scotland

In Edinburgh, a dozen lorries caused disruption on main routes into the city in an unofficial fuel protest.

The action came ahead of a planned demonstration today, when scores of haulage and farm vehicles are expected to bring the city to a standstill.

Yesterday's protest saw lorries moving at a walking pace on some of the key routes into Edinburgh at rush hour. The city bypass was badly congested for several hours.

A spokesman for the drivers, Mark Williams, said: "The key argument is to get the fuel prices back down in line with other European countries. Just now it is massively out of order. We can't accept the crippling fuel prices any longer."

However, the Scotland Office minister Brian Wilson condemned the protest. "Stopping other people getting to work and forcing old ladies to stand at bus stops, leave children waiting for buses in the rain - I don't think there's anything to be gained from any of that and I don't really think it is a very good idea," he said.

Phil Flanders, of the Road Haulage Association in Scotland, said he was disappointed at the unofficial action, and concerned that it might alienate the public ahead of today's larger protest.

But he said there could be no let up in the pressure for fairer prices. "We're not wasting our time. If we just sit back and accept it then hauliers and farmers will go out of business."

Meanwhile, petrol stations across Dumfries and Galloway reported panic buying by motorists, with some expecting their pumps to run dry by the end of the day.

Police were also on alert in Grangemouth for possible disruption at the main petro-chemical complex there.

Kirsty Scott

North-east

Five men and three lorries threw most of north-eastern England into chaos yesterday, helped by a region-wide outbreak of panic petrol buying.

The group reversed their trucks into the entrance of the Conoco and Total refineries at Immingham on the Humber, throttling the supply of fuel to garages from Nottingham to the North Yorkshire border.

Similar pickets on Tyneside completed the job for Tyne and Wear and Northumbria, where police held an emergency meeting to keep patrol cars on the road. Police drivers in Cleveland and North Yorkshire were also ordered to limit patrols to safeguard fuel supplies.

Officers were called to a garage in Derby where prices were hiked to £2 a litre as scores of drivers from the petrol-starved north-west drove there to find supplies.

No action was taken, however, against 80 trucks which reduced the motorway system in Yorkshire to chaos by driving three abreast at under 25mph around the junction of the M1 and M62 motorways.

Public support for the blockades was widespread in spite of the misery involved. Peter Turner, the managing director of Rix Petroleum in Hull whose depot was also sealed off, said: "We're the wrong target but we sympathise with the all the farmers and hauliers, some of whom are our customers and friends."

At the Hull garage 200 metres from the home of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott - who was celebrating 30 years of being MP for East Hull last night - the "no fuel" signs went up at 2pm.

Martin Wainwright

North-west and north Wales

The north-west of England was running out of petrol last night as blockades of refineries and terminals spread.

Filling stations across a swath of country from the Welsh border to the Pennines locked their pumps as tanks ran dry. Long queues formed where supplies were available.

There was no petrol in an area extending 20 miles south of Manchester city centre and drivers were finding it increasingly difficult to find fuel in the north of the city. Some drivers complained of steep price rises.

Traffic on the M6 slowed as drivers joined queues for fuel at Charnock Richard services in Lancashire.

More than 150 Liverpool taxi drivers supported pickets at the Stanlow oil refinery in Cheshire, where the blockades began last Thursday. Taxi drivers also caused gridlock in Liverpool last night by driving their cabs at a snail's pace through the city centre.

Brynle Williams, leader of the Stanlow protesters, threatened to blockade the port of Holyhead if refinery managers continued to supply fuel to Seacat ferries.

"We don't like the idea of Irish drivers coming over here with their cheap diesel then working two or three days and bringing over their cheap meat, robbing us of a living," he said, adding that Irish drivers filled their tanks with fuel bought in Ireland at half British prices.

In Trafford Park, Manchester, 30 hauliers, including reinforcements from Shropshire, continued to prevent fuel leaving the giant terminal which supplies Esso, Texaco and Elf outlets in the region.

Last night the North West Wales NHS Trust cancelled all non-emergency operations due to the crisis. Appointments at clinics apart from at Gwynedd Hospital at Bangor and Llandudno general hospital are also being cancelled.

Day-hospital facilities are being cancelled from today because ambulances will carry out emergency work only.

David Ward and Helen Carter

South-west and south Wales

Desperate motorists were being turned away from petrol stations across south Wales yesterday as a combination of panic buying and continued blockades at oil refineries and fuel depots in the region saw the pumps dry up.

Motorway drivers faced the prospect of not reaching their destinations after a number of service stations along the busy M4 corridor ran out of fuel. In Swansea supplies of unleaded petrol have been used up. Garages were rapidly running out of four star and there was no petrol or diesel available at any of the city's supermarket service stations. It was a similar tale in Newport with long queues forming outside the one Shell garage that still had supplies yesterday.

As truckers continued to blockade the Elf oil refinery at Milford Haven the company conceded that almost all its service stations in south Wales had run out of stocks. It said that some of the larger supermarket filling stations it services require two tanker loads of fuel a day to keep going.

Blockades were also continuing at the Texaco refinery at Pembroke Dock and at a key fuel distribution centre in Cardiff. Oil company staff and police said the blockades - involving just 20 vehicles at the two west Wales refineries - were orderly but there had been no movement of any tankers following discussions with the protesters.

In the south-west of England, where the Asda-WalMart hypermarket near Bristol was forced to close during the day, protesters were continuing to prevent supplies leaving Esso's Avonmouth fuel depot.

The protest was last night extended to Plymouth where militant fishermen plan to join a blockade of Cattedown Wharf, the distribution depot for Shell, BP and Esso in the area.

Elsewhere, angry truckers caused chaos in Dorset by travelling in convoy at 5mph through Poole. Among those caught in the snarl up were 30 long distance drivers, believed to be a mixture of French and British who arrived at Poole harbour on the early morning ferry from France.

Geoffrey Gibbs

London and the south-east

In the south of England hauliers and farmers have been working in shifts to stop tankers leaving refineries as panic buying led to fears that almost half the petrol stations in the London area could run out of fuel by tomorrow.

BP's biggest refinery, at Coryton, Essex, was blockaded by protesters, while four other distribution terminals and refineries in the Grays area were also picketed.

Fifty drivers belonging to the Kent Hauliers and Farmers, a group set up to co-ordinate the protests, met at Thurrock Services on the M25 at 3am yesterday morning to decide on a plan of action. They blockaded sites, including the Esso Petroleum Bitumen Depot in Purfleet, where a lorry - bedecked with a Union flag bearing the slogan "Cut UK Diesel/Tax Down" - blocked the entrance.

Moorthy Patel, from the Shell garage in Seven Sisters, north London, said: "If there is no delivery within the next 24 hours, we could run out."

But Barbara Peen of BP said there was no real cause for concern yet. "There is no reason why London garages should be affected," she said. "The shortages are a result of panic buying over the weekend."

Meanwhile Kent fire brigade has cut all non-emergency calls and community fire safety work for its engines for the duration of the protests.

Jamie Wilson

The Midlands

The Staffordshire Ambulance Service yesterday imposed a speed limit of 55mph on all vehicles involved in non-emergency journeys to conserve petrol as the fuel crisis began to hit home in the Midlands.

As protesters closed Britain's largest inland oil terminal, at Kingsbury in the West Midlands, filling stations in the region reported severe shortages. Despite the introduction of the speed limit a spokesman for Staffordshire Ambulance Service reassured the public that its current petrol supplies would last for another 11 days and the measure had been taken as a precaution.

An Esso garage in Birmingham city centre was forced to ration petrol to £10 per person after queues had begun forming from the early morning, and others were forced to close after running out of fuel.

Jamie Wilson

The action came ahead of a planned demonstration today, when scores of haulage and farm vehicles are expected to bring the city to a standstill. Yesterday's protest saw lorries moving at a walking pace on some of the key routes into Edinburgh at rush hour. The city bypass was badly congested for several hours. A spokesman for the drivers, Mark Williams, said: "The key argument is to get the fuel prices back down in line with other European countries. Just now it is massively out of order. "Stopping other people getting to work and forcing old ladies to stand at bus stops, leave children waiting for buses in the rain - I don't think there's anything to be gained from any of that and I don't really think it is a very good idea," he said. fields.headline: This man means business
fields.standfirst:
One person above all is responsible for the recent oil price hike - President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: One person above all is responsible for the recent oil price hike - President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela
fields.body:
The crisis over petrol prices in Britain and elsewhere is almost entirely due to the myopia of governments and markets over the past 18 months in failing to recognise the emergence of a new star in the global political firmament. The youthful Hugo Chavez, aged 46, elected president of Venezuela in December 1998, is the principal figure behind the price rise. Last year he singlehandedly revived the moribund organisation of petroleum exporting countries, Opec, by calling for and securing a cut in oil production, and this year he has singlemindedly persuaded its members to stand firm in defence of a reasonable price.

He recently toured all the Opec countries and sought agreement on an optimum price of $25 a barrel. He will host a great jamboree of Opec presidents in Caracas at the end of the month, only the second such event ever held.

This man means business. The west has had plenty of warning of what he has been up to, and where he is coming from, but blinded by the arrogance of globalisation it has taken no steps to prepare anyone for the dramatic developments of recent days.

Although Opec has usually appeared to western eyes as an organisation dominated by Arabs, it was actually conceived and founded by Venezuela in the heyday of what used to be called the Third World. The countries of Opec, for Venezuelans, constitute a large extended family. In the 1990s, when Venezuela was ruled by unpopular governments that signed up to the dominant strand of neo-liberalism that spread like a plague across the whole of South America, Opec was abandoned and ignored. Venezuela was one of the great cheaters of the organisation, ignoring the quotas set, and bringing in foreign companies to help increase production through the development of new fields. When the world oil price dropped below $10 a barrel, the west fondly imagined that the exporting countries - many of them perceived as "rogue states", like Iran, Iraq and Libya - were permanently defeated and that this low price would be the established pattern of the future.

Colonel Chavez - for he was originally a military officer - had other ideas. Petroleos de Venezuela, the state oil company nationalised in 1975, is the country's chief source of wealth. Chavez needed a steady and larger flow of income from the oil wells to finance his ambitious plans to transform the country and to satisfy his voters in the poorest section of society. He was well aware that his radical rhetoric, avowedly hostile to what he describes as "savage neo-liberalism" imposed on Latin America by the US, would do him no favours with nervous foreign investors. He decided to play the oil card.

At an Opec meeting in March 1999, his oil minister, Ali Rodriguez Araque, was instructed to announce that Venezuela would in future respect the cutbacks in production already agreed, and would support a further cutback of 4%. It was "a change of 180 degrees" in the policy of previous governments, Chavez proudly announced. Ali Rodriguez is now Opec's president, and the oil price has risen from $10 to over $30 a barrel.

Although the Latin American military are usually remembered for the rightwing dictators that they spawn, Chavez belongs to another tradition, that of radical junior officers, in touch with the raw conscripts from the peasantry, whose revolutionary politics are fuelled by anger at the degenerate state of the nation. Chavez is also an heir to a civilian tradition of rebellion in Latin America, that of the leftwing guerrillas of the 1960s inspired by Fidel Castro and Che Guevara. Some of his advisers were once associated with a Chinese-oriented split from the Venezuelan Communist Party who went on to make lasting contacts with radicals in the Arab world in the 1970s. Ali Rodriguez himself was a guerrilla in the 1960s, before becoming a labour lawyer and an oil expert for one of the smaller radical parties. One member of that generation, Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, "Carlos the Jackal", famous among other things for an armed attack on Opec headquarters in Vienna in December 1975, now languishes in a French jail.

Chavez is a good friend of Fidel Castro and a frequent visitor to Cuba, and his ambitions are as grandiose as those of the Cuban leader. He hopes that his reconstruction of Opec will help him to forge a new "Bolivarian" alliance in Latin America that will fulfil the dreams of Simon Bolivar, the South American liberator of the 19th century, who sought continental unity against the outside world.

Yet Chavez is no populist demagogue. He seeks a fair price for Opec oil, not an exorbitant one. This would mean price stabilisation, as Opec has reiterated throughout the summer, in a band between $22 and $28 a barrel. This week's Opec decision to increase production by 3%, might just allow that to happen eventually, but no amount of "pressure" from Tony Blair or Bill Clinton on individual countries is likely to break the fresh sense of purpose that Chavez has infused into the organisation.

 In the Shadow of the Liberator: Hugo Chavez and the Transformation of Venezuela by Richard Gott is published by Verso

Rwgott@aol.com

webTitle: Leaders stand firm as blockades multiply

fields.headline: Leaders stand firm as blockades multiply
fields.standfirst:
Rest of continent vows not to follow French example
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: Belgian truckers blocked main roads in the heart of Brussels for a second day yesterday, as protests at the price of fuel rippled across the continent.
fields.body:
Belgian truckers blocked main roads in the heart of Brussels for a second day yesterday, as protests at the price of fuel rippled across the continent.

Similar action was seen for the first time in the Netherlands while the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, agreed to meet drivers tomorrow.

But echoing tough talk by Tony Blair in London, the German transport minister, Reinhard Klimmt, said his government would not follow the example of France which, after six days of unrest, agreed last week to subsidise soaring fuel prices. Sporadic protests continued in French cities, despite the controversial concessions.

In Brussels - where the European Commission is worrying about the inflationary effects of the rising oil price but simultaneously opposing any further cuts in fuel taxes - traffic ground to a halt on the Rue de la Loi, in the heart of the EU quarter of the city.

The Belgian transport minister, Isabelle Durant, refused to meet the protesters until they opened the road outside her office. Riot police stood by but without intervening.

When talks did get under way no agreement was reached, however. One drivers' union vowed to bring the entire country to a standstill if the government did not give into its demands. Sunday's decision by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to raise production by 800,000 barrels a day had no immediate impact on the protests.

Outside Brussels, lorry drivers blocked off Belgium's largest oil refinery at Feluy, near Charleroi, run by TotalFinaElf.

In the Netherlands there were truck blockades at Rotterdam and Breda. "Lots of smaller companies are on the verge of bankruptcy because of the high prices," said Ruben Hubbers, spokesman of the Resistance party, which organised yesterday's action.

In Dublin, the president of the Irish Road Haulage Association, Gerry McMahon, said he was pleased about the planned meeting with Mr Ahern, but warned that protests by drivers would go on if the government failed to cut the petrol tax right away.

"We haven't changed our attitude. Twenty per cent immediately is the least we will accept," he told RTE Radio. The government's spokeswoman said Mr Ahern would consider truckers' concerns only "within a budgetary context".

webTitle: Boycott sympathy soars as the tanks fill up

fields.headline: Boycott sympathy soars as the tanks fill up
fields.standfirst:
At the pumps, drivers curse prices but keep their fingers on the trigger

Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: "What a lovely day to queue for petrol," said the local radio presenter as the warm autumn sun shone on long lines of cars shuffling towards the pumps.
fields.body:
"What a lovely day to queue for petrol," said the local radio presenter as the warm autumn sun shone on long lines of cars shuffling towards the pumps.

Discreet signs at Openshaw filling station a few miles east of central Manchester urged customers to limit themselves to spending £15.

"I hadn't noticed that till you mentioned it," David Timperley said as he watched £40-worth of unleaded gush into his tank.

"I'm going to keep my finger on the trigger until the pump stops. I've come all the way from the Peak District and was down to a quarter of a tank till I found this place."

What did he think of the shortage which has sent north-west drivers round in gas-guzzling circles? "How many expletives do you want?" he asked.

And yet, despite the personal inconvenience, he was sympathetic to the blockades. "There is a feeling that the country is being ripped off by the government. But queuing up here is quite unnecessary. The government is in London and they should bring the Houses of Parliament to a standstill."

As forecourt staff mopped their brows and said they had not stopped hitting the till since the station opened at 5am, David Kelly, a computer programmer from Stockport, Greater Manchester, managed to squeeze £47-worth into his silver BMW convertible.

"Most filling stations I've seen have been closed and I was getting into a bit of a panic because the fuel gauge was into the red," he said.

"I agree with the action, because the price of petrol is ridiculous and something has to be done. The government should consider cutting tax on fuel, but they don't seem to listen to the people."

One customer, who declined to give her name, remained stoical, despite driving a green Nissan Micra labelled "Passion".

"We just have to be patient," she sighed as the queue moved slowly on.

"I just kept putting off looking for petrol, because I thought the dispute would be over soon. But I'm down to less than a quarter of a tank now."

She admitted that she usually caved in to practicality.

"I live in Warrington and work in Manchester," she added.

Patrick Nolan, staying within the the voluntary limit with a £14.63 purchase, said he had once worked as an electrician at the Stanlow refinery in Cheshire, now blockaded by truckers and farmers.

"The French did it, didn't they?" he said.

"So should we. The price of petrol is something shocking. Juice in Portugal costs only 46p a litre."

The price in Openshaw is 83.9p, up from 77.9 only two weeks ago.

"Supplies are running very low and we probably have enough fuel for only another hour," said the manager, Amin Jaffer.

"And my own car."
