fields.headline: Fuelling dissent
fields.standfirst:
The highest petrol tax in Europe is certainly striking home in Britain. What is less clear is whether it is, as claimed, helping the environment
Special report: The petrol war
fields.trailText: The highest petrol tax in Europe is certainly striking home in Britain. What is less clear is whether it is, as claimed, helping the environment
fields.body:
It's since 1997 that the curve showing the increase in the price of unleaded petrol turns sharply up: since Labour came to power the price at the pump has increased by 42%. Of that, 22 percentage points were due to tax. A considerable part of Labour's public spending plans is - sorry - fuelled by pain at the pumps.

Yes, a good part of the increase in the price of petrol over recent months has been due to increases in the price of oil - the realm of Opec - but the high level of petrol prices in the United Kingdom is largely due to the tax rate. To that extent the political protest that has been mounting over the past few days addresses the right target. What government takes, government can return.

But petrol tax is scarcely a New Labour invention. The amount of tax (duty plus VAT) that is imposed on petrol has increased steeply in real terms since 1993, when the Tories first introduced the "escalator", pushing up duty beyond the general rise in prices on a regular basis. Together, VAT and duty now represent around 72% of the price on the forecourts. The UK has the highest tax rate on petrol in the European Union: cross the border from Northern Ireland into the Republic and the tax take falls dramatically.

Labour can claim to have given motorists respite. In Gordon Brown's March budget, for the first time in several years, duty on petrol was not increased in real terms. Labour can also point out that in May 1997 the total tax on petrol represented 76% of the retail price - 4 percentage points higher than the figure today. This is not, however, down to any reduction in the level of tax imposed on fuel. It has happened because the retail price has increased proportionately more. Duty imposed on fuel is a fixed amount per unit, regardless of the price. So, when the price charged to motorists rises, duty falls as a proportion of the price at the pump.

World oil prices have been rising - and that has had fiscal consequences, too. Government revenue from oil has been rising. As well as fuel duty, VAT is imposed on petrol. It is a percentage of price so when the price rises, so does the flow to Customs and Excise. The recent increase in the price of petrol could mean an extra £0.5bn for the Treasury. This fact has led some commentators to say Gordon Brown should share his largesse with motorists and use these proceeds to cut duty on petrol. It is not a convincing argument. Oil prices fluctuate and there may be an unexpected fall in the price of petrol in the future leading to unexpected losses in government revenue with - as Stephen Byers reiterated yesterday - consequences for spending on services.

The big question has to be: why is petrol taxation in the UK so much higher than elsewhere? It could be the result of environmental enlightenment. The automatic increases in duty above inflation that began in 1993 were imposed - in the heyday of John Gummer - as part of an attempt to change people's behaviour and get them out of their cars. Has the tactic worked? The general question is about the elasticity of demand for petrol - in other words, do people reduce their use of the car in the face of higher prices?

The evidence says very little. When the price of fuel goes up, people do not respond by cutting the amount of fuel they buy or by using alternative methods of transport, at least in the shortrun. Even if they did respond to price increases, the fact that some aspects of pollution from road transport (like congestion or soot) are only loosely linked to the level of fuel used, means that the policy is not very well targeted to protect the environment.

So (as an after-the-event rationalisation) using increases in petrol duty to protect the environment is hard to justify. That is both because of the lack of response by consumers to changes in price and because the cost of fuel is not always very closely related to the environmental cost involved. This is not to say that the high rate of duty has not had any effect on the behaviour of motorists. For example, people may have switched to buying more fuel-efficient cars, which helps to reduce the harmful effect on the environment. It is unclear how far British behaviour is noticeably different from those countries (Spain, Belgium) where fuel tax is considerably less.

Chancellors and environment secretaries are usually going to disagree. It is the very lack of response by motorists to increases in the price of petrol that makes it such an attractive source of revenue. If people do not cut back the amount of fuel they buy after a tax increase, large amounts of money can be easily (painlessly is another matter) raised. Petrol duty raises around £22.3bn a year - around 6% of total government revenues. A 1p cut in fuel duty would cost the government some £420m. Add the VAT and we are talking about a sizeable portion of public revenues.

Fuel taxes fall more heavily on some people than others - but beware exaggerated claims by people living in rural areas. If we look at the effect of a 6% hike in petrol duty across households from different income groups, it is middle-income households that are the most adversely affected by the increase. This is because a large proportion of the poorest households do not own a car and so the increase in the tax has no effect on them. But the picture changes if we look at all car-owning households. Here a fuel duty rise has a disproportionate effect on the poorest households among them.

The concern about the effect on those living in rural areas is less well founded. There is a slightly bigger effect on households living in rural areas but the difference is small.

webTitle: Ain't no room for high school failure

fields.headline: Ain't no room for high school failure
fields.standfirst: All hell broke loose when Indiana University basketball coach Bobby Knight was dismissed early this week. But then the US sees its high school sports as life and death, says Washington correspondent Julian Borger
fields.trailText: All hell broke loose when Indiana University basketball coach Bobby Knight was dismissed early this week. But then the US sees its high school sports as life and death, says Washington correspondent Julian Borger.
fields.body:
In Indiana earlier this week a university basketball coach was dismissed for chronically aggressive behaviour. Such are the bare facts of the fall of Bobby Knight, but they go nowhere near conveying the enormity of this event in the eyes of the US public. There were near-riots in the streets. It was front-page news, led the television bulletins and dominated talkshows.

It was, in short, the sort of coverage normally reserved for national leaders. But that is just the point. The attention Bobby Knight commands says a lot about the preoccupations of everyday America which usually pass unseen.

Knight is undeniably a colourful figure. His idea of a motivational technique appears to be grabbing his players by the throat. He was captured on video doing just that to a young basketball star at a practice game in 1997 and when the video came to light earlier this year, confirming some of the rumours about Knight's behaviour, it triggered a crisis.

There had been numerous other incidents which suggested that Knight had - in the euphemistic parlance of modern US therapy - "issues" with "anger management". For several years he was wanted in Puerto Rico for assaulting a policeman and the case was only dropped after the local government gave up trying to extradite him. He threw chairs across basketball courts and launched violent invective against other staff members.

In May, when the throat-grabbing video emerged, Knight was cautioned and placed on a "zero-tolerance" regime, meaning his job depended on unblemished behaviour. The probation did not last long. On Sunday, the Indiana University president Myles Brand announced Knight was being sacked for a string of ugly incidents, including the alleged manhandling of another player.

All hell broke loose. Crowds of students took to the streets, burning university regalia. "Wanted" pictures appeared depicting the student who had complained about Knight's behaviour in the latest incident, and he was forced to flee campus after receiving death threats.

It is hard to imagine comparable scenes in Europe, or anywhere else in the world. Elsewhere, college sports coaches don't count for very much, because college sports themselves are not considered important.

In the US, they are all-consuming. Whole towns turn out to watch their college team play, whether it be basketball, American football or baseball. It is the focal point of civic and institutional pride, and in Indiana, Knight was an institution. Knight's winning ways on the basketball court helped the midwestern state hold its head up and gave it something to cheer about.

In other down-at-heel towns, in the backwoods of Pennsylvania for example, American football is king. For many young men, playing college sports will be the high-point of their lives. They will be watched by tens of thousands, and their successes hailed as if they were military triumphs.

The same goes for secondary school soccer and Little League baseball. They attract hundreds of spectators every weekend, and have become important social occasions in their own right.

All this says a lot of good things about America. Parents and local communities tend to be much more engaged in their children and the games they play than in Europe. When I played football for my school in London, hardly anyone came to watch. If an American-sized crowd had turned up to any of my games, I would have been overcome with pride and stage fright.

Furthermore, the American obsession with sport is also far more even-handed than on the other side of the Atlantic. Because of a 1972 piece of legislation called Title IX, which forces schools to spend as much on girls' sports as boys', girls get almost as much attention as boys.

The results include a well-attended women's professional basketball league, and the best women's soccer team in the world, by far. In Britain, women's football is treated as a joke. In the US, half the nation watched as the US beat China in the Women's World Cup last year.

There is, of course, a downside, and it is personified by Bobby Knight. College and school sports are now taken so seriously, there is no room left for humour and failure. If a child is not athletic the sense of marginalisation is all the greater on the nights the whole town goes out to watch the high school team.

And then there is the rage. It percolates up through the playing field turf and pervades children's sports like a noxious gas. There is now a recognised syndrome called "Little League rage" - a pattern of assaults by parents on umpires, officials and other parents, and it applies to sports other than baseball.

A man was killed a few weeks ago after a dispute at a children's ice-hockey match. No wonder Bobby Knight is such an icon. No wonder there is such a furore around his ignominious fall in a sports-obsessed country which has not yet decided when a game is no longer just a game, and when childhood comes to an end.

webTitle: US told its gun culture is based on myth

fields.headline: US told its gun culture is based on myth
fields.standfirst:
In the 18th-century heyday of the vaunted independence militias few people had firearms, a new book says.
Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: The gut belief of many Americans that gun ownership has been central to their way of life since colonial days is a 20th century invention, says a book published in the US this week.
fields.body:
The gut belief of many Americans that gun ownership has been central to their way of life since colonial days is a 20th century invention, says a book published in the US this week.

There are currently estimated to be more than 250m firearms in private hands and every year 5m new guns are being bought - overwhelmingly by white men aged between 25 and 34. More than 16,000 people are shot dead each year on average.

Those who oppose the introduction of tough laws restricting firearms argue that widespread access to such weapons is part of America's gun-toting militia history before, during and after the independence revolution that began in 1775.

Not so, says Michael Bellesiles of Emory university in Atlanta, Georgia, in a book which, according to a New York Times review this week, "deflates the myth of the self-reliant and self-armed virtuous yeoman of the revolutionary militias".

Professor Bellesiles says that the fact that the modern US contains more gunshops than schools "would have shocked the toughest resident of the early American frontier".

The National Rifle Association and other pro-gun lobbies often evoke a picture of the 18th-century pioneer armed and ready to kill for his supper, armed to defend his property against marauders and standing shoulder to shoulder with his equally armed neighbours against oppressive government - British or American - in defence of a free way of life.

Prof Bellesiles says this image is almost wholly false. Most Americans in the time of George Washington and the "founding fathers" who signed the declaration of independence in 1776 were growers and traders, not hunters, he said.

His book, Arming America: the Origins of a National Gun Culture, says that only some 14% of households in northern New England and Pennsylvania had firearms in the years 1765 to 1790 - years typically thought of as the heyday of gun ownership and use. Over half of the guns recorded in contemporary surveys were listed as broken or otherwise defective, the book says.

Perhaps because they were unfamiliar and unpractised with the firearms of the day, early Americans were not very skilled with them. Prof Bellesiles points to the encounter that set off the revolutionary war in earnest in April 1775, near Concord and the village of Lexington, less than 20 miles from Boston.

Military accounts speak of British troops withdrawing from the area through a 15-mile gauntlet of "incessant firing". Yet. says the book, 3,763 armed Americans hiding behind walls, trees and farm buildings along this corridor managed to hit only 273 of the withdrawing British soldiers with their bullets.

These were the years in which the founders of the US wrote the second amendment to the constitution, on which the legal claims of today's gun culture rest. The amendment, adopted in 1791, states that: "A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed."

Thomas Jefferson and his colleagues would have been shocked, Prof Bellesiles believes, to learn that one member of the current US supreme court, Justice Antonin Scalia, considers that citizens have a constitutionally protected right to own machine guns.

"America's gun culture is an invented tradition," Prof Bellesiles writes. "It was not present at the nation's creation, whenever we fix that point."

Individual ownership of guns really became possible, he argues, only when Samuel Colt began to perfect the pistol in the 1830s. But the civil war of 1861-65 was, he says, "the moment when a large proportion of the country tried to replace elections with gunfire".

webTitle: PwC to sell consultancy to Hewlett Packard

fields.headline: PwC to sell consultancy to Hewlett Packard
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the big five accountancy firms, yesterday confirmed it was in talks to sell its consulting business to Hewlett Packard in a deal valued at $17bn (£12.1bn) to $18bn.
fields.body:
PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the big five accountancy firms, yesterday confirmed it was in talks to sell its consulting business to Hewlett Packard in a deal valued at $17bn (£12.1bn) to $18bn.

The deal, expected to be paid for in cash and shares, follows a similar sale earlier this year by rival accountancy firm Ernst & Young to French computer services group Cap Gemini in a $11bn deal.

Hewlett Packard, the world's second largest computer maker, said it wanted to strengthen its professional services capabilities to provide customers with "top level advice and practical implementation skills".

The company's existing consulting business grew by 46% in the third quarter, three times its overall growth, but it is still relatively unknown as a big consulting business.

The purchase of PwC's consulting practice will allow the company to compete with rivals IBM and EDS, analysts said. It will be the first deal since Carly Fiorina took over as chief executive last year.

PwC announced in February that it was looking for a buyer to take over its consulting arm. fields.headline: Silicon Fen floats would-be star
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Silicon Fen, the region around Cambridge specialising in chip technology, is about to push another fast-growing company on to the stock market.
fields.body:
Silicon Fen, the region around Cambridge specialising in chip technology, is about to push another fast-growing company on to the stock market.

TTP Communications is likely to command a valuation of about £400m when it floats next month, and has gained much of its success by emulating the business model of ARM Holdings, one of the region's technology stars.

Like ARM, TTPCom develops intellectual property and licenses it to semiconductor manufacturers who in turn use the chips and software in their products.

TTPCom's products are aimed at the emerging wireless technology market and are expected to be used in the next generation of mobile phones and wireless products based on the "bluetooth" standard. Customers include Alcatel, Panasonic and Hitachi.

The flotation, coordinated by Chase H&Q, aims to raise around £30m to fund future overseas expansion and recruit new staff. It should also allow TTPCom to join the Techmark index.

The company is 12 years old, and is a subsidiary of TTP Group, a technology and consultancy group.

In the year to March 31 it recorded sales of £18.97m and a pre-tax profit of £4.99m. It claims to be operating in a market that is set to grow from $5.5bn this year to $18.8bn in 2004.

"We also want to give staff some participation in the stock, and we want to retain the independence of the business," said Managing Director Tony Milbourn.

Several firms are attempting to raise money on the markets following renewed interest in the sector. ARC Cores, another chip designer, said recently it is planning a £490m float, while the major investment banks are preparing several more IPOs for the autumn.

webTitle: Schiller exit hits Geo share price

fields.headline: Schiller exit hits Geo share price
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: High-flying Israeli technology firm Geo Interactive Media yesterday unnerved its legions of private investors by announcing that its chief executive, Shai Schiller, had quit.
fields.body:
High-flying Israeli technology firm Geo Interactive Media yesterday unnerved its legions of private investors by announcing that its chief executive, Shai Schiller, had quit.

The Tel Aviv-based firm strongly denied reports that Mr Schiller had been forced out as part of a shake-up of senior managers or that it was shifting strategy to concentrate on wireless technologies.

"Schiller was not pushed out, he did a very huge job for us and is retiring," said the chairman, Naftali Shani. "This was not a sudden decision to leave, he told us a long time ago. He will continue to support and advise Geo as a non-executive director."

Shares in Geo were suspended at the company's request late yesterday morning after rumours of Mr Schiller's resignation spread and the price fell by 8% to £13.40.

A statement was issued shortly before 3pm confirming his retirement and replacement by co-founder Eli Reifman. Unusually, it included ringing endorsements from Geo's senior non-executive director, Mike Grabiner - the chief executive of Energis - and a senior banker from adviser Lehman Brothers.

"We wanted to demonstrate that the board unanimously supports Eli's appointment," Mr Shani said.

Shares in Geo were relisted in the afternoon and fell further to close down 16% at £12.15.

Mr Schiller had been chief executive for two years, during which time Geo grew into an international business worth £1.9bn. He retains 1.9m shares in the company, worth £23m, but cannot sell any for another 14 months.

"The past two years have been a tremendously demanding and exhilarating time," Mr Schiller said. "Inevitably the personal demands on me have been very great. I feel that now is the right time to take a break. For the benefit of any doubters out there, I have no intention of setting up a rival software company or to be employed in one."

Mr Reifman is well known to Geo shareholders, having previously co-ordinated investor relations and much of the day-to-day running of the business.

Mr Shani insisted that Geo would maintain its level of investment in broadcasting and messaging.

fields.headline: Official dies in Chechen ambush
fields.trailText: A Chechen local government official was shot dead in a rebel ambush on Sunday, the latest victim of an assassination campaign against Chechens who work for the   pro-Moscow government.
fields.body:
A Chechen local government official was shot dead in a rebel ambush on Sunday, the latest victim of an assassination campaign against Chechens who work for the pro-Moscow government.

Bukara Akhmatov was head of the administration in the village of Oktyabrskoye, the government said.

Meanwhile Interfax reported that Russian troops had found and defused a bomb on Sunday near the house of Akhmad Kadyrov, head of the government, who has survived several assassination attempts this year.

Russian soldiers killed two rebels who tried to flee after planting a mine near the village of Prigorodny, Itar-Tass reported.

Yesterday Russian jets and helicopters continued to bomb forested areas in the south of the country. Rebels attacked Russian positions 15 times in 24 hours, mostly with grenades and small arms, officials said. There was sporadic gunfire in the capital, Grozny.

The Russian military claims that rebel resistance has been all but crushed after a year of fighting, but the rebels show no sign of giving up their struggle for independence and mount almost daily attacks on the federal forces.
AP in Nazran

webTitle: Young paras talk of their fear during rescue mission

fields.headline: Young paras talk of their fear during rescue mission
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Sierra Leone
MoD news from Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The paratroopers involved in the Sierra Leone rescue revealed yesterday they were one of the youngest companies in the British Army, were new to combat and found the experience scary.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown, Ewen MacAskill  and Steven Morris
fields.body:
The paratroopers involved in the Sierra Leone rescue revealed yesterday they were one of the youngest companies in the British Army, were new to combat and found the experience scary.

As the first details of the two-hour firefight emerged, one of them, Captain Liam Cradden, told of having to wade chest-high through a jungle creek under fire.

Another, Corporal Simon Dawes, 29, confirming it had been an inexperienced team, said: "This is the first firefight I have been in where rounds were coming my way."

He added: "I don't like to talk about that sort of situation but it was scary. But once we got into the fighting the training took over."

The paratroopers succeeded in rescuing six British colleagues and a Sierra Leonean held hostage by the renegade West Side Boys, 25 of whom were killed in the firefight.

The one British soldier killed was named yesterday as Bombardier Brad Tinnion, of Harrogate, North Yorkshire. It is understood that he was in 29 Commando Royal Artillery, which acts in support of troops engaged in the kind of rapid jungle action that took place on Sunday, usually providing reconnaissance.

His mother Phyllis Collins said: "We are ever so distraught. We had a lovely son and we have lost him forever."

A dozen British soldiers suffered shrapnel or bullet wounds. The most seriously injured, who underwent emergency surgery, was last night said to be comfortable.

The paratroopers, including casualties, were flying back to Britain last night. Before they left the ministry of defence arranged a short press conference in Freetown in which the two paratroopers were fleetingly wheeled out to provide details of the assault on Rokel creek in the Occra hills.

The paratroopers were dropped by helicopter close to the stronghold of the West Side Boys. One group landed on the south side of the creek to take out a West Side Boys' base, while the other group landed on the north side where the hostages were held.

The two paratroopers spoke with conviction but it was apparent they were permitted to say only a fraction of what they knew. No mention was made of the role of the SAS, whose soldiers freed the hostages. The two paratroopers were also meant to keep the public eye off the men they had rescued, who have yet to be named or allowed to reveal how they came to be captured.

The rescue operation began at 4.00am on Sunday when two Chinooks began ferrying them to the jungle base.

Capt Cradden, 30, second in command of the company, said: "Our part in the operation was to ensure the West Side Boys' heavy guns on the south side could not interfere with operations on the north side and endanger the hostages. The helicopter landing site was 500 metres from the objective and we waded through water up to our chests for about 500 metres."

Capt Cradden, from Sheffield, said he was told to start preparing for the operation 11 days ago as the negotiations with the West Side Boys were continuing.

Cpl Dawes, from Basingstoke, said: "We came under fire at first and then it was taken out. We had helicopters and we had heavy guns that suppressed the fire."

webTitle: Viduka's Olyroos get the ball rolling

fields.headline: Viduka's Olyroos get the ball rolling
fields.standfirst: You might think the Games start in Sydney on Friday. Not so. They begin tomorrow at the MCG
fields.trailText: You might think the Games start in Sydney on Friday. Not so. They begin tomorrow at the MCG when Australia take on Italy in the football tournament.
fields.body:
The opening ceremony may be two days away but the pursuit of Olympic gold gets under way at the MCG tomorrow morning, when Australia take on Italy in the football tournament. The local media has even resorted to billing the occasion as Melbourne's chance to boast it had Sydney's Olympics before Sydney did.

The 2000 Olympics will actually begin with the Australian women's opening match three hours earlier, but as the Matildas won't be playing naked - which is how they appeared in a recent calendar designed to boost their profile - Melburnians are taking more interest in the men.

The city has long taken pride in its Italian community, with names common on Serie A teamsheets having for generations been fixtures in not only the local round-ball game, but also Australian Rules.

Tomorrow, with over 90,000 at the MCG, Australia's home of cricket will resemble English Test grounds in 1976, when a huge proportion of locals cheered the West Indies to victory. Much of the interest among the local unwashed diminished when Harry Kewell's non-appearance was confirmed, however, and even the diehards concede this tournament is destined to join the bulging Soccer Australia file marked "opportunity lost".

When the Socceroos met Iran at the MCG three years ago, with a World Cup berth on the line, Kewell was a kid with not only the world at his feet, but the chance to convert a cynical, tight-shorted audience to the wonders of the world game. As he kick-started a 2-0 lead, the blinkers were coming off. Then they let two in, and everyone left sniggering that if you could lose a game 2-2 they'd stick to Aussie Rules.

The marriage of Australia and football drifted apart that November evening. What hope is left lies with Mark Viduka. Five years ago, as a teenager, he spearheaded Melbourne's Croatian team to a title double, playing on a wasteland of a groundthat could have been a set from Mad Max II.

He moved on to Croatia Zagreb, Celtic and now Leeds, where the chairman Peter Ridsdale last week did his bit for colonial relations by trying to ensure Kewell was not the only Aussie enjoying September in Yorkshire.

Viduka's commitment to country is strong; this week he returned to the family table. "Having been to Atlanta in 96 and knowing what it's like to play for your country in the Olympics, I couldn't wait to get back," he said.

Australians tend to associate "football" with blokes catching the pig skin in outstretched arms, which makes the goalkeeper a logical starting point when speed-reading the host country's prospects.

By happy coincidence, the first position on the team sheet provides a fair gauge of the Olyroos' slim chances of success. Armed with the knowledge that their squad would comprise 15 men under the age of 23 and three over, the selectors would have pondered names like Mark Bosnich, Mark Schwarzer and John Filan to fill the No1 shirt. Sasa Ilic, forever in the hearts of Charlton fans, would have crossed their minds too.

Bosnich did not get a look in, presumably because he is too busy trying to nail down a spot in Manchester United's thirds. Middlesbrough's Schwarzer and Blackburn's Filan were also overlooked. Nobody seems to know what has happened to Ilic. All would have been vying for one of the overage berths. After much pencilling in and crossing out of names these went to Viduka, Birmingham City's Stan Lazaridis and Josip Skoko.

If, like most of Australia, you've never heard of Skoko, he is a midfielder who plays in Belgium. But let's not get bogged down with details. Last Thursday Joe Didulica, the Ajax reserve, conceded that he would not be tackling Italy at the MCG either, a training-ground injury handing the job to Nigel Martyn's Elland Road understudy Danny Milosevic.

If in the next 48 hours Milosevic is the victim of a freak gardening accident, Australia's No1 will be a 19-year-old named Michael Turnbull. Reports that one of his parents recognised him when they crossed paths in the family hallway last week are yet to be confirmed.

Olympic absenteeism, be it through disability or disinterest, will test the next wave setting out to follow the Bosnichs, Vidukas and Kewells - and the increasing and now respectable number of their countrymen playing top-level football.

Against a Brazilian team who will field Ronaldinho and Alex as over-age players, a Chile with six of the 11 who only weeks ago defeated the real Brazil 3-0, and the world Under-21 champions Nigeria, it is going to be a struggle.

Olympic timetable all times BST Tomorrow Football Women's preliminaries 7am Australia v Germany, Sweden v Brazil. Men's preliminaries 8.30am Nigeria v Honduras. 9am Cameroon v Kuwait. 10am United States v Czech Republic, Australia v Italy. TV: Eurosport 7am-12 midday, tomorrow

webTitle: Now drivers face VAT on road tolls

fields.headline: Now drivers face VAT on road tolls
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British motorists are likely to face an increase of almost 20% in the cost of using toll bridges and tunnels.
fields.body:
British motorists are likely to face an increase of almost 20% in the cost of using toll bridges and tunnels.

In a move designed to bring Britain into line with the rest of Europe, the European Court of Justice is expected to order the Treasury today to start levying VAT at 17.5% on all toll charges with immediate effect.

The Dartford river crossing, the Severn bridges, the Humber, Forth ,Tay and Clifton Sus pension bridges, and the Mersey and Tyne tunnels would all be affected. Such a ruling would be certain to anger Gordon Brown, who is already facing increasingly vocal calls from protesters to lower petrol taxes in order to ease motorists' plight.

Higher toll charges are viewed by many as a recipe for more congestion on minor roads and the government has tried to avoid the move for more than 10 years. It argues that tunnels and bridges are a public service and should be exempt from VAT.

British officials are bracing themselves for the worst. "The effects of this judgment are going to be minimal because not many roads are toll routes in the UK and business users will be able to claim the VAT back," one said.

The EC is demanding arrears dating back to 1984 . The court is thought to be considering ordering payments going back to 1994, a sum that would be in excess of £50m.

Such a ruling would be certain to anger Gordon Brown, who is already facing increasingly vocal calls from protesters to lower petrol taxes in order to ease motorists' plight. Higher toll charges are viewed by many as a recipe for more congestion on minor roads and the government has tried to avoid the move for more than 10 years. It argues that tunnels and bridges are a public service and should be exempt from VAT. British officials are bracing themselves for the worst. "The effects of this judgment are going to be minimal because not many roads are toll routes in the UK and business users will be able to claim the VAT back," one said. The EC is demanding arrears dating back to 1984 . The court is thought to be considering ordering payments going back to 1994, a sum that would be in excess of £50m.

fields.headline: French plan to save energy
fields.trailText: France will launch a wide-ranging plan to save energy   by the end of the year, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, told a global warming conference yesterday. Officials said the plan would be inspired by the steps taken after the steep oil price rise in 1973.
fields.body:
France will launch a wide-ranging plan to save energy by the end of the year, the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, told a global warming conference yesterday. Officials said the plan would be inspired by the steps taken after the steep oil price rise in 1973.

Details would be given at a ministerial conference on climate change in the Hague in November.

Mr Jospin was opening a conference on how the Kyoto international agreement on curbing greenhouse gas emissions will work in practice.

Greenpeace activists outside the conference called for the rejection of nuclear power as an alternative. France increased its reliance on nuclear energy after 1973.
Reuters in Lyon

webTitle: Truce fails to stop war in Burundi

fields.headline: Truce fails to stop war in Burundi
fields.trailText: Fighting erupted between Hutu rebels and the army outside the Burundian capital Bujumbura yesterday as violence continued despite a peace agreement signed a fortnight ago by President Pierre Buyoya and the Hutu and Tutsi political parties to end the seven-year civil war.
fields.body:
Fighting erupted between Hutu rebels and the army outside the Burundian capital Bujumbura yesterday as violence continued despite a peace agreement signed a fortnight ago by President Pierre Buyoya and the Hutu and Tutsi political parties to end the seven-year civil war.

The agreement has no provision for a ceasefire and the rebels have yet to sign it.

Yesterday a rebel rocket hit a barracks, killing one soldier and injuring three, an army spokesman, Major Eduard Nibigira, said.

The army fired at rebels attacking Kanyosha and Kabezi, nine miles south of Bujumbura, killing 10, he added. He said the rebels had infiltrated from Tanzania.

More than 200,000 people have been killed since October 1993 when Tutsi paratroopers assassinated the Hutu Melchior Ndadaye, Burnudi's first democratically elected president.

On Thursday rebels killed seven soldiers in Kabezi when they tried to break through the government lines, the army said.

Major Nibigira said: "Tanzania has a big responsibility in everything that's going on in Burundi." The army had deployed six battalions on the border, he added.

Residents said the rebels had cut off the water supply to Kabezi and Kanyosha and threatened to punish those who went back to school for the beginning of the term yesterday.
AP in Kabezi

fields.headline: Malaysians taken in copycat raid
fields.trailText: Three Malaysians have been kidnapped from a Malaysian resort off the east coast of Borneo in a snatch which virtually copied the one that led to the four-month hostage crisis on the Philippine island of Jolo.
fields.body:
Three Malaysians have been kidnapped from a Malaysian resort off the east coast of Borneo in a snatch which virtually copied the one that led to the four-month hostage crisis on the Philippine island of Jolo.

This time there were no foreign visitors at the resort, Pandanan island. Those missing are the resort manager, a diving instructor and a visitor.

No one has claimed responsibility or made any demands, and it was not clear yesterday where the hostages have been taken.

The final four foreigners held by the Aby Sayyaf Muslim separatists on Jolo were freed last week, ransomed by Libya. The group still holds a Filipino, two French journalists, 12 evangelists and an American seized a fortnight ago.

fields.headline: Saddam's quest for new glories
fields.trailText: Saddam Hussein may or may not be dying, but he is trying to leave his mark with a new national anthem and a Baghdad monument celebrating Iraq's "victorious" emergence from the Gulf war which its president set off when he tried to take over Kuwait in 1990.
fields.body:
Saddam Hussein may or may not be dying, but he is trying to leave his mark with a new national anthem and a Baghdad monument celebrating Iraq's "victorious" emergence from the Gulf war which its president set off when he tried to take over Kuwait in 1990.

Creating a design that flatters the president and is full of symbolism but carries no risk of misinterpretation is always a delicate matter in Iraq.

State TV showed President Saddam inspecting 10 different models, while their designers explained the meaning, but he did not appear totally statisfied.

"However much effort we exert to design a monument to the Mother of Battles, we will not able to cover all its meaning, largeness and greatness," he said.

Meanwhile, he has commissioned Iraq's poets to come up with a new and shorter anthem whose words are easier to remember and sing than the present ones by "soldiers during battle" and "women in their fields of work", the Iraqi press said.

To guide the poets he presented a few lines he had composed: "Glory to martyrs ... glory to mothers ... down with hesitation and defeatism ... glory to our nation and homeland."

fields.headline: Hong Kong voters ebb away
fields.trailText: Elections for the legislative council produced a dismal result in Hong Kong yesterday, with a sharply reduced poll indicating lack of public enthusiasm.
fields.body:
Elections for the legislative council produced a dismal result in Hong Kong yesterday, with a sharply reduced poll indicating lack of public enthusiasm.

Only 43.6% of eligible voters came out; two years ago, despite a fierce storm, it was 53.3%. No one claimed victory in the 24 legislative council seats put up for direct election - the only real test of opinion.

The opposition Democratic party led by Martin Lee won the largest share of these seats, as before. But it did lose ground to its main challenger, the pro-Beijing Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong.

Most of the 36 other seats - chosen on restricted forms of franchise - went as expected to pro-government candidates. This ensures that Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive - who is not standing in the election - will be able to block any challenge by the legislative council.

But the low turnout is widely seen as a negative verdict on his regime's credibility.

"I voted but many of my friends did not bother," said one ordinary voter in Hong Kong Island constituency who gave her name as Ms Lim. "We think that Beijing tells Mr Tung what to do, while the councillors just waste time talking and collect their salaries."

fields.headline: At this price?  Shire
fields.trailText: It may have just missed out this time but it can only be a matter of time before Shire Pharmaceutical makes it into the FTSE 100.
fields.body:
It may have just missed out this time but it can only be a matter of time before Shire Pharmaceutical makes it into the FTSE 100.

The combination of strong interims and a clutch of positive announcements has made it hot property in the City. As one analyst put it: "If results are anything in line with what people are expecting, it is going to go like a bomb."

Pharmaceuticals is a fast-moving, exciting industry for investors. This has led to consolidation which in turn increased the opportunities for smaller companies to exploit areas overlooked or rejected by larger rivals.

Within this field, Shire is a high growth firm with a strong, experienced management. The £3bn company was recently told US drug regulators are ready to approve Reminyl, its treatment for Alzheimer's disease. This follows approval in Europe where it should be on the market by the end of the year.

The Alzheimer's market is predicted to be worth around £400m.

Further success is expected from its new formulation for Adderall, its treatment for attention deficit disorder. The company has branded initial trials "positive" and will give detailed results next month in a presentation to the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry.

It plans to apply for registration of the drug, named SLI 381, by the US food and drug administration.

There is, however, room for improvement. Although strong in the US, Shire could look to flex its muscle elsewhere. Beefing up distribution in Europe would help, as would adding to its therapeutic product business.

Shares in Shire do not come cheap and could go to a year's high of £14.88 if the drugs prove to be as successful as the trials suggest. This, however, may take some time to achieve.

Last night Shire stood at £12.73, which was 4p down on the day. But a final push could see the company finally among the top 100 by the December or March re-evaluations. One to look out for.

webTitle: Relyon tips security unit out of bed

fields.headline: Relyon tips security unit out of bed
fields.trailText: West Country bed maker Relyon is planning to demerge its closed circuit television operations in a move that spells the end for one of the stock market's most unusual business combinations.
fields.body:
West Country bed maker Relyon is planning to demerge its closed circuit television operations in a move that spells the end for one of the stock market's most unusual business combinations.

Relyon is best known for expensive "pocket sprung" beds, sold at the top end of the furtniture industry. However, the company has been developing a sideline in closed-circuit television since buying the electronics business Photo-Scan in 1987.

Chief executive Ian Topping said the company had come to the conclusion that the two activities had little in common. When it bought Photo-Scan, Relyon had been looking for fast-growing businesses to absorb some of its steady cashflow.

He pointed out that the same customers sometimes wanted beds and cameras: many of the department stores that sell the company's beds also need to be supplied with advanced security devices.

Mr Topping said: "We are a hybrid - we've got quite separate constituent features."

Photo-Scan is to be floated on the Alternative Investment Market, with a likely value of £30m-£50m. This is likely to dwarf the rest of Relyon, which is expected to be worth £25m-£30m.

The group announced a 27% rise in half-year profits to £3.1m. Its shares rose 14p to 242.5p.

webTitle: Swift descent into violence at the Crown casino

fields.headline: Swift descent into violence at the Crown casino
fields.trailText: This was supposed to be three days of high-powered talks bringing together in Melbourne some of biggest names of the Asian-Pacific region. Instead, the World Economic Forum descended into Seattle-style violence as anti-capitalist demonstrators clashed with police.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and  Patrick Barkham  in Sydney
fields.body:
This was supposed to be three days of high-powered talks bringing together in Melbourne some of biggest names of the Asian-Pacific region. Instead, the World Economic Forum descended into Seattle-style violence as anti-capitalist demonstrators clashed with police.

The success of demonstrations last November in scuppering vital trade talks has given new life to the protesters - many of whom had rallied to the anti-capitalist cause via websites which sprung up from the demonstrations against the World Trade Organisation in Seattle.

At least eight people were taken to hospital, including two police officers, as protesters tried to prevent delegates entering the Crown casino. Police reported that there were 1,500 demonstrators, although the organisers claimed nearer 10,000.

Western Australia's right-wing prime minister, Richard Court, was stranded in his vehicle for 20 minutes as protesters daubed it with paint and let down the tyres, while Aboriginal activists "arrested" Mr Court for supporting mandatory sentencing, which leads to the jailing of people in Australia for petty crime.

Mr Court was forced to turn back after 50 baton-charging police officers failed to dislodge the protesters' barricades. Chosen for its secluded riverside site, the casino and other probable targets of anti-globalisation feeling nearby had been heavily fortified against the protesters.

What is worse for the organisers of the conference is that the demonstrations slowed the WEF's registration programme and reduced the number attending speeches and dinners on the first day of the conference, as up to 200 delegates stayed in their hotel rooms. Observers inside the building reported some of the events were only 50% full.

Brave face

After Melbourne, the next stops on the travel itinerary of the global summit protesters are the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Prague later this month. In public they are putting a brave face on things, but in private the world's top trade negotiators admit that the chances of a new round of trade negotiations starting by the end of the year have shrunk to zero.

Diplomats from the 139 members of the World Trade Organisation had hoped that the collapse of attempts to launch a new round last December would prove a temporary setback. Now they are blaming the US presidential elections for the delay, noting that any substantial negotiations are impossible until the political make-up of the new administration is known.

Next year, the world's most populous country, China, joins the Geneva based body, which will tip the balance of power inside the organisation away from the "Quad" - Japan, Canada, the US and the EU - who have traditionally managed the global trading system and in the past provided political impetus for new talks.

As a price of joining, China is opening large parts of its industry to competition from foreign firms, which is expected to cause disruption throughout its economy. Beijing will not be enthusiastic about starting another set of talks to open further markets until it has digested the fallout.

Privately, Quad policymakers admit that there is no political momentum for a new round, and that the trade agenda is bogged down in Geneva bureaucracy. Senior trade policymakers are now whispering that the organisation's rambunctious New Zealand head, Mike Moore may be a lame duck who will never see a trade round launched under his watch.

Indeed, time is running out for Moore who has only two more years at the helm of the WTO. The political fudge which shoehorned him into the job means he has a shorter than usual term, split with his rival, the Thai finance minister, Dr Supachai Panitchpakdi. Moore was the US's first choice and Supachai made himself so unpopular with US negotiators during the selection process, that some insiders doubt he will be able to muster sufficient support from the world's biggest trading nation to launch a round during his term of office which ends in 2005.

Fractious relations

Assuming Supachai's successor manages to get a trade round launched with a year of taking office, past experience suggests it will take five or six years to conclude. That suggests the earliest that the next round of talks will be signed off will be around 2012-13 - a gap of almost 20 years since the end of the Uruguay round and the longest gap between trade rounds since the founding of the WTO's predecessor 50 years ago.

The strains of running the global trading system without fresh negotiations are showing. Relations between the world's biggest trading blocs, the EU and the US, are increasingly fractious, with the two seemingly unable to solve arguments over hormone treated beef, Caribbean bananas and Washington's billion dollar export subsidies to US multinationals.

Any day now, the US will publish the latest list of EU goods it is targeting for sanctions under long running disputes over bananas and hormone treated beef. The US has been authorised to apply $300m (£205 m) of sanctions by the WTO because the EU's ban on beef and import regime favouring Caribbean bananas contravene global trading rules. But America's decision to rotate the list it targets has been described by EU negotiators as pouring fuel on the fire as it creates uncertainty for a greater group of producers. Battles behind the scenes between the world's trading powers are as heated as the fights outside their summits - and the protesters' anti-trade agenda appears to be getting the upper hand.

fields.headline: Light-fingered Olympian admits 80 year-old crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: The oldest surviving Olympic medallist flew from the US to Sydney yesterday to clear up an unsolved crime that had vexed the Olympic movement for 80 years.
fields.body:
The oldest surviving Olympic medallist flew from the US to Sydney yesterday to clear up an unsolved crime that had vexed the Olympic movement for 80 years.

Light-fingered Olympian Hal Prieste, 103, handed back to officials the Olympic flag he had shinned up a 15ft flagpole to snatch on a dare at the 1920 Antwerp games. The flag has been locked in a shabby suitcase for most of the past 80 years.

"You can't be selfish about these things. You've got to figure that it's for the good of the club and the Olympic Committee," Mr Prieste said, returning the flag to the president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch.

In 1920, police could not catch the US bronze medal-winning diver, who later became one of the original Keystone Cops who appeared in slapstick films with Charlie Chaplin.

Mr Priest said his friend and US team-mate, Duke Paoa Kahanamoku, a swimmer who later popularised surfing, had dared him to steal the pennant.

"We were buddies. We did a lot of comedy tricks like Laurel and Hardy, you know," said Mr Prieste, whose Hollywood career spanned 27 films.

While amassing a colourful CV as a touring vaudeville player, Mr Prieste forgot about the guilty secret hidden away in his suitcase.

When moving house in the mid-1990s, he rediscovered the flag, the first to show the five-ring motif of the modern Olympics. He let his secret slip to a journalist at an Olympic awards ceremony in 1997.

Bill Hybl of the US Olympic committee yesterday reassured Mr Prieste, who is now almost blind and deaf, and a wheelchair user, that the Olympic movement would show leniency.

"I've been advised by our friends in Belgium that the statute of limitation has run out on his act of 80 years ago," he said.

Australians may grumble at this generosity. A four-year ban was slapped on their Olympic swimmer Dawn Fraser for trying to steal an Olympic flag from the Japanese emperor's palace during the 1964 Tokyo games.

The flag is to be placed in the IOC's museum in Geneva. Mr Prieste, who now lives in a retirement home in New Jersey, hopes it will be displayed with a plaque bearing his name.

fields.headline: Errant trader causes chaos
fields.trailText: There were red faces all round in the City yesterday as a rogue trade sent share prices tumbling and brought near-panic to the market as the offer for the London Stock Exchange was finally announced.
fields.body:
There were red faces all round in the City yesterday as a rogue trade sent share prices tumbling and brought near-panic to the market as the offer for the London Stock Exchange was finally announced.

"Chaos" was how one trader described proceedings at 8.14am, when the FTSE 100 plunged 208.6 points to 6,392.1 after a sell order ripped through the market.

The violent fall caught dealers across the Square Mile completely unawares: they had been expecting the FTSE 100 to open modestly lower.

A lone trader at German securities house Deutsche Bank, which refused to comment, was said to have caused the chaos. It seems the errant trader, who was described by market gossips as "wet behind the ears", was trying to sell a basket of around 102 stocks - the entire FTSE 100 and two FTSE 250 stocks - worth around £15m on behalf of an institutional client.

But rather than selling the basket of shares at the so-called mid-price, the trader had entered "at best" on his terminal, causing Deutsche to sell at any price for which a buyer could be found.

To add to the confusion, London's futures market, Liffe, was also experiencing some "technical problems" and dealers had no idea where the market was headed.

The consequences, at least for a while, were dire.

Trading in a total of 23 FTSE 100 stocks were temporarily suspended. Glaxo Wellcome, already under pressure from news that completion of its merger with SmithKline Beecham, down 9.5p to 863.5p, had been postponed for a second time, slumped 120p to £18 - although it recovered to close 10p lower at £19.10. Abbey National tumbled 27.5p to 815p, but ended 5.5p easier at 837p.

Most traders expressed surprise that a single trade worth just £15m could wreak such havoc, but noted talk that Deutsche Bank intends to honour the transaction.

Leading shares eventually recovered from the early fall to close down 18.7 points at 6,582 points, with Vodafone, the market's biggest stock, doing most of the damage.

Strategists expect the FTSE 100 to trade lower until later this week, when US consumer and producer price data are released. The data should give investors a chance to assess the impact of the strong crude oil price on the US economy.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 fell 34.4 points to 6,954.1, and the Techmark 100 eased 18.8 points to 3,990.64.

Vodafone closed 12.75p weaker at 271.25p on staggering volume of 477m after Merrill Lynch - acting on behalf of Hutchison Whampoa - set about placing a three-year $2.5b bond convertible into Vodafone shares.

According to dealers, the bond issue will cut Hutchison's 3.4% stake in Vodafone to around 1.6bn shares. They attributed the weakness in Vodafone to the work of the arbitrageurs and the fact that the rest of the Hutchison stake is still overhanging the market. There were also suggestions that Merrill Lynch was attempting to hedge its exposure to the bond by selling Vodafone shares short.

Elsewhere, aerospace and defence firm BAe Systems topped the FTSE 100 performance chart, rising 21.5p to 381.5p on the back of a Morgan Stanley upgrade.

Oil majors Shell, up 17.5p to 627p and BP, 18.5p better at 671p, recovered from early weakness as crude for October delivery headed back toward 10-year highs in New York.

Analysts expect Opec's decision to raise output by 800,00 barrels a day to have little affect on the oil price.

Lower down the scale, engineer Glynwed picked up 12.25p to 201p as rumours of a 300p a share bid rumbled around the market.

Engineer Brunel Holdings extended Friday's gains, rising 0.75p, or 21.43%, to 4.25p, on news that John Hemming, the hi-tech entrepreneur, has increased his stake to 10.3%.

On AIM, video compression firm Forbidden Technology rose 20p, or 9,41%, to 232.5p after being tipped on Channel 4's investment series, Show Me the Money.

fields.headline: Glaxo merger faces US delay
fields.standfirst: Fresh inquiry by regulators holds up $110bn deal
fields.trailText: The £110bn merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham is likely to be delayed for another two months, it emerged yesterday, because of a fresh inquiry by American regulators that has angered senior executives.
fields.body:
The £110bn merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham is likely to be delayed for another two months, it emerged yesterday, because of a fresh inquiry by American regulators that has angered senior executives.

A renewed hold-up by the Federal Trade Commission has led some insiders to accuse the US government of using Glaxo and SmithKline as a "political football", with the Democrats keen to show that they are tough on the drugs industry during the ongoing presidential election campaign.

The deal, which will create the world's largest pharmaceuticals corporation, was initially scheduled for completion in August. The target date was put back to September 25 because of regulatory questions and the groups yesterday owned up to a fresh delay.

Reluctant to name a new day, they would only say that they expected completion "by the end of this year". Insiders said the general feeling was that the hold-up would last until November. Glaxo's shares slipped 10p to £19.10, while SmithKline's fell 9.5p to 863.5p.

The nature of the FTC's latest request has infuriated the companies. The commission has asked for more information about smoking cessation products - Glaxo makes a prescription drug, Zyban, while SmithKline produces Nicorette chewing gum and Nicoderm skin patches.

Officials from the FTC had initially ruled that this area posed no problems, deciding that SmithKline's products were in a different market because they were available without a prescription.

A SmithKline spokesman said: "It's disappointing, but it's manageable. The FTC has the right to revisit any areas it wants to. This underlines the sort of heightened scrutiny we're seeing in the US, not just in our industry, but in mergers across the board."

The FTC is concerned that the combined group could have an excessive share of the smoking cessation market. The two companies complain that the issue is relatively trivial - their combined sales last year were £16.9bn, of which anti-smoking products contributed £450m.

The hold-up means that Glaxo's chairman Sir Richard Sykes will remain in a full-time role for longer than he anticipated - he becomes non-executive chairman after completion. Several other directors, including SmithKline's Andrew Bonfield and Glaxo's Jeremy Strachan, will be obliged to delay their departures.

The groups had planned a satellite link-up for staff in the week of completion, allowing senior executives to address employees worldwide. This has been cancelled, as has a party in London to mark the occasion. Hundreds of redundancy payouts will be delayed as a result of the hold-up, as will the introduction of a new logo and brand image.

Analysts said the financial impact would be negligible, although Michael King of SG Securities said: "It's certainly embarrassing for them and negative for sentiment. I would imagine both companies are rather frustrated."

 Phytopharm is beginning clinical trials of a traditional Asian tonic for dementia that the company believes could reverse the death of brain receptors which causes Alzheimer's disease.

Its shares rose 3.5p to 654p on the announcement.


Slow acting relief:
January 17: Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham announce plans to merge, with the tie-up to be effective 'in the summer'.

May 8: European commission approves the combination.

July 5: Full details of the deal are disclosed, with completion scheduled for August 21.

July 25: Merger delayed until September 25.

July 31: Shareholders approve the deal, although a third vote against multi-million pound boardroom pay packages.

September 11: Merger delayed again, to be completed 'by the end of this year'.

fields.headline: £27m war toll for Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Blue Circle Industries paid 26.8m to advisers to help fend off a hostile bid from Lafarge of France.
fields.body:
Blue Circle Industries paid 26.8m to advisers to help fend off a hostile bid from Lafarge of France.

Blue Circle revealed the payments yesterday as its reported that pre-tax profits fell to £91.5m from £170.3m over the six months to June 30. There was a 45% increase in operating profits as markets in south-east Asia bounced back.

Chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite said the company was fulfilling all the promises it made in its Lafarge defence document. It was on track to deliver £400m worth of disposals and return a similar amount to shareholders.

The company was also "bang on target" for annual savings of £116m by 2003 . He denied, however, that the Lafarge approach was the catalyst for change, while conceding it had the speed of reform.

He admitted that he would have preferred not to spend nearly £27m on defence but rather use the money for purposes such as further industry consolidation.

Recent talks with Southdown in the US about a potential tie-up had ceased but Blue Circle planned to seek links next year once it had fulfilled most of its own restructuring.

Blue Circle shares remained steady, down 0.25p at 410p, with analysts upbeat about the results. David Taylor of Teather & Greenwood said: "[Blue Circle] are definitely moving in the right direction, with targets being met and trading and cost recovery coming through."

But the "Lafarge tanks are still parked on the Blue Circle lawn", with the the French company retaining 33.2% of Blue Circle. He questioned how the firm would deliver the second tranche of £400m to shareholders without paying an unpopular special dividend or using another buyback of shares which could give Lafarge a higher stake.

Briefing analysts last week, Lafarge said it was still interested in Blue Circle, triggering speculation it would make another bid next year.

fields.headline: Gerard goes native
fields.trailText: Restaurant chain Groupe Chez Gerard has given up going on recruitment drives in France because it reckons it can recruit equally good waiters and chefs in Britain.
fields.body:
Restaurant chain Groupe Chez Gerard has given up going on recruitment drives in France because it reckons it can recruit equally good waiters and chefs in Britain.

The change in policy emerged as the company plunged to a £2.1m full-year loss after a £6.5m write-off on the sale of its poorly performing Richoux cafes.

Groupe Chez Gerard has traditionally employed a recruitment officer to trawl French recruitment fairs in the belief that a few European mainland accents add authenticity to its offering of "the best steak frites this side of Paris".

However, chief executive David Williams revealed that this practice had been halted - he said rapid expansion has made the company much better known in Britain, and Groupe Chez Gerard feels it can compete for competent staff at home.

Groupe Chez Gerard employs just under 1,000 people in 19 restaurants. The group's strategy is to roll out two brands, Chez Gerard and Livebait. It plans to open in 20 more locations over two years, including Bristol, Manchester, Cambridge and Oxford.

Year-end profits on continuing operations rose 6.6% to £3.6m and the group said current trading was encouraging, with like for like sales up 3%. The shares rose 6.5p to 165p.

Mr Williams said he was keen to become "the UK's leading premium branded restaurant operator".

The company also has several one-off restaurants.

fields.headline: Next time it could be the nuclear button
fields.standfirst: Error exposes market's fragility
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange is suffering from what equity analysts commonly refer to as "negative news flow". The expression is trite and can be quite misleading, giving the impression that things are, in reality, going swimmingly - just that no one has noticed. So one of the prime pieces of news flow affecting the exchange yesterday deserves closer examination.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange is suffering from what equity analysts commonly refer to as "negative news flow". The expression is trite and can be quite misleading, giving the impression that things are, in reality, going swimmingly - just that no one has noticed. So one of the prime pieces of news flow affecting the exchange yesterday deserves closer examination.

Some junior clot, it appears, freshly promoted from back to front office at the mighty Deutsche Bank (and presumably now travelling in the opposite direction) pushed the wrong buttons on a client's £15m program trade, causing a 200-point jack-knife on London's supposed benchmark share index, the FTSE 100.

On one level this did not matter one jot. It was 8.15 in the morning, so most market participants were still stuck into their vanilla Danish. And Deutsche, grown-up player that it has become, declared it was ready to stand by the mistaken dealings, taking a hit of, say, £50,000 in the process.

Since the whole matter was over in a moment or two, there do not appear to have been victims elsewhere in the market: no one was closed out of their spread bet positions needlessly, a stream of computerised sell orders were not triggered unnecessarily at other trading houses, while the Footsie itself recovered just about all of the lost ground by the close yesterday.

Yet the trade could have been substantially bigger. If the Deutsche junior could get one drop-down menu wrong on his terminal, the chances are he could also have dropped an extra nought into the "size" box.

And the deal might have been done at 3.15pm rather than 8.15am, catching Wall Street mid-morning.

The damage could, in fact, have been widespread, with trades across the world thrown into dispute.

The FTSE 100 index, and the many financial products linked to its performance, are intrinsically linked to London's status as the premier international stock market.

They create the liquidity which, at the end of the day, the market could not exist without.

If the index and the technology used to support it are not robust and reliable, the money (and the jobs) will migrate elsewhere.

Clegg mystery

The year was 1992 and the City was full of leaden stocks. Corporate bosses had been cutting corners to keep their companies afloat. Some got found out and paid the price; others managed to trade through what was a tough recession.

But it now seems clear that John Clegg, the man then running a struggling metal basher called Wace, had found a different trading route to riches -amassing a multi-million pound fortune between himself and various members of his extended family by secretly trading his company's stock, while other shareholders were left to count their growing losses.

Details of the alleged insider dealing ring were uncovered by the exchange's survelliance department and passed on to various other enforcement bodies amid suspicions that some sort of financing operation for the IRA was under way. There was nothing so exotic as money laundering for Irish terrorists, although the insider evidence against the Cleggs was enough to warrant the appointment of two Department of Trade inspectors to carry out a full-dress inquiry.

That inquiry has now been published, having been signed off at the DTI on June 22 this year. It makes colourful reading, flitting between north London, Dublin, South Africa, Chicago and various other points as it tells the story of Mr Clegg's various name changes and his persistent attacks of blindness, which robbed him of his ability to spot the fact that half of his family were sitting on the shareholder registers of every company Wace planned to buy.

The inspectors conclude that Mr Clegg benefited from substantial secret dealings in companies such as European Colour, Tinsley Robor, Parkway and Wace itself. They reject his denials that he knew anything about these suspicious trades.

But, despite the colour, the dry humour and the dedication to detail, it seems inconceivable that two top DTI officials and their staff could have spent the better part of a decade putting the thing together. And for what? This is as far as the matter is going to go. The authorities will not be starting any extradition proceedings. After all these years, the DTI is content to let the matter rest.

Officials at the department insist the investigation has cost just £150,000 to pursue which at the very least indicates that the DTI needs to review its internal accounting procedures, because the numbers do not add up. And it is not clear why the Clegg case has been published now. Maybe they are having a clear-out before the DTI inspection department is closed down. Maybe we can even look forward to the real Archer story.

fields.headline: EasyJet loses landing charges case
fields.trailText: The government last night backed Luton airport in its battle with self-styled consumer champion EasyJet after the airline had argued it would be unfairly penalised by high landing and take-off charges.
fields.body:
The government last night backed Luton airport in its battle with self-styled consumer champion EasyJet after the airline had argued it would be unfairly penalised by high landing and take-off charges.

Chris Mullin, air minister, ruled that he could not impose a cap on charges for airlines using the airport. The ruling effectively meansthe government does not think the low- cost airline, owned by entrepreneur Stelios Haji-Ioannou, has a case against the airport.

Mr Mullin said he was not persuaded that Luton had abused its position in negotiating new charges. The introduction of a cap would require strong evidence of "abuse or potential abuse by an airport of a dominant position".

EasyJet had argued that Barclays bank, a 65% shareholder in the airport, was forcing Luton to threaten rises in landing charges and hence increasing ticket prices. The airline could transfer its base to Stansted, but would face higher landing charges there.

EasyJet pays a fee of around £1.60 for each departing passenger. Luton airport says it has to pay the local council £3 for each EasyJet traveller and wants to increase this fee to around £7.

Mr Mullin said he hoped the two sides could come to an understanding and that both would continue to flourish.

Eurotunnel drivers' ballot

Eurotunnel train drivers are to be balloted on strikes in a dispute over union recognition which could "paralyse" shuttle services. Drivers' union Aslef is urging its 230 members at Eurotunnel to back 24-hour stoppages from next month.

The move follows a long dispute over a single union deal struck between Eurotunnel and the TGWU union, under which that union will represent Eurotunnel employees - including train drivers.

Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said: "I hope Eurotunnel management will now see sense and avoid the disruption to the travelling public which follows from their refusal to recognise the union of their train crews' choice."

Japan on road to recovery

Japan's economic recovery appeared to be picking up steam yesterday with the release of data showing that the country's cautious consumers are at last loosening their purse strings. The world's second-largest economy grew at the unexpectedly rapid rate of 1% from June to August for a second consecutive quarter of growth.

Analysts said this expansion, equivalent to 4.2% on a yearly basis, confirmed that Japan is pulling clear of its deepest and most protracted recession in 50 years. The greatest cause for optimism was the sign of a pick-up in consumer spending, which accounts for three-fifths of the country's output.

Goldman's $6.5bn buy

Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, announced its biggest acquisition since going public yesterday with a $6.5bn (£4.4bn) agreed bid for Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a leading American market-maker.

The 54 partners at the New York-based firm are to share the proceeds of the sale. Goldman also set aside $900m of its own shares to be used as a retention pool for the firm's 2,700 employees. Wall Street welcomed the deal, with shares in Goldman rising more than $5 to $130 yesterday morning.

Presley joins MGM top guns

Actor and businesswoman Priscilla Presley has been elected to the board of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, MGM said yesterday. Ms Presley's election expands the board of the entertainment corporation to 11 members.

Ms Presley, 55, starred in the Naked Gun film series and is chairman of the advisory board of Elvis Presley Enterprises. She married rock legend Elvis in 1967 and the couple divorced in 1973.

MGM's stock was unchanged at $24 yesterday.

webTitle: Vodafone hit as Hutchison cuts stake

fields.headline: Vodafone hit as Hutchison cuts stake
fields.trailText: Shares in Vodafone were laid low yesterday after Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong conglomerate, reduced its stake in the mobile phone company through a $2.5bn placing. Hutchison shed the stake through a bond offering that is convertible into Vodafone shares. The offering closed by 2pm and dealers said it was twice oversubscribed.
fields.body:
Shares in Vodafone were laid low yesterday after Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong conglomerate, reduced its stake in the mobile phone company through a $2.5bn placing. Hutchison shed the stake through a bond offering that is convertible into Vodafone shares. The offering closed by 2pm and dealers said it was twice oversubscribed.

Hutchison found itself holding 5% of Vodafone at the beginning of the year after the mobile phone group acquired Germany's Mannesmann. In a rapid fire exchange of assets Hutchison acquired 10% of Mannesmann after selling the German company its UK mobile phone business Orange.

Yesterday's disposal, representing some 1% of the company caused Vodafone to sink 13p to 271p. The sheer size of Vodafone meant the sale had a knock-on effect on the FTSE 100 although the blow was softened by a recovery in the oil sector and a lively opening on Wall Street, the FTSE closing down 18.7 points at 6,582.

The bonds issued by Hutchison have an exchange price of 356p-362p, representing a premium of around 27% to Friday's closing share price.

Hutchison is understood to have raised the cash to expand its own telecomunications interests. Analysts cited the high cost of bidding for third generation licences as well as building new networks.

The company was behind the successful bid for a fifth licence in Britain in partnership with TWI of Canada and is also a large shareholder in Voicestream, the US cellular network.

Winning the UK licence alone cost the company £4.4bn while the group estimates the price of building the network at another £5bn.

fields.headline: Terrorism fear for Cape Town
fields.trailText: Faced with a campaign of terror in Cape Town, South Africa's safety and security minister declared yesterday that the country could descend into the sort of violence that has blighted Algeria unless the perpetra- tors were caught soon.
fields.body:
Faced with a campaign of terror in Cape Town, South Africa's safety and security minister declared yesterday that the country could descend into the sort of violence that has blighted Algeria unless the perpetra- tors were caught soon.

Three people have died and more than 100 have been injured since a bombing campaign began in Cape Town two years ago. There have been 19 attacks on public places, eight of them this year. Police stations, the airport, restaurants and gay bars have been targeted; last week a magistrate was assassinated.

The minister, Steve Tshwete, said there was no doubt that a vigilante group called People Against Gangsterism and Drugs (or Pagad) and its armed wing known as the G-Force was behind the attacks. Members style themselves as populist Muslim activists, but analysts see them as basically a gang protecting their financial interests through intimidation.

"The police are not looking anywhere else. The security data focuses us on only one direction and that is Pagad," Mr Tshwete said. More police were being sent in, he said.

"Our friends in Algeria have even intimated to us if we are not taking a bold stand we might soon find ourselves in a similar situation as one finds in Algeria today." Tens of thousands have died in Algeria since 1992 in fighting between Islamic extremist factions, and between these factions and the security forces.
Mike Cohen in Cape Town, AP,

fields.headline: Insults in high places
fields.standfirst: Bitter altercations are routine in politics
fields.trailText: Coming days after it was claimed, plausibly if not conclusively, that a former American president, his finger on the nuclear button, was drugged and half-demented through most of his second term, the revelation that Tony Blair was heard to say "blast Gordon" or, yet more daringly, "damn Gordon", has limited shock value. Prime ministers swear at their chancellors (and vice versa) as a constitutional duty.
fields.body:
Coming days after it was claimed, plausibly if not conclusively, that a former American president, his finger on the nuclear button, was drugged and half-demented through most of his second term, the revelation that Tony Blair was heard to say "blast Gordon" or, yet more daringly, "damn Gordon", has limited shock value. Prime ministers swear at their chancellors (and vice versa) as a constitutional duty. Think Major-Lamont, Thatcher-Lawson, Wilson-Callaghan or, if you want an even earlier Labour precedent, Ramsay Mac and hairshirted Philip Snowden. In moments of provocation, football managers swear at team captains, producers at directors, board chairs at chief executives - so under what rule of exceptions should Number 10 be a haven of brotherly love? Or sisterly. No, what is astonishing from the recent assault of the books on the Blair government is how unbruised it emerges.

The killer anecdotes in the serialised versions which appeared this weekend of Andrew Rawnsley's account of the Blair-Brown relationship and Julia Langdon's saga of Mo, come from before that watershed winter of 1998-1999, which saw the departure of those merchants of bile, Peter Mandelson and Charlie Whelan. Nothing said or done between cabinet colleagues since May 1997 has yet matched the venom and mistrust of John Major's last three years in office. On Sunday evening television we had Michael Heseltine refighting old wars with Norman Tebbit. What can Labour offer to compete with that clash - made all the more ferocious because it was based on ideological difference? Even on Europe, allegedly a rich site of Blair-Brown dissent, differences are over tactics and timing, not substance. Julia Langdon's racy tale of Mo Mowlam's life and loves points to few ideological and policy differences from the Blairite mainstream. Sex and swearing can spice a political narrative. But without a bit of real left-right there is not much chance of a knock-out.
