fields.headline: Big, loud and proud
fields.standfirst: Let's hear it for the great northern lass, says  Laura Barton
fields.trailText: Let's hear it for the great northern lass, says  Laura Barton
fields.body:
W e're big lasses; sturdy-calved, and vast-bellied, hefty arms like slabs of meat. For we've to weather the hoist and heave-ho of our skivvying, and have to ride out our cold northern winters. We dine on pie and chips, stewed tea and beef dripping, think lasagne's exotic (what would we want with that foreign muck?). Give us hot-pot and Chorley cakes and a nice bit of cod. We're ruined with children, and husbands who drink or who died in the pit some 30 years ago now. Freshly-permed and large-breasted in the doorways of our terraced houses.

Or we're out on the town with our gladrags on: tight white dresses and too much slap on our faces. We're Tia Maria-ed and ready for dancing. We are always game for a laugh. For we're northern women, you see, and you know what that means - flat vowels, big chests and lacking in class.

That's what they say, and how are you to know better if you've never put a foot past the Watford gap. But you know what it's like - all those chimneys and cobbles, weekdays 7.30, the Coronation Street credits. We're hauled in when you need us, for a game show, a soap opera. Think Lisa Tarbuck, rather than her svelte southern replacement for the Big Breakfast, Denise Van Outen.

E ven Marks and Spencer tell us we're frumps. They may have launched a new advertising campaign featuring a naked size 16 model who bellows "I'm normal", but last week they decided against launching their top-of-the-range clothing in Liverpool. Deprived of their exclusive Autograph collection, the good women of that city surely wept in the streets - forced now to spend their wages in Wade Smith and Armani. Dreaming of a day when they can afford the train fare to the M&S flagship store Manchester.

And yesterday, a survey by Thornton's informed us of the great north-south chocolate divide. After work, southerners will head to the gym or meet friends, while our friends in the north nip home, see the family, share some toffees in front of the telly. Up north they buy bigger boxes too, family-sized ones for the lounge.

Back in March, Professor Stephen Gray of Nottingham Trent University unveiled his study of some 2,500 women across Britain. He told us that the ladies of Merseyside were the biggest in the land, weighing an average of 11st 2lb, with busts of 42 inches, and hips just half an inch wider. "Factory girls in the north face less peer pressure to be slim than office girls in London," he said. And he's lucky we couldn't hear him above the roar of the machinery, 'cause we'd have decked him. Coming 'round here with his fancy statistics. "There's a lot of science gone into this," he said. Ay, lad, and we'll have kicked it out again before we're through.

Professor Gray works for a company called Computer Clothing Research, advising fashion chains such as Next. This particular survey was commissioned by Marks and Spencer, which subsequently launched a pilot scheme of tailoring sizes to fit different regions. St Helens, Merseyside, saw sales swell by more than 500% as soon as the bigger sizes reached the rails. It's there in black and white, and read all over: we can't pay, won't pay, for high-class fashion and we'd rather stay in on the couch, getting fatter.

I go home to Wigan, where women, broad as houses, thick as thieves and, possibly, two short planks, lumber and sway under the weight of bags, jam-packed and stuffed plump with bargains. Red-faced, fingers bulging purple from carrier bag straps twisted knife-sharp, they tread the well-worn path from bus station to market and back again. In the market hall, the butchers wipe their meaty hands across their stripey aprons, bag up brawn and mince. Next door you can buy poor bens and cough candy by the quarter, by the ounce, whatever you can afford.

But all we get given up here is the scrag ends, the broken biscuits and the outsized slacks. The end-of-the line cosmetics in tan and pearly pinks, shimmering exotically beside the talc and the kirby grips. Small wonder you think we all look second-rate; we are the bargain basement of the nation, we get sent the offcuts. Therefore we shall remain here on our sofas (Brookside's on in five minutes), your plumper, less dapper cousins, until Marks and Spencer deign to show us naked, on a cliff-top, bellowing "I am northern".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Ex-footballer denies drug plot
fields.body:
Ex-footballer denies drug plot

The former Scottish international footballer Frank McAvennie denied conspiring to deal in more than £110,000 worth of ecstasy and amphetamines at Newcastle upon Tyne crown court yesterday.

Rhapsodies on blue

Christ Church College, Oxford, has launched a £1,000 competition, the Christopher Tower poetry prize, for 16- to 18-year-olds on the theme of blue. The poet laureate, Andrew Motion, will be among the judges.

BBC sorry for Duke 'Nazi' slur

The BBC has apologised to the Duke of Edinburgh after Mohamed Al Fayed described him as a Nazi during an interview on You Only Live Once. A palace spokeswoman said: "The duke fought in the navy against Nazi Germany and has the medals to prove it."

Eton rebuked over dog care

The Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles has advised Eton College to improve care of its dogs after a complaint to the RSPCA about their condition.

fields.headline: Web lines
fields.body:
The American success of www.iVillage.com and www.women.com could force existing British sites to sharpen their shopping-oriented content. Around 5m women regularly access the internet in Britain and women are set to overtake men as the prime users by next summer. While some 28% of women users use the internet to shop, it would be refreshing to see old and new sites also target women's minds.

Homeless and disadvantaged women are among the targets of a new government initiative to extend internet access. Tony Blair's launch this week of the UK online campaign will create 600 community-based computer centres in some of the country's poorest areas. More than 6,000 UK online centres are planned and will combine computer skills training with health and accommodation advice.

Fancy a trip to the theatre or a health spa treat but don't have anyone to go with? Then www.ladiesletsgoout.co.uk may have the solution. This online friend-finding service matches like-minded women looking for a platonic pal to share their hobbies, holidays and other interests.

F ans of the author Fay Weldon can bypass the book stores and log on to the internet for her latest novel, which is being published in weekly instalments on the government-to-citizen site www.YouGov.com. webTitle: 'The rules have relaxed since I arrived'

fields.headline: 'The rules have relaxed since I arrived'
fields.standfirst: The worker Indian software expert plugs gap in UK skills
fields.trailText: Raju Oak, 40, is in charge of customer relations management and e-business for Mastek UK, a software development firm in Bristol.
fields.body:
Raju Oak, 40, is in charge of customer relations management and e-business for Mastek UK, a software development firm in Bristol.

He moved from Bombay, India, just over four years ago and was followed two months later by his wife and son.

Mr Oak said he was employed in Britain to plug a shortfall in information technology and project management skills.

"There are fairly significant shortages in the UK in both these areas and there have been for some time," he said. "What the UK is excellent at is structuring businesses, but you need to deliver what you promise. And for that you need the people to build software.

"Where software development is concerned schooling and training in India focuses more on academic study, perhaps to the exclusion of other things, and enforces the kind of analytical thinking used in developing software. In British schools life skills are much more stressed.

"In the end I found it surprisingly easy to move to Bristol. All our institutions in India are modelled on a British way of life and when I arrived it was much more familiar than I thought it would be," he said.

"Also, in areas like IT, the profession is beginning to command a higher loyalty than one's nationality. And that's not just true of India, but the UK as well. People here are moving abroad too.

"The process is much easier now. Rules and regulations for foreign workers have relaxed considerably since I arrived. There used to be many more bureaucratic hurdles as well as the suspicious attitude of officials. Any migration request had to be justified at every step of the way.

"Today it is much easier to persuade people that you are adding value. It is partly a case of global companies needing to be mobile, the boundaries are coming down."

While Mr Oak and his family miss their network of friends in Bombay, they do not miss the noise and pollution levels or the extremities of poverty on the streets.

However, Mr Oak is concerned about the schooling of his son, Neeraj, 11. Although he fitted in well at primary level and has now won a scholarship to a public school, Mr Oak said academic standards are not as rigorous as those in India.

webTitle: Skills shortage breaks down an old taboo

fields.headline: Skills shortage breaks down an old taboo
fields.standfirst: Analysis Firms have been obliged to recruit abroad
fields.trailText: The call by the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, for a "market led" relaxation of immigration rules to plug Britain's skills gap breached a taboo that has gripped public life for 40 years. But ministers are far from alone in their conviction that the immigration debate has to be opened up. Pressure for change is growing from business in particular and a wider conviction that Britain will lose out unless restrictions are eased.
fields.body:
The call by the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, for a "market led" relaxation of immigration rules to plug Britain's skills gap breached a taboo that has gripped public life for 40 years. But ministers are far from alone in their conviction that the immigration debate has to be opened up. Pressure for change is growing from business in particular and a wider conviction that Britain will lose out unless restrictions are eased.

A combination of growing skilled labour shortages across the economy, an under-trained domestic workforce, the accelerating globalisation of the labour market and an ageing population has hammered home the need to open up.

While the need to recruit foreign teachers and nurses is largely the result of chronic underfunding and low esteem for public service work, private sector employers are increasingly looking abroad to fill skilled vacancies and ease the upward pressure on pay.

Nearly eight years of uninterrupted growth have created bottlenecks and shortages - less serious than in previous upturns, in the CBI's view, but serious none the less.

Computer and IT professionals are among those in greatest demand, but shortages are also cited in sales, catering, customer and financial services and construction.

One survey showed 20% of company vacancies unfilled due to a lack of skilled applicants and in London, where the problems are most acute, two thirds of firms say they cannot find skilled staff, compared with 15% 10 years ago.

Bill Maclachlan, manager of a small London electrical contracting firm, Mac Services, says he relies mainly on staff from South Africa, Australasia and eastern Europe.

But the greatest strain is expected to be in the areas of fastest moving technological change. Britain is expected to need around half a million extra workers with IT skills in the next 10 years and other countries will be fishing in the same pool.

Using foreign labour to fill the gaps in the market is nothing new and a large proportion of postwar immigration was organised by government to meet labour shortages in public services or industries. After a slump in the 1970s and 1980s, the numbers have again been picking up rapidly.

The annual number of work permits issued, the main method of legal entry for non-European Union skilled workers and professionals, rose to nearly 77,000 last year - from a low of around 15,000 in the early Thatcher years - which is roughly the level of the late 1960s.

They cover everyone from senior Japanese and US bankers being transferred from one part of their global corporate empires to another, to agency nurses. Most come from advanced industrial countries outside the EU, from which there are no restrictions.

But as the labour market has tightened, companies have become increasingly frustrated by the delays and bureaucracy of the overseas labour service in Sheffield, which issues the permits. The government is streamlining the system and testing amore liberal scheme to attract foreign entrepreneurs.

There is a patchwork of other schemes under which non-EU citizens can work in Britain. Around 40,000, mostly Australians and South Africans, do largely unskilled jobs under the Commonwealth working visit scheme; another allows 10,000 predominantly east Europeans to do seasonal agricultural work while many more are employed illegally; students have some opportunities to work; and asylum seekers can work after six months. Altogether there are nearly 1m foreign workers, including those from the EU.

But there are suspicions of racial bias in the discretionary decisions left to officials and anomalies are rampant. Highly paid chefs are allowed in under the work permit system, while Indian restaurateurs are unable to bring in staff from the subcontinent to keep family businesses going.

Two thousand qualified doctors struggling through the asylum system are unable to practise because they cannot afford the specialist language course, even though there is a serious shortage of home-grown doctors, who each cost £200,000 to train.

The obvious solution to skills shortages would appear to be to train more British workers. But Sarah Spencer of the Institute for Public Policy Research says that is unlikely to work because of the lead times involved, the speed of industrial change and the demographic pressure of an ageing population.

"Skills shortages are only part of the story," Susan Anderson of the CBI argues. "It is also about the creation of a mobile global workforce and it's as much about the UK sending people out as the other way round."

Ms Spencer hopes the government will take a lead in arguing the positive case for economic migrants and highlight, for example, the fact that they pay more in taxes than they claim in benefits. "Labour migration is the easier end of the debate. What we really need to do is rethink the immigration system as a whole."

webTitle: Market forces to determine migration policy

fields.headline: Market forces to determine migration policy
fields.standfirst: Work permits could depend on job offer 'at high level'
fields.trailText: The government is considering making immigration policy even more market-orientated by making a work permit dependent on a job offer "at sufficiently high level" rather than simply letting in people with skills in fields like IT.
fields.body:
The government is considering making immigration policy even more market-orientated by making a work permit dependent on a job offer "at sufficiently high level" rather than simply letting in people with skills in fields like IT.

The need to further streamline the system to meet the challenges of the globalised economy and an ageing home population was revealed yesterday by the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, as part of a Whitehall initiative to open a debate on immigration.

In a speech at the Institute for Public Policy Research think-tank in London she linked America's long economic boom to the 11m migrants admitted during the 90s and warned that Germany's break with tradition by offering citizenship to Indian IT specialists had not attracted the numbers expected.

"The market for skilled labour is a global market and not necessarily a buyer's market," said the minister, who noted that changes to immigration policy in such countries as Canada and Australia were also designed to stress flexible and transferable skills.

Though the government has already made it easier for people with skills, business experience and good ideas to enter Britain, ministers may now go further.

Mrs Roche said Britain could "make a permit contingent primarily on a job offer at a sufficiently high level, rather than seeking to identify employment sectors with shortages".

Britain could also follow the US, Mrs Roche suggested, in holding "programmes of induction and guidance. We could attach greater symbolic importance to the achievement of UK citizenship".

Mrs Roche, MP for Hornsey in north London and herself the descendant of Polish-Jewish migrants, was speaking with Tony Blair's blessing as ministers seek to change the suspicious public mood towards immigration this year.

Tabloid backed anger has been fuelled by the post-Kosovo wave of refugees and other recent arrivals from south and east Europe and beyond, including Romanian Gypsies and the Chinese stowaways found suffocated in a lorry at Dover. While insisting that genuine asylum seekers will always be welcome, ministers also want voters to grasp that, far from being a threat, "managed migration" in the economic sense has a long and fruitful history in Britain.

Mrs Roche cited Shami Ahmed, the founder of Joe Bloggs clothing company, and 200 Asian multimillionaires as examples of economic migrants - some refugees - who enriched themselves and the country.

Downing Street, which has shown a close interest in Mrs Roche's text, knows it is walking a tightrope. Yesterday the minister acknowledged that the high number of asylum seekers in the last year was "unfortunate" because it "skewed" the migration debate.

Mrs Roche said: "Asylum procedures are increasingly being misused by those who have no real fear of persecution. This degrades the integrity of the system and rewards the people traffickers.

"I fully understand public concern about the asylum system and about the wider threat to a properly regulated system of immigration control."

fields.headline: Ambushed officer faces court martial
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Sierra Leone
MoD news from Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The officer in charge of the British soldiers taken hostage in Sierra Leone six weeks ago faces court martial if he cannot provide an adequate explanation of why he allowed his group to be captured.
fields.body:
The officer in charge of the British soldiers taken hostage in Sierra Leone six weeks ago faces court martial if he cannot provide an adequate explanation of why he allowed his group to be captured.

The officer and five of his men were resting aboard a navy ship off the capital Freetown yesterday after their rescue by paratroopers on Sunday.

The MoD, which is anxious to avoid the embarrassment of a court martial if possible, insisted it was still in the dark about how the soldiers had been taken hostage by the undisciplined and barely trained West Side Boys. The death of the British paratrooper in the rescue operation adds to the seriousness of the inquiry.

An MoD official said: "Until we know what happened, we cannot say if any action will be taken."

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said: "Once we have been able properly to debrief all the hostages, we will find out precisely why it was that they came to be detained."

He added that the debriefing could result in new measures to ensure the safety of the 200 British soldiers who are based in Sierra Leone to help train the country's shattered army.

One possibility includes sending in British reinforcements. MoD sources suggested this was the stock reply to any question about troop deployment and that further increases were unlikely.

It is uncertain how long British forces will be involved in Sierra Leone. Mr Hoon said it could in theory be six weeks but Foreign Office sources indicated it could be years.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, dismissed Conservative calls for a British withdrawal. He said British troops were in Sierra Leone because "first, the people of Sierra Leone still live under threat of a brutal rebel force second, because the government of Sierra Leone is a democratically elected government and thirdly, because we are a leading member of the United Nations, we are committed to UN peacekeeping".

But the government is continuing to refuse to put the British force under the UN flag and is instead maintaining its separate identity and command. The MoD said this was because the British force was in Sierra Leone to train its army and that should not be confused with the UN's role as a peacekeeper.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, called for Britain to contribute a battalion of troops to the UN peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone, which is being upgraded from 13,500 to 20,000.

He said: "It is not the number of troops that matters, so much as the quality of the troops. That has been part of the failure of the UN effort -they have simply not had good enough troops to do the job."

The Conservative defence spokesman, Iain Duncan Smith, said that the British troops involved in training duties in Sierra Leone could not remain there without reinforcement.

He said: "We either now take the decision to withdraw British troops - which I would favour - and tell the UN to get on with the job they were told to do in the first place, or else we decide, if we put British troops in, they have got to be properly protected."

webTitle: Izzard makes a killing in Hollywood

fields.headline: Izzard makes a killing in Hollywood
fields.trailText: Eddie Izzard was the toast of Hollywood after winning two Emmys in the annual television awards ceremony in Los Angeles for his show Dressed To Kill. His victories came on a night of surprises with unfancied programmes picking up awards and shows with gay themes being honoured.
fields.body:
Eddie Izzard was the toast of Hollywood after winning two Emmys in the annual television awards ceremony in Los Angeles for his show Dressed To Kill. His victories came on a night of surprises with unfancied programmes picking up awards and shows with gay themes being honoured.

He won Emmys for writing the show and for his performance, beating American gag writing heavyweights such as fellow nominees on the Late Show With David Letterman and Late Night With Conan O'Brien, but was too busy working to pick up the award on Sunday night.

His show was filmed for American channel HBO at the Stage Door theatre in San Francisco in 1998, and his unique blend of rambling humour and transvestism has also played to sold out houses in New York and Los Angeles.

The White House-based drama series, The West Wing, picked up most awards. The series, which stars Martin Sheen as the liberal president and Rob Lowe, took a record nine awards, including best drama series. It surpassed the record of eight awards set by Hill Street Blues and equalled by ER.

The Sopranos, nominated in 18 categories, had to be content with James Gandolfini's solo effort which he attributed to the judges' "affinity for slightly overweight bald men".

Gandolfini, the star of The Sopranos, the acclaimed drama series about a New Jersey mob family, won the best actor award most critics believed should have been his last year.

Vanessa Redgrave won a best supporting role for her part in the lesbian love story, If These Walls Could Talk 2, which also starred Sharon Stone, Ellen DeGeneres and Chloe Sevigny. There was an emotional reception for Michael J Fox's best actor in a comedy series award. He left Spin City because of Parkinson's disease.

Bruce Willis picked up the best guest performance in a series for his role in Friends but the hit comedy programme, along with ER, Ally McBeal, Frasier and Sex in the City, was otherwise virtually ignored.

Jennifer Aniston had been tipped for best comedy actress but the award went to Megan Mullally for Will & Grace, the comedy about a gay man and a straight woman.

The BBC's prehistoric documentary series Walking With Dinosaurs was named best animated programme of more than 60 minutes and won technical awards for its visual effects and sound editing.

Gary Shandling, star of the Larry Sanders show, hosted the event and poked fun at the proliferation of "reality" shows such as Big Brother and Survivor which are currently eating up the ratings. "

"I think real people should not be on television," he said. "It's for special people like us, people who have trained and studied to appear real."

Traditionally the Emmy nominations were made by people who attended a special weekend screening which disqualified many people unable to attend due to work. As a result, those nominating tended to be from the elderly end of the industry who were not too busy to participate. This led to stagnation with the same programmes being nominated year after year. Under the new rules, members of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences could watch the shows on video.

webTitle: American Asians celebrate collapse of Los Alamos spy case

fields.headline: American Asians celebrate collapse of Los Alamos spy case
fields.trailText: A case which began 18 months ago amid spectacular claims that a Taiwan-born American scientist had passed the "crown jewels" of the US nuclear weapons programme to China ended in a humiliating collapse yesterday when the suspect, Wen Ho Lee, was freed by a New Mexico court after a plea bargain with federal prosecutors.
fields.body:
A case which began 18 months ago amid spectacular claims that a Taiwan-born American scientist had passed the "crown jewels" of the US nuclear weapons programme to China ended in a humiliating collapse yesterday when the suspect, Wen Ho Lee, was freed by a New Mexico court after a plea bargain with federal prosecutors.

Prosecutors, who had earlier abandoned all attempts to have Mr Lee tried for espionage, also dropped 58 of the 59 charges remaining against him, accepting in return a plea of guilty to a single charge of downloading classified material relating to his work at the Los Alamos nuclear laboratories on to a private computer.

Mr Lee, 60, was due to be freed by the court in Albuquerque. He was expected to be sentenced to the nine months he has already spent behind bars during the investigations into his case - most of it in solitary confinement.

fields.headline: Blair puts £1bn into net centres
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday extended his campaign to make Britain a leader in the internet revolution by promising a further £1bn to ensure all government services are online by 2005, and 6,000 online centres by 2002, to be placed in shopping centres, libraries, community centres and places of entertainment.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday extended his campaign to make Britain a leader in the internet revolution by promising a further £1bn to ensure all government services are online by 2005, and 6,000 online centres by 2002, to be placed in shopping centres, libraries, community centres and places of entertainment.

There will be an effort to put the centres in areas of economic deprivation to forestall the so-called digital divide, and they will have extended opening hours to enable people to learn IT skills or pursue interests and hobbies.

Speaking in Loughborough on a tour through the Midlands, the prime minister also announced a brand name - UK On-line - for the campaign.

fields.headline: Disabled girls secretly sterilised
fields.trailText: Fourteen young girls from a French home for people with learning disabilities have been sterilised without their knowledge over the past five years, a lawyer has claimed.
fields.body:
Fourteen young girls from a French home for people with learning disabilities have been sterilised without their knowledge over the past five years, a lawyer has claimed.

Acting for a local association for the mentally handicapped, the lawyer, Pierre Gonzales de Gaspard, yesterday filed a formal request for a criminal investigation with the Yonne district court in Sens, some 50 miles south-west of Paris.

"These girls form a captive target and are completely incapable of resisting those who have full authority over them," he said. "But they are not guinea pigs, or sex objects. It is imperative that these practices stop and that those responsible be punished."

The association, known by its initials ADHY, says it has conclusive evidence from a care assistant and at least one parent that hysterectomies were performed on the girls at five different hospitals in the region.

It said the girls were escorted to hospital by an unidentified nurse from the home, the Aid through Work Centre in Sens, and were never told the true purpose of the operations they underwent.

"We are not making these accusation lightly," ADHY chairman, Pierre Manoir, said. "We have evidence and witnesses and these people know that untrue testimony would make them liable to prosecution."

The director of the home, which allows men and women to mix freely and, according to French media reports, has in the past boasted of its "healthy lack of institutional restraints", declined all comment on the allegations.

But a local social services official, Marie-Chantal Aucouturier, appeared to admit they were well founded. "This case raises the very difficult question of the sexuality of the mentally handicapped," she said. "But such practices have now stopped."

Under French law, hysterectomies and vasectomies may be performed only in cases of medical necessity after thorough examination of the patient and consultation with them, their family or legal guardian, and their doctor.

But Nadine Diedrich, a research scientist and author of a 1998 study of the practice, said that while sterilisation of people with learning disabilities in France was not systematic, it was far more widespread than assumed.

"The sexual conduct of the mentally ill can be very disturbing," she said.

"That is why this practice exists. But no figures whatsoever are available."

webTitle: Berlusconi poses as new Italian PM

fields.headline: Berlusconi poses as new Italian PM
fields.trailText: Six years after his banishment to the wilderness, the Italian parliament returned from its summer holiday yesterday to find Silvio Berlusconi making a spectacular comeback as leader of the centre-right opposition.
fields.body:
Six years after his banishment to the wilderness, the Italian parliament returned from its summer holiday yesterday to find Silvio Berlusconi making a spectacular comeback as leader of the centre-right opposition.

Later this month he will try to topple the government and trigger a snap general election, which the polls say he will win.

He has mobilised his family, yacht and media empire for an American-style campaign of glamour and money.

Posters with his tanned, beaming face are appearing on billboards in advance of his attack on the government's budget, which may lead to a confidence vote.

Mr Berlusconi, 64, returned to Rome with 25 "recipes" for a better future devised with advisers at his Bermuda holiday home. He will board his yacht next weekend for a campaign cruise to signal the countdown to his restoration as prime minister, the job he lost in 1994 after seven tumultuous months.

His daughter Marina, 34, vice-president of his holding company Fininvest, has posed in a black bikini for the lifestyle magazine Oggi, which described her as a powerful businesswoman with a super-feminine physique.

Kristen Pazik, the girlfriend of his son Pier Silvio, posed nude for GQ magazine. She described her potential father-in-law as the most fascinating man in the world.

But Sergio Romano, a commentator tipped to be foreign minister in a Berlusconi cabinet, warned that flaunting success and beauty might alienate traditionalists. "For every vote he gains from the Bermuda villa image, he loses one," he said.

Mr Berlusconi, who owns AC Milan football club and whose family controls the private television network Mediaset, has shaken off most of the corruption allegations which dogged him through the 90s.

He launched a new era in Italian electioneering when he made a 37,000-tonne cruiser ship his Forza Italia party headquarters for last April's regional elections.

The nine-party government coalition, which includes Marxists, Greens, and former Christian Democrats, hopes to revive its popularity with a tax-cutting budget.

It is split on whether to dump the technocrat prime minister, Giuliano Amato. To counter Mr Berlusconi's charisma there is a growing clamour to install the telegenic mayor of Rome, Francesco Rutelli, who would be a fresh face untainted by corruption.

fields.headline: Dead lorry immigrants identified
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Police have identified the 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a lorry at Dover in June.
fields.body:
Police have identified the 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in the back of a lorry at Dover in June.

Kent detectives have worked with police in the southern province of Fujian, where most of the 54 men and four women who perished originated.

They showed photographs to families who believed they had lost relatives and then asked them to give blood samples which were compared with DNA samples taken from the dead.

A Kent police spokesman said: "The Chinese police and government have been very cooperative and a lot of people have come forward in China. People were desperate to find out whether their loved ones were involved."

The names of the dead are expected to be released after the detectives return to Britain this week.

Customs officers discovered the 58 dead, together with two survivors, when they opened a sealed refrigerator container in Dover on June 18. Twelve people are facing charges in connection with the deaths. A Dutch lorry driver, Perry Wacker, 32, has been charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and people smuggling offences.

You Yi, 38, a chef, and Ying Guo, 29, an interpreter, of South Woodford, east London, are jointly charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK. Nine people are also in custody in the Netherlands charged with people smuggling.

webTitle: In 1965 he presided over a racist tragedy.  Today he may be re-elected for the 10th time

fields.headline: In 1965 he presided over a racist tragedy.  Today he may be re-elected for the 10th time
fields.trailText: It was 35 years ago that civil rights marchers were attacked by state troopers in Selma as they demonstrated for the rights of black people to vote. The mayor then was a skinny young appliance salesman with a crewcut called Joe Smitherman who referred to the leader of the marchers as "Martin Luther Coon". Today the same Joe Smitherman is fighting to hold onto his office in the face of a challenge that would see the first black mayor of the city that stands as a landmark in the history of the civil rights movement.
fields.body:
It was 35 years ago that civil rights marchers were attacked by state troopers in Selma as they demonstrated for the rights of black people to vote. The mayor then was a skinny young appliance salesman with a crewcut called Joe Smitherman who referred to the leader of the marchers as "Martin Luther Coon". Today the same Joe Smitherman is fighting to hold onto his office in the face of a challenge that would see the first black mayor of the city that stands as a landmark in the history of the civil rights movement.

Claims of electoral fraud and intimidation, and allegations that vehicles belonging to campaigners against Smitherman have been firebombed, have brought veteran civil rights campaigners from across the country and US Justice Department officials to this city of 24,000 people. 'Joe's Gotta Go', is the slogan of a volunteer army of students and activists who have been declared unwelcome guests in the local press just as they were 35 years ago. This weekend Martin Luther King III and veteran civil rights leader the Reverend Fred Shuttlesworth were in town to campaign. Last week it was hip-hop stars from New Orleans trying to persuade teenagers to vote for the first time.

If Smitherman, now 70, wins, it will be his 10th victory, one that will act as a reminder that some things have not changed since the violence of what was known as bloody Sunday in 1965 when state troopers tear-gassed and cracked the heads of the 600 black and white marchers who sought to cross the Pettus Bridge over the Alabama River and challenge Governor George Wallace and his battle cry of "segregation forever".

The violence led to the legendary Selma-Montgomery march and to the Voters Rights Act pushed through in 1965 by President Lyndon Johnson as America reacted in horror to the scenes of violence and bigotry and the four attendant killings by Klansmen, troopers and local racists.

Selma has been a black majority city since 1984 and blacks now make up 65% of the 14,000 registered voters but Smitherman has remained in office. In the primary last month he came in ahead of his main challenger, black businessman James Perkins Jnr, with 4,352 votes to 4,076. Third place went to another black candidate, attorney and iman Yusuf Salaam. Today the voters make their final decision.

Smitherman, now heavier and white-haired and living alone with two cats in a house rented from his lawyer daughter, is angry about the influx of outsiders and claims that he has been misrepresented as a bigot for years. His son Steve, a property developer and former policeman who is holding the fort at the Smitherman campaign headquarters, said that he had met the Reverend Martin Luther King as a boy. "He was a well-spoken gentleman, a lot different from what we're running against this time."

Violence

His father's oft-quoted remark, he said, was a slip of the tongue which happened because there was at the time a white council man named Martin Coon. "The press has played it into the ground ever since," said Smitherman.

Race, he said, was no longer the main issue and he had voted for a black council clerk against two white candidates. As for the alleged car-bombing of the vehicles of the 'Joe's Gotta Go' campaign, he believed that it was either an accident or had been carried out deliberately to win sympathy for Perkins and generate publicity. Perkins supporters say this is the classic explanation of any acts of violence throughout the civil rights movement.

Smitherman's supporters point to a showdown with the Ku Klux Klan whom he told to get out of town when they showed up at city hall in 1979. His opponents remember him barricading the entrance to the federal poverty programme in 1970 because he said it discriminated against whites. Townsend Davis in his history of the civil rights movement, Weary Feet, Rested Souls, acknowledges that Smitherman has been "chameleonlike" on racial issues and "the themes of reconciliation and repentance" have become standard in his speeches.

James Perkins, who was a schoolboy during the 1965 marches - his mother was a nurse who patched up the marchers - is suffering from 'politician's voice' but is able to articulate why he believes his third tilt at the Smitherman crown will be decisive and why it deserves to be.

"A lot has changed here but not for the better," he said, sitting in his back yard as campaigners stuffed envelopes. "I was in the first fully integrated classes during the desegregation era and they were 50/50 black and white. Now they are 90% black because all the whites have left the public school system." Residential areas were still largely, if unofficially, segregated except in the downtown area, he said.

Nowhere in the civil rights iconography holds a higher place than the Pettus Bridge, and at a 'Joe's Gotta Go' rally there on a hot afternoon there are people who remember vividly the crack of billy-club on skull and the whiff of teargas as the state troopers sang a jeering 'Bye, Bye Blackbird' while driving the marchers back, leaving 70 in hospital.

Lily Brown, aged 69, from Birmingham, was kicked by a police horse during the rampage and suffered a blood clot. She is back on the bridge today. "Everything changed but nothing changed," she said. "I can't for the life of me understand why they still have the man who oppressed us as mayor."

Diane Moton has a special reason to remember the final march to Montgomery. Her brother Leroy Moton, a young volunteer with the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, was in a car on his way back from Montgomery with a white activist from Detroit, Viola Liuzzo, when they were spotted by armed Klansmen and pursued along Highway 80 at 100 miles an hour. Liuzzo was shot and killed and her brother survived by playing dead.

"I thought I was going to die here," she said, explaining why she was returning to campaign after many years away.

Joanne Bland, who founded the National Voting Rights Museum in the centre of town, blamed "intimidation and a sense of hopelessness over the years" as the reasons why Smitherman was still in office. The museum records the blunter times when signs stated: "We serve colored. Carry out only."

This has been the most bitterly fought election campaign that anyone can remember, not least because of accusations of betrayals against black people who are backing Smitherman. The Smitherman camp are particularly pleased that Yusuf Salaam is telling his supporters not to back Perkins who he feels has been disrespectful towards Muslims, a charge Perkins denies. There are also claims by the Perkins camp that Smitherman's supporters are bamboozling old people into signing over their absentee ballots.

Disillusioned

As the bridge rally ends, there is activity in the Smitherman headquarters where almost all the afternoon's campaigners are black. One of them, Timfreit Drane, said that he had previously campaigned for Perkins but was now disillusioned. "My interest is the betterment of my city. Perkins is supposed to be a businessman [in computer technology] but not one of his businesses are in operation," he said.

On the eve of the election, the strains of Lift Every Voice and Sing in Selma's Tabernacle baptist church drown out the distance wail of the freight train and the fluttering of hundreds of fans. The pastor, Dr Aaron Dobynes, likens the moment to the sighting of the Promised Land: "I feel the same sense of anticipation as the people leaving Egypt ...we want to thank God for the victory that will be ours."

When the Tabernacle was first built in 1922 the architect was told that it was unacceptable that a black church should open onto Selma's main street. The instruction was ignored. As the rally ended last night the mainly black congregation spilled out onto the main street. Today they will discover whether another long link with the past has finally been broken.

The pastor, Dr Aaron Dobynes, likens the moment to the sighting of the Promised Land: "I feel the same sense of anticipation as the people leaving Egypt ...we want to thank God for the victory that will be ours." When the Tabernacle was first built in 1922 the architect was told that it was unacceptable that a black church should open onto Selma's main street. The instruction was ignored. As the rally ended last night the mainly black congregation spilled out onto the main street. Today they will discover whether another long link with the past has finally been broken.

fields.standfirst: Set designer lifts top portrait prize
fields.trailText: A celebrated set designer who worked with the late Sir Kenneth MacMillan has won one of the richest painting prizes in the country for a portrait of the legendary choreographer. Yolanda Sonnabend - who is better known for her ballet and theatre work - picked up the £20,000 Garrick/Milne prize for her low-key but subtle picture of MacMillan at work. He died in 1992   backstage at the Royal Opera House, an exit which was seen as fitting for a man who had revolutionised Covent Garden over four decades.
fields.body:
A celebrated set designer who worked with the late Sir Kenneth MacMillan has won one of the richest painting prizes in the country for a portrait of the legendary choreographer. Yolanda Sonnabend - who is better known for her ballet and theatre work - picked up the £20,000 Garrick/Milne prize for her low-key but subtle picture of MacMillan at work. He died in 1992 backstage at the Royal Opera House, an exit which was seen as fitting for a man who had revolutionised Covent Garden over four decades.

The new prize, which comes out of the bequest that the creator of Winnie the Pooh, AA Milne, left to his London club the Garrick, is intended to revive theatrical portraiture.

Zimbabwe-born Sonnabend, who worked with MacMillan on Requiem Valley of Shadow and My Brother My Sister, is probably better known for her theatre designs for the Royal Shakespeare Company than her portrait painting. She is now working on a new Royal Ballet revival of Swan Lake and the English National Ballet's Rite of Spring.

Jim Russell picked up the £7,000 second prize for his study of the American playwright Arthur Miller at the Young Vic, while Tom Coates came third with his glimpse of less glamorous backstage life in Wig Preparation.

fields.headline: Woman, 35, 'haunted by rape ordeal'
fields.trailText: A woman told yesterday how she has been haunted by a rape ordeal every day for 16 years. Known only as Miss N for legal reasons, the woman claimed she was attacked by Nicholas Edwards when she was a 19-year-old model and dancer.
fields.body:
A woman told yesterday how she has been haunted by a rape ordeal every day for 16 years. Known only as Miss N for legal reasons, the woman claimed she was attacked by Nicholas Edwards when she was a 19-year-old model and dancer.

She told a jury at the Old Bailey she became pregnant after Edwards called at her home in Buckinghamshire one night in April 1984 and demanded sex.

The woman, now 35, sobbed as she denied suggestions that she agreed to sleep with Edwards.

Edwards, 39, an engineering welder, of Sydenham, south-east London, denies raping a 23-year-old mother, Miss D, in his flat in 1998.

But Miss N and four other women are giving evidence in court in an unusual legal move because the prosecution alleges that their experiences with Edwards bear "striking similarities".

The women in each alleged incident say Edwards raped them, but he says they were willing sexual partners.

Later, Miss S told the court that Edwards raped her in 1985 when she was 17. Miss S confirmed that Edwards had been convicted at Reading crown court of raping her. Earlier Miss N confirmed that Edwards had been cleared of rape in her case. The trial continues today.

fields.trailText: A toyshop chain will shut its tills every Tuesday morning from today to allow children to play with its merchandise for free.
fields.body:
A toyshop chain will shut its tills every Tuesday morning from today to allow children to play with its merchandise for free.

The Early Learning Centre, with 220 stores around the UK, has teamed with the Pre-School Learning Alliance to run free weekly play sessions from 9.30am until 11am.

With the alliance's help, the firm has designed themed activity sessions, allowing pre-school children to learn as they play.

The firm said it had held a successful trial during which its staff stopped selling to help parents and children. The fact that staff cleared up also proved popular with parents in the trial.

webTitle: Jail halts killer's job with elderly

fields.headline: Jail halts killer's job with elderly
fields.trailText: A murderer serving life for battering a pensioner to death with a hammer has been removed from rehabilitation work in an old people's home, the Home Office said yesterday.
fields.body:
A murderer serving life for battering a pensioner to death with a hammer has been removed from rehabilitation work in an old people's home, the Home Office said yesterday.

The move followed criticism from Age Concern and Victim Support, but was yesterday described by his wife as "absolutely ridiculous".

Brian Parsons, 40, is serving life in Ford open prison, near Arundel, West Sussex, for the 1987 murder of Ivy Batten, 84, at her home in Shute Bottom, Devon.

Parsons was due yesterday to start work at a home near the prison as part of his rehabilitation, carrying out odd jobs. But when news of the placement emerged it was criticised as "insensitive" by a Devon pensioners' group, and Age Concern believed the prison authorities should reconsider.

A prison service spokesman said that Parsons, from Colyton, Devon, would be found other outside work.

webTitle: School resource: how tanker spills harm the environment

fields.headline: Oil on troubled waters
fields.standfirst: John Crace examines how tanker spills harm the environment, and what can be done to prevent them
fields.trailText: John Crace examines how tanker spills harm the environment, and what can be done to prevent them
fields.body:
Oil spills from supertankers receive a lot of publicity and a single incident can have a significant, and in some cases catastrophic, impact on both the local environment and the local economy. But oil spills are responsible for only a small proportion of oil in the sea. According to the United Nations Environment Programme (Unep), of the millions of tonnes of oil discharged into the sea, ships release only about half and much of this is deliberately flushed into the sea as tankers clean their tanks. The rest of the oil comes from routine discharges from land-based industrial plant.

Marine environment

Oil has been proved to affect the reproduction and physiology of fish, shellfish and plankton. However, no two oil spills produce identical effects on the environment and recovery rates may vary from a matter of weeks to more than 10 years. The key factor determining how quickly the environment can recover is the type of oil and the quantities spilt. Oil is composed of hundreds of compounds, some of which are toxic and may cause cancer, and it can be broadly divided into light crudes, which disperse easily, and heavy crudes, which form thick slicks. Light crudes may disappear more quickly from the surface, but their toxicity may last longer. There is no clear correlation between the size of a spill and the extent of the damage. Other factors that influence the environmental impact are whether dispersants are used, whether the sea is rough, the temperature of the water, the presence of bacteria that can digest the oil, whether the shore line is rocky or sandy and the mix of species in the area of the spill.

Incidents

The National Centre for Scientific Research in France has estimated that a shipping incident occurs every two to three days worldwide, and between 1992 and 1999 the UK Marine Accident Investigation Branch recorded 148 tanker accidents. Between 1992 and 1999, the top five foreign flags involved in tanker accidents were the Bahamas, Norway, Gibraltar, Liberia and Malta. The two worst incidents to affect the UK in the last decade have been the Braer in 1993, when 84,500 tonnes of light crude was spilt off the Shetland Islands and the Sea Empress in 1996, when 130,000 tonnes of Forties crude was spilt off the Pembrokeshire coast.

Safeguards

Environmental groups believe that all new tankers should be built to a minimum design/construction standard and that all existing ships should be updated to these standards as soon as possible. They also want action taken to improve ship maintenance and crew training and believe all vessels passing through narrow, busy, dangerous or environmentally sensitive areas should be subject to compulsory pilotage.

Oil spill online

The WWF and Dynamic Distance Learning will be running an online debate for school children on how an oil spill might affect a stretch of coastline. During this internet-based project, children will be able to debate the issues with their peers and discuss their views with experts from a variety of conservation, government and maritime agencies, as well as with schools from other countries. Schools or individuals wishing to take part in the debate, which will take place between November 6 and 17, should log on to www.wwflearning.co.uk to register.

fields.headline: Submarine pair deny damage
fields.trailText: Two protesters swam 150 metres in wetsuits to a Trident nuclear submarine and smashed equipment with a hammer to gain publicity for their cause, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Two protesters swam 150 metres in wetsuits to a Trident nuclear submarine and smashed equipment with a hammer to gain publicity for their cause, a court heard yesterday.

Rachel Wenham, 28, from Leeds, and Rosie James, 25, from London, who are activists from the nuclear disarmament group, Trident Ploughshares, hung a banner saying "women want peace" from the conning tower of HMS Vengeance which was berthed at Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, in February last year, Dennis Watson, prosecuting, told Manchester crown court.

They took a hammer to testing equipment then spray painted "Peace, no more death" and "Hiroshima" slogans on the side of the submarine which was designed to carry one quarter of Britain's nuclear arsenal.

Both women denied two charges each of causing criminal damage.

Mr Watson said that damage to "sophisticated and purpose built" equipment would cost thousands of pounds to repair.

He added that the women surrendered when they were noticed by security guards. "Part of their purpose was to be apprehended. They were heard to say that they had missed the newspapers." He said this referred to the publicity they sought.

The court heard that Ms Wenham said that she was acting to prevent a crime because she believed the nuclear programme was illegal. She claimed she was justified under international law.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: German
fields.trailText: Recommended German language and culture websites
fields.body:
Oskar's youth magazine

*****

Aimed at: teenagers and university students

Fun, enthusiastic and colourful English-language magazine on the country trendily referred to as "D-land" throughout. There are interesting and enthusiastic articles on a range of subjects from where to crash cheaply in Berlin to German hip-hop and student-exchange experiences.

The German way

****

Aimed at: everyone

Based around Hyde Flippo's language course, this site offers large sections of his book (with sound) as well as biographies of famous Germans, Austrians and Swiss, all with excellent links.

BBC Education

****

Aimed at: everyone

Hundreds of links from this comprehensive site, with sections on GCSE revision (including scoreable tests), business German and plenty of fun activities and tests, some requiring RealPlayer to access sound.

Teaching materials

***

Aimed at: primary teachers

The National Advisory Centre on Early Language Learning provides detailed descriptions of well-selected primary-age learning materials, with links to publishers.

Pronunciation guide

****

Aimed at: everyone

Gary Smith's small but thorough site specialises in the pronunciation of all the main sounds in German, with extra tips on spelling. Visitors will need RealPlayer to hear the examples of words containing each sound.

German culture

***

Aimed at: everyone

A slightly chaotic site in English on a range of topics from traditions to "rules" on how to behave when you arrive abroad. Despite its quirkiness, discussion forums and a vast range of links make this site worth a visit.

Handbook of grammar

***

Aimed at: everyone

This site offers a clear grammar guide with plenty of examples and practical colour-coding. Though at present it is still being written, in time it should prove of great use to students.

German for Travellers

****

Aimed at: tourists

Visit this site before you go on holiday to learn basic vocabulary. Each word can be listened to before you test yourself with the user-friendly quizzes.

Nicht nur für Kinder

**

Aimed at: everyone

As the site's name warns us, this certainly is "not just for kids". Browse through the fairy tales, web magazines, handicraft instructions, games, songs etc. The idea is to learn German the way German children do, but some more basic-level German might be more useful for younger learners.

Germany online

*****

Aimed at: everyone

Hi-tech graphics and high-quality information. There is news on the latest in German culture and business, students and scholars, politics and more, with access to film and video catalogues, online radio programmes and press releases.

You can find more German sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Getting to know you
fields.standfirst: A class full of new faces? I'm sure they'd love to tell you all about themselves
fields.trailText: A class full of new faces? I'm sure they'd love to tell you all about themselves
fields.body:
It's the start of a new term. What better way to open than with something every child in the classroom is an expert in: themselves. Autobiographical work serves both as a reassuring launch pad for students and as an ideal means for teachers to get a sense of the personalities behind the new names in their registers.

The questionnaire

Capitalise on pupils' familiarity with surveys to set them one of your own. Indicate you want the answers to be as full as possible. Use them as a prompt for a spirited classroom discussion. The personality quiz can help to get students using their senses and psychology in their writing. It may also provide a way into some literary discussions and the early stages of abstract thought about language. Responses seem to be more spontaneous if the list is kept fairly loose.

1. What is the best thing about you?

2. Which bit of your character would you most like to change?

3. If you had £1 what would you do with it?

4. Describe something that makes you angry.

5. What is your favourite smell?

6. Other than music, what is your favourite sound?

7. What is your favourite word? It can be one you just like the sound of.

8. If you awoke from uneasy dream and found yourself transformed into something, what would it be?

9. What things make you worry?

10. What talent or skill would you most like? What first step could you take to acquiring this ability?

11. What is the first thing you see when you wake up in the morning?

12. What is the first thing you would rather see when you wake up in the morning?

13. What can you see from your bedroom window?

14. What is the second sound you hear in the morning?

15. What living thing would you least like to find under your bed?

16. What character from a story would you like to meet and why?

17. What film would you most like to have acted in? Why?

18. What part of adult life are you looking forward to the most?

19. What part of adult life are you least looking forward to?

20. Look back at your answer to question number 13. If you were transformed into this thing - how would you get out of bed?

21.In a recent Western, the Native Americans explain how they give people names that suit their characters. Someone ends up being called "Dances With Wolves" because that is something that happens to him. What would your Native American name be? (It can be a whole sentence long if necessary.)

22. What do you know now that you wish you had known when you were six?

23. What is your favourite meal of the day? Why?

24. When have you felt proudest of yourself?

25. What three objects (not photographs) would you take to a desert island to remind you of home or your family?

Finally: Choose three of the answers you have given that you would like to explain most to the class. Why did you choose them?

This will keep a class absorbed for an entire lesson and is an ideal jumping-off point for written work. Students can be asked to develop any answers they choose into a longer response. They can also return to the survey and plunder it for ideas for subsequent work such as creating letters introducing themselves, describing their typical day or writing acrostics based on their names.

Other tried and tested personal and autobiographical work includes the following:

Daydreams

Use this formula: "Mr (teacher's name) thinks I'm learning the difference between a noun and a verb, but NO! I'm . . .

Students work through their new teachers and subjects, contrasting the dullest of tasks with the riches of their imagination. They can vary the "contradiction phrases" - "think again... fat chance... dream on". The work creates splendid poems and introduces the idea of antithesis - a great box to be able to tick on literacy strategy sheet.

My room

Pupils' own experiences are the most fruitful source for their writing. By observing what they take for granted, the world around them can be transformed. What do their rooms mean to them? Which object or picture brings them the greatest pleasure or brings back the most memories? What would it be like to return to their room as an adult and find it perfectly preserved?

Vote for Me

Prepare a sheet with that logo, an obvious space for a picture and ruled lines for writing. Pupils must design their own mini-poster including a self-portrait and a full explanation of what makes them special. This is great for display - your next lesson should start with everyone hunting for their poster on the classroom walls. Some of the bizarre images will fix pupils indelibly in your mind.

According to Ross, aged 11: "No one can get into our world. It has a wall 20 feet high, and adults have only five-foot ladders." Autobiographical work early on is one way of finding an extension to the ladder long enough to give you a view over the wall.

Curriculum relevance: year 6 and 7, key stage 2 and 3 English. In drama, the questionnaire could be used as research before students interview one another. It could be a stimulus in tutor periods and in early PSHE sessions. It is also a great cover lesson.

Autobiographical work early on is one way of finding an extension to the ladder long enough to give you a view over the wall. Curriculum relevance: year 6 and 7, key stage 2 and 3 English. In drama, the questionnaire could be used as research before students interview one another. It could be a stimulus in tutor periods and in early PSHE sessions. It is also a great cover lesson.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Honesty hurts | Gap years | Ready and willing | Rewriting history | Paper teachers | What do they think? | Part-time problems
fields.body:
Honesty hurts

Many academics and university administrators will be appalled at the decision of the Higher Education Funding Council that there will be no formal investigation of the "inaccurate" submission to the 1996 Research Assessment Exercise by the Department of East Asian Studies at Sheffield University (Bright Sparks, Education, September 5). In effect more deserving departments at other universities have been deprived of the £900,000 of public funding which has gone to the perpetrators.

That a former member of one of the assessment panels believes the case to be "one of hundreds" indicates that a less-than-scrupulous minority amongst vice-chancellors and heads of department already treats the exercise less as a measure of the quality of research than as an opportunity for its smoke-and-mirrors inflation. This tendency can only be encouraged by a failure to investigate such abuses as come to light.

Honesty in the reporting of research, as in its performance, may be its own reward, but it would also be prudent to remove what amounts to a tax upon it.

Peter Armstrong
Professor of Management
Keele University

Gap years

Your article on the Mindset List (Mind the gap, Higher, September 5) was great fun. In about 1990, in a lecture on energy and environmental policy, I asked my students to recall the Yom Kippur War. Blank incomprehension. Then, from one student: "Bob, we were three!"

Dr Robert Lowe
Leeds Metropolitan University

Ready and willing

Yesterday I was appalled to note that delegates from several London boroughs were "obliged" to fly to Australia to seek out recruits, and that a cash incentive is being offered for trainees in the teaching profession (Shortage of teachers "papered over", Guardian, September 6). But where are all these vacancies?

I am a modern-languages teacher with over 16 years' experience. Having taken a year out when we moved house, I spent the next two years applying for countless jobs, before finally giving up. Most of my applications were not even acknowledged. I was only granted one interview - at an independent school! The implications are that schools cannot afford to employ experienced staff as they are too expensive, that headteachers prefer NQTs. This being the case, how can they afford to pay cash incentives to recruit new trainees or send headteachers to Australia? Is it the end of the line for experienced (expensive) teachers?

Margaret Allen
965782N@knotes.kodak.com

Rewriting history

With regard to your short piece, History is bunk (Higher, September 5), and your concern over facts, you say the journal I co-edit, Rethinking History: The Journal of Theory and Practice, allows "historians to reinterpret history without the inconvenience of facts".

Permit me to say that I rather concerned about your attitude toward facts. First, I am not sure I said precisely what you quote me as saying. Second, neither I, nor my co-editor nor subscribers would be inconvenienced by facts.

The point of Rethinking History: The Journal of Theory and Practice, is not that facts "are a bad thing" but that, if history is a narrative-linguistic cultural practice as much as it is an empirical-analytical one, then historians should have the opportunity to examine the consequences for their discipline.

Among those consequences is a questioning of a belief in naive empiricism - which is not quite the same as history without facts. I suspect that a serious and scholarly approach to the nature of historical reality and its narration would not make such good copy for you.

Oh, by the way: if you are so keen to defend facts, then you might begin by spelling my name properly - it is Alun, not Alan.

Alun Munslow
Professor of history and historical theory
Department of history and politics, Staffordshire University

Paper teachers

It is misleading to equate membership of the ILT with having a teaching qualification, other than in a nominal sense, as Francis Beckett appears to do (You are in my sight, Higher, September 5).

Membership of the ILT does not depend on having your teaching observed and assessed by experienced and respected practitioners in the same field. As far I can see, what you have to do is show that you can write about your teaching using the fashionable jargon of the day. Your written submission may then be assessed by people who have no experience of your particular discipline.

It is as though you could get a driving licence by writing about your approach to the task of driving a car and then having this judged by tram drivers.

Alan Slomson
Leeds

What do they think?

Theresa Crossley (Letters, September 5) is quite right that the Curriculum 2000 reforms have been implemented without consulting the young people who will be affected this year.

She, and others, may be interested to know that there is an Institute of Education/Nuffield Foundation research project that is investigating these reforms.

As part of the project we have interviewed 240 students in 40 schools. Most students are positive about the extra choice and flexibility but are concerned about the extra workload and the extra set of exams. For more information on our research, visit our website via: www.ioe.ac.uk/lll/nuffield.htm or e-mail me at c.savory@ioe.ac.uk

Chris Savory
Institute of Education, London

Part-time problems

Caroline Evans (Letters, September 5) is annoyed that she can't do a modular or part-time PGCE course. The TTA is keen on this model as a way of attracting people like her into the profession. Unfortunately, schools are not keen, and since two-thirds of any PGCE course takes place in schools, their views have to be taken into account.

Rob Spence
Department of English
Edge Hill College of Higher Education, Ormskirk

fields.headline: Spelling
fields.trailText: Websites to help you spell well
fields.body:
The Guardian has a slightly dubious - and mostly unjustified - reputation for sloppy spelling. In reality, as the "Grauniad" legend shows, typos and true spelling mistakes are very different sins. Leaving out the odd letter in an email is more likely to be due to haste than ignorance.

Poor spelling can be a sign of dyslexia - but it is far from the only symptom (see www.bda-dyslexia.org.uk for some of the others). Mark Twain blamed it on the non-phonetic (or "non-fonetic", as he put it) nature of English, and believed that it made it harder for immigrants to the US to obtain citizenship. He even appealed for the Associated Press to adopt a phonetic spelling system (www.marktwain.about.com).

At the Simplified Spelling Society's site (www.les.aston.ac.uk) you can download programs to convert traditional spellings to reformed versions. Sadly, the organisations cannot agree on a single system - not least because dialects and accents would render any attempt at standardisation impossible.

One self-confessed "bad speller" would like to see pronunciation follow spelling, rather than vice versa: "I can only spell 'anemone' because my biology teacher would always say it exactly like that... when I write it, it is an-e-mone, not an-em-on-ee."

"Mostly," writes another poor speller, "it was boring. At school I had to learn lists of words that I was tested on." Yet this approach, which David Blunkett's recent list of 600 recommended spellings for 11-year-olds seems likely to encourage, is not the only way to tackle the problem. As the BBC's spelling resource (www.bbc.co.uk/education) and the Guardian's learn.co.uk site show, strategies for "understanding" the structure and sounds of words do exist. The BBC encourages children's confidence by employing Shakespeare, a notoriously inconsistent speller, as its guide.

The Basic Skills Agency (www.basic-skills.co.uk) can help those with poor spelling.

 The list of 600 recommended spellings can be found at: www.educationunlimited.co.uk

The Guardian's education site, Education Unlimited, is looking for website reviewers to help expand its Netclass section. If you have expertise in a subject (or level) and experience of the national curriculum, or teach in an FE college, email: editor@educationunlimited.co.uk before September 22.

webTitle: Furthermore: the phases of holiday withdrawal

fields.headline: Furthermore
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  is moving through the phases of holiday withdrawal
fields.trailText: After a summer break spent catching up on the latest John Grisham novel you can drift through a few days of enrolment miasma in a trance-like state. I am reliably informed that the term for this state is Post Vacation Euphoria.
fields.body:
After a summer break spent catching up on the latest John Grisham novel you can drift through a few days of enrolment miasma in a trance-like state. I am reliably informed that the term for this state is Post Vacation Euphoria.

Oh bugger it! Just writing this down has made me lose mine. I'm out of the Euphoric stage already and into the next stage, Grim Reality Disorder. I know all these terms because my mate Colin from maths came across them on the internet. The worst stage, according to him, is the Chronic Regressive Anti-establishment Phase. Colin tells me it goes by the acronym CRAP.

"After a week back here you realise the accommodation's crap, this year's new and expensively designed college logo is crap, you've had enough crap from your Dean of Studies and you've got a bloody crap timetable to look forward to," he sighed, noisily turning the jobs pages in Guardian Education.

People walk more slowly at the beginning of term. It is something they have learned to do over August. They have lingered over buying a hand-thrown pot from an Aegean artisan or cruised with the air conditioning set high down some road in Florida.

And then people speed up. They realise they are back at work. And they can't do anything about it. But before they do, they like to offload their summer experiences onto someone else. There is a lot to be said for the social niceties of swapping tales of holiday adventure. But it can be difficult for the unwary recipient.

For example, I am the departmental "Buddy" to a newly qualified lecturer who has been fortunate enough to land an attractive part-time temporary post until at least Christmas. Damien is so grateful for this sudden start to his career that he keeps shaking people's hands over-effusively whenever I introduce him to someone new.

Having left Damien momentarily alone outside the college Non-Technical Supplies Welcome Centre while I popped in to put my name down on the waiting list for some re-cycled Blu-Tack, I returned to find him in conversation with Sigourney from Physics.

"And then we found this fantastic beach near Trondheim," she enthused. Damien kept nodding his head and smiling. I made a mental note to tactfully advise him on his use of body language, especially with the ebullient Sigourney. Someone told me that she had six boxes of slides in her pigeon hole. Say the wrong thing or nod at the wrong moment and Damien could have been in for a lengthy discourse on the Norwegian fishing industry.

And when the animated off-loading of travellers' tales subsides, it is collegiate business as usual. There are always those who are quick to point out that they spent bloody August in college sorting out the computer network or processing applications. As squirrels with nuts we retreat to our corners to start storing up our anxieties for the long academic winter.

I think my record for Post Holiday Euphoria is three and a half days. Yet again I came nowhere near beating it this year.

webTitle: Writer  Catherine Moye tries re-learning the parts of speech

fields.headline: It's a noun!
fields.standfirst: Writer  Catherine Moye has another bash at learning the parts of speech
fields.trailText: Writer Catherine Moye has another bash at learning the parts of speech
fields.body:
I never dreamed it would come to this. To think those years spent begging my mother for a sick note - turning in deathbed performances worthy of the Royal Opera House or, if that failed, playing truant in the park - had all been for naught. Not only was I returning to school 15 years after I'd left, I was actually paying for it.

What dip in my fortunes, what breakdown in my mental health could have bought me to such a nadir in life?

I left school vowing never to return. George Bernard Shaw echoed my sentiments when he declared, "the only time my education was interrupted was when I went to school."

As a self-educator, my expertise was affirmed by the system. I passed my English Literature O-level without troubling to read the books. Instead I saw the movie versions of The Great Gatsby, Far From the Madding Crowd and Romeo and Juliet - owing more to Mia Farrow, Robert Redford, Julie Christie and Alan Bates for my B grade pass than to Shakespeare, Thomas Hardy and Scott Fitzgerald.

Bluffing my way through English literature O-level affected my future fortunes for good and bad. On the one hand it gave me the confidence to write on any subject, however limited my understanding, on the other, it fostered a paranoia that sooner or later I would be exposed for the impostor I was.

For the last 10 years I have been earning my living as a writer without being able to distinguish a noun from a verb, an adjective from an adverb - a bit like becoming a nun without reading the New Testament first.

But editing my own work, trying to make it "sound right", has cost me a fortune in cranial osteopathy and the occasional trip to a floatation tank.

Newspaper subeditors, their foreheads prematurely furrowed in exasperation over my copy would ring and implore: "What, exactly do you mean by this?" then read out sentences devoid of punctuation and sense.

I finally conceded that I had to go back to ABC, and picked up a copy of my Adult Education Institute's, prospectus. There it was: Brush up your Grammar.

I signed up and discovered impostors like myself are running the whole country - publishers, doctors, script editors and even authors of government policy documents. All 15 of us used the language on a daily basis and none of us knew the principles that lay behind it.

By week three we were all perfect pupils. In that respect it was nothing like school. Adolescence, whose unruly growth is upward and outward, makes it agonisingly painful for some of us to restrict our minds to formal learning. But as an adult there is a complete change in the equation. Following years of chaotic experiences in every walk of life, the mind is left so uncertain and full of superfluous information that it comes as a great relief to distil everything back down to a few basic principles.

Hallelujah, there are but eight basic parts of speech.

Today, I have a sense of deliverance from the very subject that I once found so imprisoning. Freedom at being able to identify my subject from my predicate and to never labour over my sentences again.

And as an adult there is a greater sense of purpose in acquiring knowledge because you're in the driving seat of your life and therefore need to master all the controls, not sitting in the back seat going wherever it pleases Big Brother to drift.

Next term I'm going to take French and after that, history.
