fields.headline: Rostrum
fields.standfirst: Why won't the Ofsted chief accept that A-level teaching has improved, asks  Neil Hopkins
fields.trailText: Why won't the Ofsted chief accept that A-level teaching has improved, asks Neil Hopkins
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead's voice is apparently the latest to join the criticism of A-levels. In education we have become used to "saloon bar experts" declaiming their views on what is wrong with schools and colleges today; but this is different. This is the man in charge of standards. This really hurts.

My college is one of the biggest A-level centres in the country, with over 800 candidates sitting exams every year. And yes, our results have improved significantly over the years. We expect this year's results to place us once again as the highest scoring college in our region, and one of the top ten in the country. Does this mean that exam standards must have fallen in our part of Hampshire?

Of course, it's not that simple. But then it's not quite that simple nationally, either. Changes in pass rates or similar measures do not necessarily tell us anything about standards. All they tell us is how successful students are at passing exams.

How do I explain improving grades? Surely I don't expect the Institute of Directors and others to believe that students are more intelligent than they were? Well no, but maybe students now are working harder. Maybe teachers are better at teaching. Maybe, just maybe, all that hard work the teaching profession has put into improving itself over the years has actually achieved something. My college has been inspected twice in the last five years and on neither occasion did inspectors see a single unsatisfactory lesson. Perhaps that might just have a bearing on our excellent results?

The common fallacy in the standards debate is surely the presumption that A-levels are any sort of absolute measure of intelligence or potential. Those who say that a student leaving school nowadays with say an A-level grade C is not as bright as they would have been 30 years ago, may perhaps have a point. I know of no evidence either way. That does not mean that the standard of a grade C must have dropped. It may mean that hard work and expert teaching have enabled a student who might have struggled to better a D in the 1970s, to obtain a grade C today. If the equivalent 1970's teenager were somehow transported by time machine to a sixth-form college today, she might still struggle to raise her grade to a C unless she were prepared to settle into today's much greater work ethic, or she might fail completely to adjust to the use of computer technology. If today's grade C youngster were transported back to the 1970s, she might still achieve a grade C, or she might be tempted to work less, or she might find her teachers less skilled, or ...

In practice, students are different now, teaching techniques are different now, and even subjects are different now. Some mathematical topics now covered as early as GCSE were not taught until undergraduate level in the 70s. Other topics once in A-level maths papers, such as curve sketching, have withered on the vine as modern calculators have made them redundant.

In short, it is impossible to make these sorts of comparisons with any real confidence. The best we can do is to ensure that the standards of exam papers are maintained over successive years. That is a job for expert researchers. In fact, the exam boards already do this. The government's own watchdogs, the QCA and others, have done it for years. They appear to be happy with standards. My students were happy with their results. Let's praise them for doing well.

 Neil Hopkins is principal of Peter Symonds College in Winchester, but he writes here in a personal capacity.
fields.bodyText: Chris Woodhead's voice is apparently the latest to join the criticism of A-levels. In education we have become used to "saloon bar experts" declaiming their views on what is wrong with schools and colleges today; but this is different. This is the man in charge of standards. This really hurts. My college is one of the biggest A-level centres in the country, with over 800 candidates sitting exams every year. And yes, our results have improved significantly over the years. We expect this year's results to place us once again as the highest scoring college in our region, and one of the top ten in the country. Does this mean that exam standards must have fallen in our part of Hampshire? Of course, it's not that simple. But then it's not quite that simple nationally, either. Changes in pass rates or similar measures do not necessarily tell us anything about standards. All they tell us is how successful students are at passing exams. How do I explain improving grades? Surely I don't expect the Institute of Directors and others to believe that students are more intelligent than they were? Well no, but maybe students now are working harder. Maybe teachers are better at teaching. Maybe, just maybe, all that hard work the teaching profession has put into improving itself over the years has actually achieved something. My college has been inspected twice in the last five years and on neither occasion did inspectors see a single unsatisfactory lesson. Perhaps that might just have a bearing on our excellent results? The common fallacy in the standards debate is surely the presumption that A-levels are any sort of absolute measure of intelligence or potential. Those who say that a student leaving school nowadays with say an A-level grade C is not as bright as they would have been 30 years ago, may perhaps have a point. I know of no evidence either way. That does not mean that the standard of a grade C must have dropped. It may mean that hard work and expert teaching have enabled a student who might have struggled to better a D in the 1970s, to obtain a grade C today. If the equivalent 1970's teenager were somehow transported by time machine to a sixth-form college today, she might still struggle to raise her grade to a C unless she were prepared to settle into today's much greater work ethic, or she might fail completely to adjust to the use of computer technology. If today's grade C youngster were transported back to the 1970s, she might still achieve a grade C, or she might be tempted to work less, or she might find her teachers less skilled, or ... In practice, students are different now, teaching techniques are different now, and even subjects are different now. Some mathematical topics now covered as early as GCSE were not taught until undergraduate level in the 70s. Other topics once in A-level maths papers, such as curve sketching, have withered on the vine as modern calculators have made them redundant. In short, it is impossible to make these sorts of comparisons with any real confidence. The best we can do is to ensure that the standards of exam papers are maintained over successive years. That is a job for expert researchers. In fact, the exam boards already do this. The government's own watchdogs, the QCA and others, have done it for years. They appear to be happy with standards. My students were happy with their results. Let's praise them for doing well.  Neil Hopkins is principal of Peter Symonds College in Winchester, but he writes here in a personal capacity.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: I have just received a phone call from my child's school, informing me that he's missing lessons without reason. He's now in year 10 and is becoming increasingly disaffected. What can I do to support him and prevent this from becoming a much bigger problem?
fields.trailText: I have just received a phone call from my child's school, informing me that he's missing lessons without reason. What can I do to support him and prevent this from becoming a much bigger problem?
fields.body:
Susan Rees is an adviser with the Advisory Centre for Education:

Banner headlines on truancy tend to portray an alarming but simplistic picture, which belies the subtleties and complexities surrounding the problem.

At one end of the scale, children may miss lessons through boredom or complete disaffection with school; at the other, there are the school refusers who will not attend due to a range of anxieties. In the middle are those who either miss specific lessons, or indulge in a bit of "bunking", usually as a one-off incident.

One thing is true of all of these - the school will take it seriously, as will the local education authority. There's increasing pressure to meet attendance targets, and they will expect you as parents to take it seriously, too.

This can mean that schools focus on the effects of truancy, as opposed to tackling its causes. And this is where parents should start. Find out why your child is missing lessons, and then take the matter up with the school. You do have a legal duty to send your child to school, but if a 13-year-old refuses point blank to go, it's unrealistic to think that you can physically make them.

There can be many reasons why young people don't want to attend a particular lesson or school day - ranging from fear of bullying or a clash with a particular teacher through to worries about finding a subject too hard. In this case, you and the school can act on the specific cause of the problem, and work towards a solution. It's important to make clear to your child that you don't approve of them "opting out", but taking a strong disciplinary stance will rarely help.

Look for patterns of behaviour as early as possible, and find out the underlying triggers for non-attendance. Sometimes, they may have little ostensively to do with school itself, but can escalate to the point where a child may be deemed "school-phobic". Some children may have real anxieties about leaving their parent(s), or find the transition from home to school traumatic. Here, intervention by the school's learning support department may be needed, or contact your local education authority and seek advice from an education officer.

Don't forget your son is undergoing all the pain and confusion of adolescence - so he may be sullen and disaffected. Some schools and teachers deal well with teenage issues, but others don't. If a teacher has rubbed your son up the wrong way, sit down again and identify with your child what has caused the problem, and then ask the school for guidance. Around the age of 14 or 15 the likelihood of youngsters becoming totally disillusioned and disaffected with school is at its highest. This is also the age where more exclusions occur.

For more persistant truants, the approach should be the same. If a child is bored with school, find out why. At the end of key stage 3, and especially in key stage 4, question if the curriculum is really relevant to the child's needs.

The curriculum is flexible, with opportunities for vocational study in the form of GNVQs. Your son might benefit from work-related learning, and some young people react positively to attending colleges for part of their studies as opposed to school.

That said, no one should feel forced into adopting this strategy - all children have an entitlement to study the full curriculum, and the needs and benefits of the child in question must be at the heart of any decisions about their educational future. There is a danger in misreading the signs - disaffection among some ethnic groups, for example, may stem from a lack of understanding shown by the school towards their culture.

Better remedies will be found if all parties communicate effectively - the child, the parents and the school - and work together positively to overcome difficulties. High but realistic expectations are vital.

The Advisory Centre for Education's help line is 020-7354 8321; website: www.ace-ed.org.uk

 If you have been in a similar situation, and feel that you could offer advice to our readers from your own experience, we would like to hear from you.

Write to "If you ask me", Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, faxed to 020-7239 9933, or emailed to amanda.roper@theguardian.com.

Please ensure all correspondence reaches us by Thursday, September 7.

Next week's query: Do I need to buy a computer to help my children with their education? If so, what on earth do I need to buy them, and how much will it all cost? Please help, I'm a technophobe and a constantly nagged parent in need of guidance!

webTitle: So you want to learn about...jockeys

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...
fields.standfirst: Jockeys
fields.trailText: Jockeys
fields.body:
I'd like to be a jockey. You and a thousand others.

Really. I never knew it was so popular. Stands to reason.

Why? Glamorous business.

How true! Those thundering hooves over the turf, the wind whipping the face... You've done it before, then.

Oh, years ago. Where?

Blackpool beach. You mean on a donkey?

Yes, but they're related, aren't they? To racehorses?!

Well, loosely. Come to think of it, I have been given a few donkeys to ride.

So. How do I get started? There are around 35,000 people in the UK who work in the horse racing industry.

But I want to be a jockey... Hang on. It's all relevant. About 7,000 of these people work at stables where the horses are kept...

I know what stables are. Look, do you want good advice or not?

Sorry. Please go on... where horses are kept and trained.

But what about the jockeys? Patience. Many of these 7,000 aspire to become jockeys.

And how many succeed? I'd say that only around one in 10 actually make it as a jockey.

I see. Never mind. I'm still on. What do I need? More often than not new recruits will begin as "stable hands" or "lads", male or female. Anyone aged 16 to 18 who joins the industry is registered on a youth training programme.

What do they do? Responsibilities include labouring and mucking out while also learning how to groom and exercise the horses.

What qualities do they look for? The work of stable lads and apprentice jockeys is very physical. Jockeys need to be strong, especially their hands and arms. Emotionally they have to be calm and confident and respect the rather conservative traditions of the racing world. Working long hours and in adverse weather conditions is to be expected.

And what about size? There are weight restrictions. For men: seven to eight stone or around 50kg; for women eight to nine stone or around 56kg. National Hunt jockeys may be a little heavier.

Is there any training? Anyone who is under 19 when joining the industry must attend a race school at Doncaster or Newmarket where stable staff are trained. Recently NVQs have been introduced in Racehorse Care and Management, Racehorse Care and Horse Care.

What next? An apprenticeship usually finishes for a flat jockey at 25, or having ridden 95 winners. The equivalent for a National Hunt Jockey is 65 winners or age 26.

What about pay? Stable hands and apprentice jockeys who are over 19 can expect to earn around £140 per week after a year's experience. Trainers employ jockeys to ride "flat" racing (March to November) and National Hunt (all year round). Salaries can vary depending on success. There is usually an agreed rate per ride with a percentage of the prize money. Established jockeys can command high fees and are often contracted to ride for wealthy owners.

 Racing and Thoroughbred Breeding Training Board (RTBTB)

Suite 16, Unit 8, Kings Court, Willie Snaith Road, Newmarket, Suffolk, CB8 7SG.

 Stable Lads' Association (SLA)

4 Dunsmore Way, Midway, Swadlincote, Derbyshire, DE11 7LA

 Learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Standard bearer
fields.standfirst: As new curriculum agency chief, Cambridge professor David Hargreaves is venturing from the realms of academe into the political bearpit to improve schools
fields.trailText: As new curriculum agency chief, Cambridge professor David Hargreaves is venturing from the realms of academe into the political bearpit to improve schools
fields.body:
David Hargreaves' welcome to Whitehall politics was swift and brutal. On his first Monday morning in his job as guardian of examination standards the Guardian front page announced that his colleague Chris Woodhead was denouncing A-levels as too easy.

The chief inspector rubbed salt in the wound by dismissing whatever the government or teachers or exam boards might say as wishful thinking - "Everybody wants to believe that things are getting better."

As the new chief executive of the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority, Professor Hargreaves has moved from Cambridge academe to the political cockpit. How will he fare? He personifies the Labour government's attempts to recruit academics in the crusade to raise education standards - success or failure in his new post has implications for the wider research community in the universities.

Hundreds of members of the British Educational Research Association meeting in Cardiff last week heard calls for a greater say in schools policy.

As it happens Hargreaves genuinely believes things are improving. "The evidence of national testing is that standards are rising. There is no evidence at all to support the claims that tests are being made easier." One of his jobs is to make sure A-level and GCSE standards remain firm. Yet he is scornful of the complaints that these exams must be getting easier because more young people are passing them. "Some people seem to think if a school increased the percentage of pupils who could swim a length of the baths from 50% to 80%, that somehow [means] the length of the swimming pool has got shorter," he said.

As an academic Hargreaves appeals instinctively to evidence in any argument - though his time with the troubled Inner London Education Authority will have taught him that, when it comes to infighting between politicians or departmental battles, lack of evidence has never stopped anybody.

This is a man who said that expensive inspections of schools had limited value and that secondary pupils should spend more time out of school learning in the workplace. Several years ago he predicted the growth in classroom assistants and now predicts the eventual disappearance of GCSEs.

He is joint vice-chairman of the government's standards task force with Chris Woodhead. Speaking as he packed up his books from his Cambridge office - before the A-levels outburst - he said: "We don't always have the same views but we have learnt to respect our differences. We will work with Ofsted collaboratively."

Both men have angered academics with their criticism of educational research. Hargreaves believes too much of the £70m national research effort is neither true "blue skies" work nor of practical help to teachers on what works in the classroom. "But I completely disagree with Chris Woodhead. His line seems to be to scrap it - my line is to deal with the low quality and find ways of making it better." One way would be to involve teachers themselves in research, he argues.

He is David Blunkett's appointee and backs the broad thrust of government policy, although he believes the education secretary will want him to be an independent voice.

 Michael Bassey, secretary of BERA, called for a "national forum for education development" to be established which would bring politicians, teachers and researchers together to discuss ways of improving teaching in schools.

"A modern democracy needs to link the ballot box to professional expertise and academic insight," he said. Some research presented at the Cardiff conference could lead to "a substantial enhancement in the quality of education".

Lee Elliot-Major

 A searchable database of all papers presented at the conference is available at: www.leeds.ac.uk/

fields.headline: The big one
fields.standfirst: How do adults learn? It doesn't all happen in the mind says the professor heading a major new bid to find out
fields.trailText: How do adults learn? It doesn't all happen in the mind says the professor heading a major new bid to find out
fields.body:
As it should do, given the cost, the grandest and most expensive research project into further education will be tossing some big questions around.

The biggest, actually: how do students learn and how are they taught?

At first sight it seems staggering that we need to ponder these questions. Picture the rage and panic if the pilot of a Jumbo jet taxiing to take off casually informs passengers that he is one of the guinea pigs in an investigation to find out how people fly planes.

For fly, substitute teach and learn, and this is effectively what hundreds of students at four colleges around the country will be told by their tutors. Both students and tutors will be key players in the venture, says Professor Martin Bloomer, of Exeter university, who is heading the four-year project from a rather pokey office on the St Luke's college campus.

The common research model is for academics to take a detached, lofty view of the people they are observing, like zoologists viewing the antics of cobras safely from behind thick glass, giving the occasional poke with long sticks. Teachers, like the snakes, understandably can react badly to this approach.

"Here the academics and practitioners are partners in the research," says Bloomer. "We want the teachers to lead. We want them to suggest topics to focus on."

Misunderstanding is inevitable when nitty gritty mysteries like the human gene map or the mechanics of learning are under assault. The local BBC news has just described the four-year research programme as a government-funded venture designed to boost standards across further education.

Not an entirely ludicrous precis, surely. The further education limb is an £815,000 chunk of a £12.5m programme entitled the Teaching and Learning research project, and a good £2m of the cost comes from the Department for Education. Most of the cash can be tracked back to the taxpayer one way or another.

And hasn't David Blunkett signalled his wish for educational research which is paid for with public money to have feasible application for teachers and lecturers?

The venture is sponsored by the Economic and Social Research Council and is thus independent of government, Bloomer declares.

And any suggestion that the professor and his four partner academics - Phil Hodkinson, professor of life long learning at Leeds University, Denis Gleeson, professor of education, Warwick University, Dr David James, University of Western England and Dr Keith Postlethwaite, also of Exeter University - are somehow concocting a magic elixir for further education is likely to get up the noses of everyone in the sector. Which is not to say that the five don't have aspirations for their efforts.

"The aim is to deepen understanding of these processes," Bloomer says. "The aspirations are that on the basis of that deeper understanding we can make more informed judgements about educational practice, whether at the individual practitioner level or at national policy level."

So what do we know already about teaching and learning? Surely they have been raked over more than any other part of the education garden.

Apparently not that much in the 16-to-death age group which Bloomer and his colleagues are to concentrate on. But they are not starting with a tabula rasa. There are theories which have changed through the decades, and Bloomer holds views which he hopes to test.

One tenet is the notion of the praxis - the practising of the art or skill - of teaching. Bloomer believes this floats between two extremes: the view - Plato, Locke - that theory informs practice, and the reverse - Aristotle, Kant - that theory is induced from practice. The praxis, he says, is an intermeshing of the practical and theoretical: "There is a symbiotic relationship between the two."

He holds the image of the teacher as an autonomous professional continuously trimming the sails and nudging the tiller in response to changing conditions and student needs.

"We want to support teachers in investigating their own personal theory-making in practice and its impact upon practice."

In the project's opening phase, researchers will establish contact with four teachers at each of the four colleges - Bloomer doesn't want to identify them because arrangements haven't been quite finalised - who will suggest aspects of their work to be focused on.

"The thrust of it will be to examine educational practice in the full complexity of the changing world - that's as sharp as I can get to the focus."

The five leading academics all have a common interest in the social conditions of learning.

"In the past we've been driven by notions of learning as mentalist, that it takes place in the head."

Sociologists and psychologists have more recently come to recognise the importance of social and cultural conditions.

"We will be working with the teachers and students in the social relationships, in the cultural contexts each of them bring into their learning."

Bloomer left his distinguished Birmingham grammar school at 15 in a mutually agreed parting. He had, after all, put poster paint into the school's water tower. After a couple of years, he dropped out of an apprenticeship with British Leyland, headed for 1960s London and did various jobs.

He eventually returned to education via teacher training, without A- levels, in his early 20s and then did a masters after teaching for three years.

The point is, he says, that his perhaps messy career path is much more common than it is assumed. "The majority of people have life histories that have not followed the clear trajectory by which they are often described."

He buys the notion that for most people there are no more jobs for life, that we can expect to make at least three significant career changes.

And yet policy lags behind. "It is embedded in the assumption that 16-year-olds know what they want, will remain the same people and are able to make judgments for life."

When people want to change direction, the educational system penalises them. It is in his view still hopelessly polarised between academic and vocational.

An advocate of the baccalaureate model, he believes everyone should pursue an academic-vocational mixture, increasing one or other component as they need.

The traditional divide is partly based on a notion that there are different sorts of learners and is related to the tendency to polarise between delivery and discovery modes of teaching, ie between teachers simply spouting material at students or prompting them to think and find out for themselves.

Students put themselves into the different roles. Some demand rigid sticking to syllabus, others want to wrestle with ideas. In Bloomer's experience either category can, with appropriate encouragement, find themselves at home in the other.

"I think the kind of thinking which dominates policy making is that there are types of learners naturally disposed to one mode or other.

"The question for a teacher should be: if I'm going to support these young people through their educational and personal development, I should encourage them to master a range of approaches to learning because then they will get more out of life."

The local BBC news has just described the four-year research programme as a government-funded venture designed to boost standards across further education. Not an entirely ludicrous precis, surely. The further education limb is an £815,000 chunk of a £12.5m programme entitled the Teaching and Learning research project, and a good £2m of the cost comes from the Department for Education. Most of the cash can be tracked back to the taxpayer one way or another. And hasn't David Blunkett signalled his wish for educational research which is paid for with public money to have feasible application for teachers and lecturers? The venture is sponsored by the Economic and Social Research Council and is thus independent of government, Bloomer declares. And any suggestion that the professor and his four partner academics - Phil Hodkinson, professor of life long learning at Leeds University, Denis Gleeson, professor of education, Warwick University, Dr David James, University of Western England and Dr Keith Postlethwaite, also of Exeter University - are somehow concocting a magic elixir for further education is likely to get up the noses of everyone in the sector. Which is not to say that the five don't have aspirations for their efforts. "The aim is to deepen understanding of these processes," Bloomer says. "The aspirations are that on the basis of that deeper understanding we can make more informed judgements about educational practice, whether at the individual practitioner level or at national policy level." So what do we know already about teaching and learning? Surely they have been raked over more than any other part of the education garden. Apparently not that much in the 16-to-death age group which Bloomer and his colleagues are to concentrate on. But they are not starting with a tabula rasa. There are theories which have changed through the decades, and Bloomer holds views which he hopes to test. One tenet is the notion of the praxis - the practising of the art or skill - of teaching. Bloomer believes this floats between two extremes: the view - Plato, Locke - that theory informs practice, and the reverse - Aristotle, Kant - that theory is induced from practice. The praxis, he says, is an intermeshing of the practical and theoretical: "There is a symbiotic relationship between the two." He holds the image of the teacher as an autonomous professional continuously trimming the sails and nudging the tiller in response to changing conditions and student needs. "We want to support teachers in investigating their own personal theory-making in practice and its impact upon practice." In the project's opening phase, researchers will establish contact with four teachers at each of the four colleges - Bloomer doesn't want to identify them because arrangements haven't been quite finalised - who will suggest aspects of their work to be focused on. "The thrust of it will be to examine educational practice in the full complexity of the changing world - that's as sharp as I can get to the focus." The five leading academics all have a common interest in the social conditions of learning. "In the past we've been driven by notions of learning as mentalist, that it takes place in the head." Sociologists and psychologists have more recently come to recognise the importance of social and cultural conditions. "We will be working with the teachers and students in the social relationships, in the cultural contexts each of them bring into their learning." Bloomer left his distinguished Birmingham grammar school at 15 in a mutually agreed parting. He had, after all, put poster paint into the school's water tower. After a couple of years, he dropped out of an apprenticeship with British Leyland, headed for 1960s London and did various jobs. He eventually returned to education via teacher training, without A- levels, in his early 20s and then did a masters after teaching for three years. The point is, he says, that his perhaps messy career path is much more common than it is assumed. "The majority of people have life histories that have not followed the clear trajectory by which they are often described." He buys the notion that for most people there are no more jobs for life, that we can expect to make at least three significant career changes. And yet policy lags behind. "It is embedded in the assumption that 16-year-olds know what they want, will remain the same people and are able to make judgments for life." When people want to change direction, the educational system penalises them. It is in his view still hopelessly polarised between academic and vocational. An advocate of the baccalaureate model, he believes everyone should pursue an academic-vocational mixture, increasing one or other component as they need. The traditional divide is partly based on a notion that there are different sorts of learners and is related to the tendency to polarise between delivery and discovery modes of teaching, ie between teachers simply spouting material at students or prompting them to think and find out for themselves. Students put themselves into the different roles. Some demand rigid sticking to syllabus, others want to wrestle with ideas. In Bloomer's experience either category can, with appropriate encouragement, find themselves at home in the other. "I think the kind of thinking which dominates policy making is that there are types of learners naturally disposed to one mode or other. "The question for a teacher should be: if I'm going to support these young people through their educational and personal development, I should encourage them to master a range of approaches to learning because then they will get more out of life."

webTitle: Graduate debt - no longer a dirty word

fields.headline: Debt - no longer a dirty word
fields.standfirst: Gail Whiteley is divorced with two daughters, both law graduates. Both are now in work but one still owes a fortune
fields.trailText: Gail Whiteley is divorced with two daughters, both law graduates. Both are now in work but one still owes a fortune
fields.body:
How do I feel about having a daughter get herself into serious debt while going through university - debts which have still not been paid off over two years after graduation, even though she has been fully employed since then? We appear to have conflicting attitudes.

By the time my younger daughter had graduated she owed money to the bank, her father, the student loan company and me. She had found the grant totally inadequate to live on, especially during her last year when she went from one financial crisis to another. During the run-up to her finals we came to an arrangement whereby I would send her cash, something that I couldn't easily afford, each month, just to take the financial pressure off her during revison and final exam preparations.

I found it very difficult to accept that this way of life was what young people were being forced to adopt. My feelings towards debt derive from my upbringing and the different way my generation was taught to regard finance and possessions. If you were not able to pay for something, you didn't have it. It was as simple as that.

My daughters' generation seems to have a completely different attitude to finance - debt is a way of life. Despite knowing my views and always having been encouraged to live within their means while at home, it no longer seems to worry them. If they feel they need credit, they take it out. No problem!

My younger daughter blames the present system of student loans which makes it impossible for any student to get through university without going into debt or receiving significant parental help.

In her opinion debt is actively encouraged - loans, overdrafts and credit cards are almost being thrust down their throats by the banks and student loan companies, with no thought or pressure about paying it all back.

Suddenly on their own, most of them for the first time, students have no experience of budgeting for themselves. All the hidden extras and expenses that we all know about, such as food, heating and phone bills, come as a surprise to them. While they are still at home they blithely consume with little thought about who pays at the end of the day. Sharing bills with other students, particularly the aforementioned phone bill, becomes a nightmare.

One tip for all new students' parents is to suggest changing the phone at the student house to take incoming calls only. It can save them a fortune.

While I feel very proud of my daughter, I am also enormously relieved that she is now struggling on her own and I would certainly not like to find myself back at the beginning again.

webTitle: Putting children through university under pressure

fields.headline: Close to the edge
fields.standfirst: For parents out of work, alone, or with younger children to support, financing a child through university can be a nightmare - but they do survive the ordeal as  Lynne Boundy can testify
fields.trailText: For parents out of work, alone, or with younger children to support, financing a child through university can be a nightmare - but they do survive the ordeal as Lynne Boundy can testify
fields.body:
Filling in the grant form was not difficult. Income nil, expenditure unlimited. I exaggerate - we had state benefits of £70 odd a week but that barely covered all the insurance premiums we had been paying in our pre-unemployment days. So Simon, the youngest of our four children who was starting a degree course at Edinburgh University, was awarded a grant that was enough to pay for his accommodation. The student loan just might pay for his food and travel, and perhaps his books. But what about the beer, clothes, phone calls, visits to the cinema, tickets to see a band, all the things that ease the drudgery of study and help you socialise?

Our eldest son, who joined the RAF, had been seen off to Cranwell years previously and fully kitted out. In Simon's case, we could give him little more than a few pairs of well-pressed jeans (sorry, anathema to young people) and sweatshirts, none of them new.

During that first year he subsisted with his grant and student loan. At home we had little time for our youngest son, obsessed as we were with our own problems of managing on state benefits and wondering how we would pay the next bill. My husband, Peter, was suffering from a loss of identity and feelings of desperation as he was rejected for job after job; while I was trying to focus on the Master's degree I had started. We were also coping with a severely ill parent.

So apart from the weekly phone call in which our son always assured us that he was managing, we left him alone. In some ways our lives were running in parallel, all struggling to survive, though I suspect we were managing rather less well financially than he was. At least he was having fun.

The end of the first year, apart from exams and partying, is taken up with finding accommodation for the second year with amenable flatmates and, most importantly in Simon's straightened circumstances, with Getting Back the Deposit. This is the equivalent of a month's rent, a considerable sum for a poverty-stricken student. Yet most landlords see it as fair game and an extra bonus on top of the often exploitative rents charged.

There is a further expense not built into the grants system. To guarantee reasonable accommodation with like-minded friends, it seems you have to find, and pay rent for, the following year's flat or house from July of the previous academic year - throughout the summer vacation. For most students, including our son, working during the summer is de rigueur. The relevant local authorities insisted we were not entitled to anything extra for the additional adult living with us over the summer. "He can get a job," was the riposte.

Easier said than done. With our experience of fighting our way round the system, we admitted defeat. By this time we, too, were depending on handouts from grandparents and our own children. And our debts were spiralling with little prospect of work. A short-term maintenance job in a local factory enabled Simon to keep up his rent payments on his flat, to go out with his mates occasionally, and to give him something extra for the beginning of the next year. Yet we felt guilty we could do so little to support him. While so many of his peers were backpacking or just package-holidaying, he had to stay at home for lack of funds. But conscious of our sensibilities, he never complained.

Illness inevitably follows living on a starvation diet and "burning the candle at both ends", so it came as no great surprise when Simon rang us in the first term of his second year, to say: "Mum, I'm in hospital."

Our son, who had never had a day's absence from school, had developed an abscess in his throat which had to be drained as it was constricting his swallowing. We wanted to rush up there and bring him home but, stoic as ever, he insisted he could cope. His main concern was the exam he had to take in two days' time.

With strict instructions to tell his tutor he was taking the exam under the influence of powerful drugs (of the medicinal variety) and was feeling less than well, he sat the exam. We took great comfort from his caring flatmates who visited him in hospital and phoned us about his progress. But less comfort from his 90-minute wait in the wintry conditions of Edinburgh in December for a bus to take him home from the hospital.

His second year has been equally stressful financially - he has taken out the maximum student loan - and how he avoided massive debts is a mystery. Yet he has still enjoyed a social life. The vacation will again have to be spent earning enough money to pay his rent over the summer. Fortunately, Edinburgh offers better holiday job prospects than where we live, so we don't know how much we will see him.

Now we are in work again and slowly becoming financially more stable. Repossession is no longer a threat. Whatever we are able to send him is always gratefully received though, sadly, we can't afford it often. And no, we would not have wanted him to have lived at home and gone to a local university. Living in a different environment from home and mixing with others is an essential step in a young person's life, and where better to do this than in a vibrant academic environment.

How has Simon gained? Apart from having spent four years in a beautiful city, he has probably made lifelong friends, has learned to manage his money and time and, above all, has learned to survive in a situation he may have to face again with an uncertain economic future.

For us it's been an uncertain time. While we have enjoyed watching him gain new skills and ideas, the effect of unemployment and fear of the unknown, has been compounded by feelings of guilt at being unable to give him financial and emotional support when it was needed. In fact, it was often he who gave us emotional support.

 This is an extract from How I supported my son or daughter through university, edited by Lynne Boundy (Independent Studies, Lancaster University, supported by the Guardian) £9.95 (inc p&p), tel: 01524 593430, email: IndStud@lancaster.ac.uk

Students say

"It was hard to ask my parents for money - especially when I needed some extra towards a computer in the second year - because I know it's been a struggle for them to help out with the finances even though I worked part-time throughout my degree."

"My mum's having to work full-time, indefinitely, to support three of us through university, while her colleagues are taking early retirement and enjoying themselves."

"I didn't communicate very well with my parents, apart from when I was asking for a top-up, but thinking back I think it's essential."

"After my parents got divorced, it made it more difficult to get a reasonable allowance - particularly from my dad who has taken on a new young family. So he has no idea what it's like for me struggling on a pittance."

"Anyone with life skills (like managing money) will be better able to benefit from university. Even smaller people may be advantaged because they need less food to survive."

"My parents seemed to think I'd graduate in July with a full-time job lined up straight away. They're only now realising that graduate jobs are hard to get."

Feeling the pinch?

 www.freefund.com also gives details of (often obscure) awards and scholarships.

 The DfEE publishes a leaflet, Financial Support for Higher Education Students in 2000/ 2001, which is available by calling 0800-731-9133 or see the website: www.dfee.gov.uk

 For the Student Loan Company, call: 0800-405010

webTitle: John Crace meets a man who gave up drink to learn

fields.headline: Return ticket
fields.standfirst: John Crace meets a man who has bid goodbye to booze and the three Bs
fields.trailText: John Crace meets a man who has bid goodbye to booze and the three Bs
fields.body:
The way to hell is paved with assumptions. If you'd happened to bump into John Harmsworth five years ago when he was a chronic alcoholic sleeping rough in Lincoln's Inn Field, you'd almost certainly have written him off as a lost cause. And you wouldn't have been alone, because Harmsworth had already written himself off. Homelessness and alcoholism is a one-way ticket, right? Wrong. And Harmsworth himself is the proof. Within a year of finally kicking the drink, he has completed both a computer and an IT teacher training programme and has worked as an unpaid classroom assistant. And it gets better still. Last week he landed his first paid job for 16 years, when he was appointed a classroom support worker for the Peabody Trust with a salary of £18,000, and on Friday he went to the Dome as one of the five winners of this year's Learning Works awards to celebrate those who have rebuilt their lives through work-based learning. It has been, as John says, "one hell of a year".

Harmsworth's first steps to recovery began in 1997. "I received a letter from my daughter which read, "Dear Dad, I'm getting married, but we think it would be best if you didn't come down. Where were you when I needed you? Please don't hate me for writing this letter, love Vicki," he says. "I wrote back: 'A man sits drinking on the floor in a flat in London, as always, alone. Cans of food are stacked in order under the table. The floor is mostly covered with rubbish and empty bottles. He looks at his watch. It says 11.30am, but he knows that's not the real time. The real time is 5.15am, it's always been.

'He wakes up in a single bed. It's about 5am on Wednesday August 30, 1982. In the night his four-year-old son has crept into bed beside him. His left cheek is sort of stuck to the man's right bicep. The man carefully raises the boy's head, like removing a Post-It note. He stirs but does not wake. The man puts a few clothes in a bag. His son looks so beautiful lying there. He kisses him gently on the forehead.

'He goes into his daughter's bedroom. She's eight. She's lying on her back, her mouth slightly open. He thinks back to coming in from work when she was three. She would run towards him and he would sweep her up in his arms to hug her and kiss her.

'The time is 5.15am. He bends down and kisses her softly on the lips and the world comes to an end. Bang. He leaves the house and hitchhikes up the road to nowhere. To answer your letter: I couldn't hate you if I tried. I love you.' "

When Harmsworth's drinking brought his marriage to its knees, he walked out, not just on his family but his whole life.

"The first person to stop for me was going to Birmingham and I thought 'That'll do.' " For a while he maintained some contact with his children, but after a while it became easier not to as he settled into a new existence as professional drinker and social security claimant.

Several years later he gravitated to London where he has remained ever since. "At school you learn the three Rs," he smiles, "but on the street you learn the three Bs. Begging, busking and selling the Big Issue." Harmsworth proved to be a good learner and for the best part of 15 years he survived on his wits, living from hand-out to hand-out. "It was quite simple really," he says. "All you needed to know was how to sign on and what times the off-licence opened."

And that's the way it remained until his daughter's letter prompted him to change his life. He didn't manage it at first, only knocking up a few month's on the wagon before going back on the booze, but in June last year he finally cracked it - shortly before the birth of his grandson, Dylan.

Without the drink, Harmsworth found he had time on his hands and took himself off to the Peabody Skills Centre, below the hostel where he was living. "I'd bought myself a computer for £50 in one of my dry periods and had become very interested in learning more about them," he says. He proved an exceptionally quick learner and his ability to communicate his skills to others soon came to the notice of his teachers. And the results speak for themselves. Today Harmsworth doesn't just have a life and a job, he has a family, too. He is reunited with his daughter, son, brother and father.

Several years later he gravitated to London where he has remained ever since. "At school you learn the three Rs," he smiles, "but on the street you learn the three Bs. Begging, busking and selling the Big Issue." Harmsworth proved to be a good learner and for the best part of 15 years he survived on his wits, living from hand-out to hand-out. "It was quite simple really," he says. "All you needed to know was how to sign on and what times the off-licence opened." And that's the way it remained until his daughter's letter prompted him to change his life. He didn't manage it at first, only knocking up a few month's on the wagon before going back on the booze, but in June last year he finally cracked it - shortly before the birth of his grandson, Dylan. Without the drink, Harmsworth found he had time on his hands and took himself off to the Peabody Skills Centre, below the hostel where he was living. "I'd bought myself a computer for £50 in one of my dry periods and had become very interested in learning more about them," he says. He proved an exceptionally quick learner and his ability to communicate his skills to others soon came to the notice of his teachers. And the results speak for themselves. Today Harmsworth doesn't just have a life and a job, he has a family, too. He is reunited with his daughter, son, brother and father.

webTitle: We've got the cash, you find more students, colleges told

fields.headline: Desperate measures
fields.standfirst: We've got the cash, you find more students, colleges told
fields.trailText: The government is promising colleges that it will effectively fund unlimited further education growth in a desperate attempt to hit its target of 700,000 extra students by 2002.
fields.body:
The government is promising colleges that it will effectively fund unlimited further education growth in a desperate attempt to hit its target of 700,000 extra students by 2002.

The blunt dash-for-growth message suggests jitters within the Department for Education and Employment about missing this target.

The first solid figures on student recruitment since the education secretary, David Blunkett, set the target actually showed an overall drop in numbers of about 100,000.

Now officials have told colleges that government will stump up full funding for any extra students, part-time or full-time, signed on for courses which lead to recognised qualifications, and is effectively lifting the limits each college has been set under the existing funding formula.

But many colleges may hold back until the education secretary David Blunkett announces it publicly. Managements have learned the hard way that restrictions which are suddenly lifted can be slammed down again with equal swiftness, and with severe financial consequences.

Civil servants have been advised that colleges need a clear guarantee from Blunkett himself that the cash for this growth will come through, ideally in a letter from the education secretary to all institutions and in a public announcement.

The Further Education Funding Council informed colleges in June that it had £60m for additional adult students beyond final funding agreements for this new year. A letter invited institutions to apply for extra growth funding by the end of July and acknowledged that some were wary about disappointment. Roughly a hundred colleges applied.

Anxious that the message hasn't got through, officials at the DfEE told the Association of Colleges last week that they want the necessary 15% growth in the next 15 months and that the full funding will be available.

The 700,000 target looked a tall order when Blunkett announced it at the 1998 Association of Colleges conference, as part of a "something for something" deal in return for an unprecedented boost in further education funding. Most of the extra students would be adults, and 50,000 would be full-time and in the 16 to 19 age bracket.

The baseline for this five-year growth was 1997/98, the new government's first year, when student numbers in the sector totalled about 3.9m. Ministers blamed the 100,000 drop in numbers in 1998/99 on tighter controls imposed on colleges' franchising operations. These operations had significantly boosted recruitment during the mid 1990s.

College fingers were burnt in 1997 when the outgoing Tory administration abruptly capped the so-called Demand Led Element (DLE) of funding, which had also been designed to boost growth. The current deal is more generous than DLE. Officials have told the association that additional students will attract full-funding.

This does not mean that students will not have to pay fees where they apply. The current system in which the over-19s pay fees unless they are in certain exempt categories - eg they receive state means-tested benefits - will stay.

So, although pulling in more students will be financially attractive to colleges, they have still got to persuade more to enrol.

David Gibson, the Association of College's chief executive, said that there are positive signs of a return to growth.

"But obviously colleges need to feel that if they go all out for growth, the rug is not going to be pulled away again in six months time."

webTitle: Labour will rebuff universities' calls for higher fees

fields.headline: Collision course
fields.standfirst: Labour will rebuff universities' calls for higher fees
fields.trailText: Labour will rebuff universities' calls for higher fees
fields.body:
Labour officials have rubbished Tory proposals for universities to be privatised. However, they appear to be on collision course with academic heads, who this week are considering privatisation and top-up fees as options to avert the funding crisis in higher education.

Labour advisers say that radical Tory plans to fund universities through one-off endowments and end state grants would impose huge top-up fees on middle-class students and parents. "The Tories don't even know what universities would participate," a statement said. "The plan will cost nearly £80bn in England alone and there is no detail as to where the billions would come from."

The draft Conservative election manifesto plans to free universities from red tape and government control have set the tone for the highly charged political debate over university funding in the run-up to the next general election. The Tories say that universities would be endowed with money from government windfalls from future privatisation proceeds and asset sales. But they would prevent academic institutions charging top-up fees in the short term.

Labour officials argue that the government would be powerless to stop universities charging extra fees under such a scheme. They have also attacked calls to abolish current tuition fees for university students, unveiled last week by the Liberal Democrats in their pre-manifesto document.

Labour are likely to stick to existing policies for universities, where fees are restricted by the government to a flat rate of £1,050 a year for students from the richest backgrounds. And the university funding issue may not even warrant a mention in the election manifesto.

But privatisation is certainly on the universities' own agenda when vice-chancellors discuss future funding options for the sector during their annual conference. Universities would be able to opt out of state control and set their own level of fees under one of the proposals in a report by Sir William Taylor, former head of Hull, Huddersfield and Thames Valley universities.

Universities say they can't deliver what politicians, employers, students and the public expect from them in the face of continuing funding cuts. The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals wants a political commitment to a major review of higher education in the next Parliament.

Under the privatisation option being presented, universities would have to set aside bursaries for 20% of undergraduates who are from the poorest backgrounds. Other options include higher upfront tuition fees with income-contingent loans; means tested fees increased by 10% each year; fees for limited numbers of courses; full costs fees and scholarships. "The secretary of state has called for a vigorous debate on higher education funding, on which it appears the government has not yet made up its mind and may not at present be of one mind," claims the report for vice-chancellors.

Vice-chancellors will be asked to fill in a questionnaire to vote on what issues should influence funding decisions. These range from concerns over student access and acceptibility to students and parents to the revenue potential for institutions and the electoral risk associated with any political backers. Detailed modelling of the funding options will not be completed until the end of the year.

Student leaders meanwhile have also attacked the Tory proposals. "The Conservatives' talk of ensuring some 'access for students from poor backgrounds', though sounding good in principle, begins to resemble the financially elitist funding formula for universities in the US, with Victorian-style handouts to pauper students," a statement from the Aldwych Group said. The group shadows the 20 elite university heads of the Russell Group and aims to counteract elitism.

Higher education minister Baroness Blackstone will be among the speakers discussing the future of universities during meetings organised by the CVCP and the Association of University Teachers at the Labour party conference in Bournemouth next week.

webTitle: Parents review the government's new guides to learning

fields.headline: 'I never knew my way around before'
fields.standfirst: Parents review the government's new guides to learning
fields.trailText: Parents review the government's new guides to learning
fields.body:
Learning Journey 1

A guide to the curriculum for parents of three- to seven-year-olds.

 Debbie Moorhead, mother of Christian, 7, and Joseph, 5:
"I've often felt out of my depth at school. The teachers would be going on about key stage 1 and literacy hour and I wouldn't know what they were on about. The evenings in school on literacy hour and numeracy hour have helped, but this book is a step forward, too. I came away feeling better informed and enthused about my children's learning. The book gives you a good idea of what you can talk to the teacher about, and about what you should expect from the school. The tips on what to do with your child were simple and effective. I'd keep a book like this in a handy place."

Learning Journey 2

A guide to the curriculum for parents of seven- to 11-year-olds.

 Caroline d'Auria, mother of Charlie, 10:
"This is ideal - I never feel I know what I should do about Charlie's education, and this outlined a lot of what I think I need to know. It gave the impression that you can be quite proactive in teaching your child or at least supporting the teacher, which I liked. I was especially interested to read the list of things Charlie should be able to do aged 11 - things like using joined-up writing. I think at this stage, with a child in year 6, it's especially good to have that so you can go to see the class teacher if you think there's anything your child seems a bit behind on."

 Kathy Wittet, mother of Eleanor, 8:
"This will be really useful when Eleanor is 11 because what it's really telling me is what I can expect her to know by then. But it hasn't got much about the interim, about what you should expect from a child in year 4, for example. The tips are similarly all aimed at the children at the top of the age group - one suggests you get your child to go through your itemised phone bill and tot up what his or her calls have cost, for example, but an eight-year-old isn't going to be using the phone regularly. I'd prefer something specific for each year group."

 Kate Amis, mother of Phoebe, 10 and Henry, 7:
"I felt really positive about this book: it's not patronising; the activities it suggests are interesting. It did seem aimed at parents with older children, though, and there is too much emphasis on targets."

Learning Journey 3

A Parent's Guide to the Secondary Schools Curriculum

 Maureen Desmond, mother of Sophie, 11:
"Clear and readable; to the point, and easy to navigate one's way around. It explained all about key stages and I thought that was a good start. I think the ideal time to read it would be the summer before your child moves on to secondary school. I've got a few caveats: the tips on things to do were a bit lame, things like getting your child to watch educational TV documentaries. By this stage you're either doing that, or you're not going to be persuaded to do it by a booklet. But overall I liked it."

webTitle: Students are shopping for courses as never before

fields.headline: How much for a B and two Cs?
fields.standfirst: Egged on by ads on prime-time TV, students are shopping for courses as never before
fields.trailText: This year's scramble for university places has seen a dramatic rise in student customer power. Applicants have been demanding better offers from academic admissions staff, and even turning down accepted places for better deals in other universities.
fields.body:
This year's scramble for university places has seen a dramatic rise in student customer power. Applicants have been demanding better offers from academic admissions staff, and even turning down accepted places for better deals in other universities. Universities, meanwhile, are mounting increasingly aggressive marketing campaigns to lure students to their campuses.

Students usually fight over unfilled places on degree courses during the annual clearing process in August. But dynamics of the market for student admissions this year experienced a shift: there have been more government-funded places available, but not enough students to fill them. In England alone an extra 17,000 full-time places have been available this year, as part of the government's drive to expand student numbers. Yet the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service reports that student admissions are only up 5,000 for the UK as a whole. The figures show that the number of actual applicants is down by 0.4% on last year.

Statistics for part-time students are not published centrally, but many academic admissions officers fear that they too will also experience falling demand. The numbers of mature students enrolling on university degree courses has gone down since the introduction of tuition fees three years ago.

According to Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of the University of Westminster, the new choosy student customers are causing mayhem to planning for student numbers at the university. "There has been much more shopping around this year," says Copland. "Students are coming to us with certain A-level grades, and asking what offers we can make." He says that some students are turning down accepted places after receiving better offers from other universities, which they apply to directly, outside the Ucas system.

London academic institutions are finding it increasingly difficult to attract cash-strapped students who are put off by the high cost of living in the capital city. The take-up of students varies for different subjects, with science and engineering degree courses often the hardest to fill.

There have also been reports of universities poaching students from other institutions by offering £1,000 bursaries. This is not allowed under the Ucas system, where students are allocated two university places: a firm offer and a back-up place.

The latest figures from the admissions service reveal a rise this year in the numbers of applicants who remain undecided about the places they have been offered. Last week Ucas reported that just over 16,000 students have still to confirm if they are accepting university offers. Although the number of students withdrawing from the Ucas scheme is down on previous years, with just under 10,000 applicants bailing out, many students withdraw after deciding to take out a gap year, or intended to retake A-levels, and reapply next year.

There is also increasingly intense competition between universities to fill places, particularly those fighting over students from their local region. London institutions have for sometime used the London Underground for advertising campaigns. Elsewhere in the country, buses can be seen adorned with university publicity.

The north-west, for example, has witnessed rival marketing campaigns by the University of Central Lancashire and Salford University. Adverts for both universities have been seen on the same buses. And the universities have exploited local radio and TV networks.

Both Central Lancashire and Salford campaigns benefited handsomely from the national spotlight brought by adverts on Channel 4. Both were scheduled during the Big Brother programme - which is popular among 18- to 25-year-olds - at the height of its popularity.

Central Lancashire witnessed one of the biggest increases in student applications across the academic sector this year.

fields.headline: Wide skies
fields.standfirst: Durham's 'other' campus is shattering the university's reputation as stuffy and aloof
fields.trailText: Durham's 'other' campus is shattering the university's reputation as stuffy and aloof
fields.body:
In 1987 Mrs Thatcher did her famous "walk in the wilderness". Armed with her handbag, she stepped out into a decaying industrial wasteland that was to become the brave new world of her government's urban regeneration initiatives. She was treading over a site that would turn into a gleaming higher-education and research park: Durham University's £35 million development on Teesside. Its Stockton campus became the first example of urban regeneration money being used to develop higher education.

When Britain's vice-chancellors meet here for their annual conference, which begins today, they will undoubtedly be mindful of its political resonance. Already under intense pressure from the government to open their doors to the children of the working class and ethnic minorities, university leaders can expect to be lectured this week on widening access by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.

Vice-chancellors might also be told that one of the schools targeted by Stockton is Monkseaton Community High in Whitley Bay, the school of Laura Spence, whose rejection by Oxford and acceptance by Harvard last summer proved to be a political incendiary device.

Like its parent institution, Durham University in Stockton extends along the riverside. But there the similarity ends. No castle or cathedral, no world heritage site here. Stockton is a symbol of how a university as traditional and elite as Durham can set about widening access, penetrating the heart of a community where unemployment is twice the national average (five times as high in some wards).

Teesside suffers the lowest educational achievement nationally. As few as 25% of 16-year-olds gain five GCSE A-Cs, and a similarly low percentage of 18-year-olds pursue further education. Only 19 out of every thousand locally enter higher education, an abysmal record even for the north-east - in Sunderland and Tyneside the figure is 42.

Although only 58% of Durham's total student population is from state schools, the Stockton campus enrols over 50% of its 1,600 full-time students from the local area, 40% being mature students coming through non A-level routes. It runs a foundation year for people without relevant qualifications to prepare for degree entry.

Full-time schools liaison officers are employed to run Stars, the School Targeted Raising Aspiration Scheme, working with year 9s (13-14-year-olds about to make their GCSE choices) and again with pupils in Years 10 and 11, sending in undergraduates to help them with revision and study skills.

Vice-chancellors are expecting Blunkett to put more flesh on these initiatives when he addresses their conference in a keynote speech.

One such scheme was a large summer school for gifted and talented 11- and 12-year-olds, funded by the government's Excellence in Cities initiative, run by the Stockton education authority but hosted by the university free of charge with office, IT, academic and social support.

"The kids were totally seduced by the facilities we have here and the fact that it is here on their doorstep," recalls Richard Taylor, head of Durham's student marketing at Stockton. "I think it helped to raise their aspirations. There is a problem with emigration from this area. The brightest go away and don't come back. But put a top UK university on the doorstep, give people the opportunity to stay and that will start to put skills back into Teesside, pushing up the level of the population qualified at degree level."

Durham is in the process of setting up a joint medical school with the University of Newcastle on the Stockton campus. "There is a shortage of GPs in the area and there are consultant vacancies in just about every discipline," says Taylor. "But if people can study here there is a possibility that they will stay."

Haleema Jabbar, 21, is in the final year of an applied psychology degree on the Stockton site. Her family, Muslims who originate from Pakistan, live in Gateshead and four of her seven siblings attend university. Haleema is a high achiever, having gained an A grade A-level, two Bs and a C to gain her Durham University place. She says: "I wanted to go to a traditional university with the prestige and job opportunities that goes with it. Durham was my first choice; but I also fancied somewhere that was newer and fresh, and the Stockton campus with its more applied degrees seemed to fit the bill for me.

"It's been absolutely brilliant. We have the same lecturers as students in Durham itself, but we enjoy fantastic state-of-the-art facilities and a very friendly atmosphere. There is a lot of support and closeness between lecturers and students. We are like a family, everybody knows everybody and there's a lot of cultural diversity, mature and local students.

"Stockton has the Durham prestige but less of the formality. I really see it as Durham entering the new millennium. This is the way forward."

Tim Smith, 38, lives in Stockton, is married and has two children. He left school in Stockton at 16 with low CSE grades and was a soldier for 16 years. He left the army with the intention of becoming a nurse, but after the foundation year at Durham University's Stockton site, he discovered he had ability in science. He is about to start his second year of an environmental science degree. His wife, Sarah, 25, left school in Stockton at 16 with nine GCSEs but went on to become a hairdresser. She is about to start the foundation year with the intention of becoming a primary school teacher with a specialism in IT. "I have done it the hard way. I wish I had had the support to do it when I was 18, that's what I keep telling my kids."

fields.bodyText: In 1987 Mrs Thatcher did her famous "walk in the wilderness". Armed with her handbag, she stepped out into a decaying industrial wasteland that was to become the brave new world of her government's urban regeneration initiatives. She was treading over a site that would turn into a gleaming higher-education and research park: Durham University's £35 million development on Teesside. Its Stockton campus became the first example of urban regeneration money being used to develop higher education. When Britain's vice-chancellors meet here for their annual conference, which begins today, they will undoubtedly be mindful of its political resonance. Already under intense pressure from the government to open their doors to the children of the working class and ethnic minorities, university leaders can expect to be lectured this week on widening access by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary. Vice-chancellors might also be told that one of the schools targeted by Stockton is Monkseaton Community High in Whitley Bay, the school of Laura Spence, whose rejection by Oxford and acceptance by Harvard last summer proved to be a political incendiary device. Like its parent institution, Durham University in Stockton extends along the riverside. But there the similarity ends. No castle or cathedral, no world heritage site here. Stockton is a symbol of how a university as traditional and elite as Durham can set about widening access, penetrating the heart of a community where unemployment is twice the national average (five times as high in some wards). Teesside suffers the lowest educational achievement nationally. As few as 25% of 16-year-olds gain five GCSE A-Cs, and a similarly low percentage of 18-year-olds pursue further education. Only 19 out of every thousand locally enter higher education, an abysmal record even for the north-east - in Sunderland and Tyneside the figure is 42. Although only 58% of Durham's total student population is from state schools, the Stockton campus enrols over 50% of its 1,600 full-time students from the local area, 40% being mature students coming through non A-level routes. It runs a foundation year for people without relevant qualifications to prepare for degree entry. Full-time schools liaison officers are employed to run Stars, the School Targeted Raising Aspiration Scheme, working with year 9s (13-14-year-olds about to make their GCSE choices) and again with pupils in Years 10 and 11, sending in undergraduates to help them with revision and study skills. Vice-chancellors are expecting Blunkett to put more flesh on these initiatives when he addresses their conference in a keynote speech. One such scheme was a large summer school for gifted and talented 11- and 12-year-olds, funded by the government's Excellence in Cities initiative, run by the Stockton education authority but hosted by the university free of charge with office, IT, academic and social support. "The kids were totally seduced by the facilities we have here and the fact that it is here on their doorstep," recalls Richard Taylor, head of Durham's student marketing at Stockton. "I think it helped to raise their aspirations. There is a problem with emigration from this area. The brightest go away and don't come back. But put a top UK university on the doorstep, give people the opportunity to stay and that will start to put skills back into Teesside, pushing up the level of the population qualified at degree level." Durham is in the process of setting up a joint medical school with the University of Newcastle on the Stockton campus. "There is a shortage of GPs in the area and there are consultant vacancies in just about every discipline," says Taylor. "But if people can study here there is a possibility that they will stay." Haleema Jabbar, 21, is in the final year of an applied psychology degree on the Stockton site. Her family, Muslims who originate from Pakistan, live in Gateshead and four of her seven siblings attend university. Haleema is a high achiever, having gained an A grade A-level, two Bs and a C to gain her Durham University place. She says: "I wanted to go to a traditional university with the prestige and job opportunities that goes with it. Durham was my first choice; but I also fancied somewhere that was newer and fresh, and the Stockton campus with its more applied degrees seemed to fit the bill for me. "It's been absolutely brilliant. We have the same lecturers as students in Durham itself, but we enjoy fantastic state-of-the-art facilities and a very friendly atmosphere. There is a lot of support and closeness between lecturers and students. We are like a family, everybody knows everybody and there's a lot of cultural diversity, mature and local students. He left the army with the intention of becoming a nurse, but after the foundation year at Durham University's Stockton site, he discovered he had ability in science. webTitle: Is it ever all right for a teacher to hit a child?

fields.headline: Respect, please sir
fields.standfirst: Is it ever all right for a teacher to hit a child? asks  Children's Express
fields.trailText: Is it ever all right for a teacher to hit a child? asks Children's Express
fields.body:
Our generation has never known a time when corporal punishment was allowed, so it is difficult for us to understand that some teachers may feel poorly equipped now that the cane has gone. Most teachers, too, recognise the sanity of the 1987 legislation, which protects children's rights in the classroom. From our experience, it is a dwindling minority who still favour the clip around the ear or rap across the knuckles - though they may feel strengthened when cases such as headteacher Marjorie Evans' hit the headlines.

For most of the pupils we spoke to, the issue was not how children could be forced to behave better, but how teachers could be encouraged to treat their pupils better. Holly, 15, rejects corporal punishment. "It is wrong to hit kids; you could shout at them, give them detention, but you shouldn't hit them." Most pupils respect their teachers, she believes, but warns, "if the teacher is cheeky to them, they'll be cheeky back."

Primary school student Conor, 10, agrees: "As we grow up we become more unruly and less like sheep."

By the time pupils reach adolescence, they will react very badly to a teacher who tries to control them. "As young people grow and start developing into adults they are going to push the teacher and try to get independence," says 17-year-old schoolboy Ryan, "and teachers try, in a sense, to take this independence away." This only causes trouble, he thinks, if there are problems at home: "Sometimes young people push to the absolute limits, sometimes maybe it is to get a thrill to see what the teacher is going to do, but basically, it depends on the child's background. If the child knows that their parents will do nothing, he or she will continually push."

Ryan believes that those students who constantly land themselves in trouble need counselling, not more punishment. "Parents and schools have to work in partnership when a child's behaviour becomes an issue."

According to some of the young people we interviewed, physical reprimand is still sometimes used in the classroom (and they weren't talking about duster lobbing or a little arm grabbing - none of which was considered threatening, but simply a sign that a teacher had "lost their cool").

For lower-sixth student Drew, 17, it all boils down to mutual respect.

"Teachers who are very calm and talk things through are the best. They get more respect because you can relate to them and be on more of an equal footing," he says.

The message being clearly written on the blackboard by young people is that they want an ounce of respect and their views to be heard.

 Children's Express is a programme of learning through journalism for eight- to 18-year-olds. This piece is by Mairead Duffy, 15, Marguerite McNiel, 15, Drew Mikhael, 17, Michael Leathem, 14 and Thomas Kielty, 15.
