webTitle: David Blunkett: The government's new package for parents

fields.headline: Partners in time
fields.standfirst: Ever wondered what your child actually does at school? All will be revealed as  David Blunkett unveils the government's new package for parents
fields.trailText: Ever wondered what your child actually does at school? All will be revealed as David Blunkett unveils the government's new package for parents
fields.body:
Until a decade ago, education was a secret garden for many parents. While most parents now know something of their school's exam results and inspection reports, there has been a glaring gap in understanding what is actually being taught to youngsters through the curriculum in different phases of education. Today we hope to fill the gap.

Mori research last year found that a third of parents did not feel very confident talking to teachers about their children's work or supporting their children doing their homework. When we talked further to parents, we found they wanted to know more about what goes on day to day in school; and with the right tips, many are more than willing to play a bigger role. Over 40% of parents asked for practical help with maths and 30% wanted guidance on how to encourage children to do their homework.

That is why Tony Blair and I are launching a new package of materials for parents today, backed by national TV advertising. The package includes guides to the new national curriculum, special practical subject leaflets, a revamped parents' website and a new termly parents' magazine.

Parents are a child's first educator. But whilst parents' role in pre-school is widely recognised, support provided in the home can also make a real difference as children go through school.

I know sometimes people say government tries to preach or nanny people too much. But today's campaign is the exact opposite of that approach. It offers a practical guide to the curriculum and tips for those parents who want them. Arming parents with the facts about what's happening in their children's school not only gives them the chance to play a part at home, it empowers them to play a supportive role at school with teachers, too; and it narrows the gap between "those in the know" and those unfamiliar with the complexities of the education system.

We found that this worked in the National Year of Reading and Maths Year 2000, when millions of leaflets offering practical tips were taken by parents, who told us how valuable they found them.

I also know there are some parents who make life a misery for teachers: either by failing to ensure children turn up for classes or by verbally and even physically abusing teachers. We are tackling those problems. But the irresponsibility of a small minority of parents should not distract us from offering the majority of parents the practical support they want.

The campaign will use a number of approaches to help parents overcome their concerns about getting more involved in their children's education.

The Parents' Guides to the National Curriculum show parents just what their children learn at school and how they can help. There are three guides: one for parents of three- to seven-year-olds, one for parents of seven- to 11-year-olds, and one for parents of secondary pupils [see parents' reviews below].

The guides offer all sorts of ideas for parents, for example when your child has just started primary school, ask them specific questions. What have they done well at? What is more difficult? This helps parents to see what a child is doing and helps children to think about their work.

There are plenty of everyday situations where parents can help children aged seven to 11. If they get a takeaway, for instance, they can let their child plan it. Give them a certain amount to spend and see if they succeed in ordering what everyone wants without breaking the budget!

For teenagers, revision for exams is best if it's active. Try getting your child to take you through the main points - it is a really good way of consolidating learning.

Parents can pick the guides up from schools and libraries, order a free copy (08000 96 66 26) or find them on the web. Parents, children and teachers have "road-tested" the guides, and most teaching unions back them, too.

We are also publishing a magazine. Parents and Schools magazine will address topical issues - its first issue looks at how to tackle bullying, offers advice on literacy and numeracy and using the internet safely. It is an easy way for busy parents to find out about important school issues. It will be available from retail outlets, including Sainsbury's, Morrisons, Budgens and Lloyds Pharmacies, and from libraries and doctors' surgeries or by calling 0800 389 3899.

From today our parents' website is being expanded, giving parents more access to the web. The site includes information on all aspects of education - from bullying and school meals to the curriculum. Its search facility allows parents to hunt for a school in their area and check its results. An interactive map gives information about interesting days out for children - from theme parks and pop concerts to city farms and medieval tournaments. The site is www.parents.dfee.gov.uk.

Next week we are holding a parents online week (September 18-22). Most schools now have internet access and children are picking up computer and internet skills in the classroom. But computers can be daunting for parents who feel left behind by new technology. Parents online week will give parents a chance to see what computers can do for their family and their children's education.

A further plank of the campaign is the publication of the first 12 topic guides, which will arm parents with essential information on popular school topics, such as: electricity, Romans or plants. For example, the Romans leaflet gives ideas for places to visit, and shows you how to make a Roman mosaic with your child. The leaflets can be found on the web at www.parents.dfee.gov.uk/discover

Taken together, this package opens education to parents in a way which we hope will engage many who may have been put off getting involved in school. Ministers have long said that parents are essential partners in their children's education - with this extra practical support, we are helping to turn that slogan into a reality.

 David Blunkett is Secretary of State for Education and Employment.

fields.headline: My inspiration
fields.standfirst: Adam Hart-Davis
fields.trailText: Adam Hart-Davis
fields.body:
 Adam Hart-Davis, 57, is a presenter of TV science programmes. His latest series, What the Romans Did for Us, begins in November.

I was brought up in a remote farmhouse near Henley that had been lent to my parents when they were evacuated from London during the early part of the war. My sister was nine years older than me and my brother seven, so I was clearly a mistake. My parents claimed I was the result of a celebration in 1942, but I never quite worked out what event I have to thank for my existence.

"I can clearly remember my first day at the local infants' school. My mum came to collect me at 3.30pm and I told her, 'I've done that'. I thought that you only went to school for one day and I was astonished to find I had to go back. Otherwise my lasting memories are of the foul-smelling outside loos and of a rather dreamy character I sat next to in the painting class.

"When I was eight years old my parents sent me to St Andrew's, a Victorian gothic pile doubling as a boys' boarding school near Pangbourne. I was always academically able, though I feel my real talent was for passing exams, although I did once manage just 3% in a history exam and went on to fail my history O-level.

"The deputy head was a former cricketer, Raymond Robertson-Glasgow, who left me with no enthusiasm for the game but did instil a deep love of reading. My father was always profoundly unhelpful if I asked him what was worth reading; he'd point to his library of 20,000 books and tell me to choose one myself. Robertson-Glasgow used to read anything from 1066 and All That to The Pit and The Pendulum out loud to us on Sunday mornings, and I loved it.

"My real inspiration, though, was a small, frog-like Canadian called Mr Turner who taught me maths and science. He was quite strict but he took the trouble to encourage me outside normal lessons. If I'd finished a set of problems, he'd get me to do something more advanced. Once he gave me a picture of Pascal's triangle and asked me what I made of it. I didn't have a clue, but it was flattering to be asked. When I was leaving he beetled up to me and said: "I've got just one thing to say - science." As I've made a career out of science, his words must have had some impact.

"I went on to Eton, which I both loved and hated. I took my academic work rather seriously, which wasn't always the case with pupils there. But then if you're going off to be king or work in daddy's merchant bank, perhaps schoolwork isn't quite so important. I had a wonderful physics teacher, Jack Goodier, who helped me get a scholarship to Oxford, but my lasting impressions of the school were of staying at Number 10 with a friend, David Douglas-Home, when his father was prime minister, and stealing some of the writing paper.

"Before I went to Oxford, I spent a year in India teaching for VSO. It was a truly wonderful experience and, to be honest, that was the point when I felt my life had really begun."

webTitle: Cool school: St John the Baptist school, Woking

fields.headline: C'est bon, n'est-ce pas?
fields.trailText: St John the Baptist school, Woking
fields.body:
El éxito en negocio requiere el entrenamiento y la disciplina y el duro trabajo - and in the future, being able to understand this David Rockefeller quotation will be a big help, too.

Pupils at St John the Baptist school in Woking are beginning to realise this. They know that the ability to speak a foreign language not only helps on holiday, but also makes you infinitely more employable.

The school recently won a European language award from the Centre for Information on Language Teaching and Research. The judges praised the way in which languages are infused into all areas of the curriculum. It's not unusual for a maths lesson to be conducted in German, for example, or a skeleton labelled in French during a biology lesson. As part of a recent design and technology project, pupils made pop-up books written in a variety of languages.

A significant part of this is the "international week", which has been held at the school in June/July for the past three years. Thanks to the work of Mary Dingle, co-ordinator, the week now attracts many speakers and uses different methods to show that languages are enjoyable as well as invaluable in the new European context.

The fun aspects are communicated during the week through such games as "bridge the gap". In teams, pupils answer questions about Europe - a correct response earns a token, which is used to build a bridge from Britain to France. The first one to Calais wins.

In the past Sir Anthony Meyer, a former Tory MP, has helped year 12 pupils to participate in a mock European parliamentary election. British Airways has made a presentation to year 8 classes, emphasising that having another language is essential in today's air industry. Mr Fuhrig, of the Goethe Institute, has used games to demonstrate the importance of other languages and cultures.

Dingle says that to get speakers to attend the week, it is simply a matter of asking them. She tries to introduce new elements each year, and hopes to boast an international footballer next year. "I approached Chelsea football club, who said they'd be very keen to be involved but as it coincided with Euro 2000, it wasn't feasible. But I'm optimistic of getting them involved next year, which would particularly interest the boys."

Not all events revolve around outside speakers. The school canteen was transformed during European cafe day and staff dressed in the national costumes of France, Germany and Italy. Pupils then had to order what they wanted in the appropriate language.

While international week mainly focuses on Europe, the school also aims to raise awareness of the rest of the world. A Japanese intern visits the school annually for six months, teaching the language, culture and even the odd martial arts lesson. Dingle realises that pupils will not all be fluent Japanese speakers at the end of this, but she says this is all part of "immersing pupils in other cultures".

This approach has paid dividends. Dingle reports that there is a bigger uptake of languages at GCSE level, with improved results and more pupils continuing their studies post-16. This is partly because the school makes it possible to combine languages with other options.

In line with this philosophy, St John offers GNVQ programmes with a language option. Dr Holgar Briel from Surrey University's linguistics department spoke to year 12 and 13 pupils about the opportunities in higher education to combine languages with law, business, etc.

Ani Magill, headteacher at St John, points out that many commentators warn that Britain still has a distinct lack of people with the necessary knowledge of languages to compete in today's industries. Over the next 20 years, the world market is set to alter dramatically - Mandarin and Spanish, for instance, will be the languages of the future.

The study of a foreign language can help you to win friends and influence people - or at least those under 16. This year Stephen Fawkes, a senior education officer and project manager for the BBC, opened the international week by singing a Spice Girls song - entirely in French.

Pupils at St John the Baptist school in Woking are beginning to realise this. They know that the ability to speak a foreign language not only helps on holiday, but also makes you infinitely more employable. The school recently won a European language award from the Centre for Information on Language Teaching and Research. The judges praised the way in which languages are infused into all areas of the curriculum. It's not unusual for a maths lesson to be conducted in German, for example, or a skeleton labelled in French during a biology lesson. As part of a recent design and technology project, pupils made pop-up books written in a variety of languages. A significant part of this is the "international week", which has been held at the school in June/July for the past three years. Thanks to the work of Mary Dingle, co-ordinator, the week now attracts many speakers and uses different methods to show that languages are enjoyable as well as invaluable in the new European context. The fun aspects are communicated during the week through such games as "bridge the gap". In teams, pupils answer questions about Europe - a correct response earns a token, which is used to build a bridge from Britain to France. The first one to Calais wins. In the past Sir Anthony Meyer, a former Tory MP, has helped year 12 pupils to participate in a mock European parliamentary election. British Airways has made a presentation to year 8 classes, emphasising that having another language is essential in today's air industry. Mr Fuhrig, of the Goethe Institute, has used games to demonstrate the importance of other languages and cultures. Dingle says that to get speakers to attend the week, it is simply a matter of asking them. She tries to introduce new elements each year, and hopes to boast an international footballer next year. "I approached Chelsea football club, who said they'd be very keen to be involved but as it coincided with Euro 2000, it wasn't feasible. But I'm optimistic of getting them involved next year, which would particularly interest the boys." Not all events revolve around outside speakers. Pupils then had to order what they wanted in the appropriate language. While international week mainly focuses on Europe, the school also aims to raise awareness of the rest of the world. A Japanese intern visits the school annually for six months, teaching the language, culture and even the odd martial arts lesson. Dingle realises that pupils will not all be fluent Japanese speakers at the end of this, but she says this is all part of "immersing pupils in other cultures". This approach has paid dividends. Dingle reports that there is a bigger uptake of languages at GCSE level, with improved results and more pupils continuing their studies post-16. webTitle: Vialli victim of Chelsea player power

fields.headline: Vialli victim of Chelsea player power
fields.standfirst: Italian pays the price for his failures in man-management
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli yesterday paid the price for becoming a clone of the man he grew to hate, the man who was manager before him, Ruud Gullit.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli yesterday paid the price for becoming a clone of the man he grew to hate, the man who was manager before him, Ruud Gullit.

Chelsea's decision to sack Vialli was largely precipitated by his distant and insensitive treatment of players, especially Gianfranco Zola, which came straight from the Gullit manual of man-management. Such behaviour played a major part in the Dutchman's downfall. Now it has done for Vialli.

Chelsea will seek a replacement who can not only inspire the team as a person but bring the sort of success to Stamford Bridge that their millionaire status demands. The bookmakers have made Zola favourite, though Chelsea may now be tempted to go for someone with a proven track record. There has also long been speculation that George Graham is destined for the Stamford Bridge hot-seat.

The axe fell on Vialli without warning. The day began with news that Chelsea had made an inquiry about signing Vialli's friend and former Juventus team-mate Paolo di Canio from West Ham. But by the afternoon Vialli himself had become the story. He was summoned to a meeting with the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates and the managing director Colin Hutchinson at 5pm yesterday, and it was decided to terminate the Italian's contract forthwith.

If the move was swift when it came, it was hardly a complete shock. Chelsea's results have been disappointing by the club's newly adopted high standards. After finishing third in the Premiership two years ago, Vialli could only manage fifth last season, not only failing to win the title, but missing out on a lucrative Champions League place as well.

Bates showed his impatience with Chelsea's inconsistent domestic form last season and there was also criticism of Vialli's insistence on rotating his strikers.

This summer, in an attempt to meet Bates's aspirations, Vialli promised to direct all his efforts and those of the team to lifting the Premiership title. He was given £23m to spend on players to underpin that pledge but the season went wrong almost as soon as it started.

Unrest among players both present and recently departed began to surface in the press. Frank Lebeouf, Didier Deschamps and Dan Petrescu all voiced their unhappiness at the way the club was being managed. And the stress began to show in fractured performances on the field.

Chelsea have managed one win in their five games this season leaving them a disappointing 10th in the table - a dismal record which includes surrendering a two-goal lead at home to Arsenal and losing to the Premiership's poor relations, Bradford City.

But it was Vialli's treatment of Zola which upset the Chelsea hierarchy. The striker could not understand why a man whom he once classed as a friend changed so much once he took charge of Chelsea in February 1998, his first managerial role.

Suddenly Vialli started to blank Zola and drop him without explanation. It may have been an attempt to avoid charges of favouritism and to separate himself from his old team-mates now he was in charge. But it was insensitive and unsuccessful.

Yesterday the only player to speak up in support of Vialli was Chelsea's England left-back Graeme le Saux who said: "All the players are shocked and no one had any idea this was happening."

Chelsea would only supply an official statement, but that also intimated that Vialli's exit was about more than the team's performance on the field. "Chelsea have great admiration for the achievements of Gianluca Vialli in his two-and-a-half years in charge of team affairs and would like to place on record our appreciation for his services to Chelsea Football Club," said the official release. "However, the club feels that in a wider context it is in our best interests to seek a change of direction."

Vialli now joins the list of great players who struggled to translate their skills into management. He won two league titles and a European Cup while playing in Italy, but at Stamford Bridge he could not bring home either - and neither did he look like doing so. The European Cup Winners' Cup, FA Cup and Worthington Cup that he did manage were not enough to satisfy Chelsea's demand for prestige or their craving for revenue.

The club said that an announcement on Vialli's successor will be made in due course. For the immediate future the current staff, including Graham Rix and Ray Wilkins, will take charge of the team, beginning with tomorrow's Uefa Cup tie against St Gallen.

Bridge of sighs and sideswipes

'Errors of judgment have been made with the rotation system [but] it's also down to the players' attitude when they go out on the pitch'
Ken Bates, Nov 1999

'Vialli has problems with everybody, with Albert Ferrer and many others. It's normal for a coach to get on with his lads, but not him'
Frank Leboeuf, August 2000

'The fans wanted me to play but Vialli didn't. And his word is final. Vialli never said anything to me but the message was very clear'
Dan Petrescu, August 2000

'You could imagine the effect inside the Chelsea dressing room. This kind of thing is poison to team spirit and, with things how they are at Chelsea, simply disastrous'
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink (after Arsenal pulled back two-goal deficit, Sept 6)

'I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became'
Didier Deschamps, August 2000

'At the end of the day it is going to make us a better side. We have to aim for the Champions League'
Peter Osgood, yesterday

fields.headline: Wenger predicts progress at last
fields.trailText: Arséne Wenger believes his team's fate will be decided in the home games, which makes tonight's Group B opener away to Sparta Prague look decisive.
fields.body:
With due respect to the InterToto Cup, the real European business starts tonight. Over the next two days England's trio of Champions League sides go into battle with one eye on the points column and the other on the bank balance. Welcome back to football's Who Wants To Be A Multi-Millionaire?

The glitz and glamour are supposed to be unmistakable. But ask the audience and many will suggest the "Champions" tag is ridiculous and the format bloated. The holders Real Madrid started at the Bernabeu in front of 15,000 last year. Arsenal get under way at Sparta Prague this evening having sold only 675 of their 1,200 tickets.

Seats in the away end for Leeds's visit to Barcelona tomorrow will be harder to find than the Dennis Bergkamp School of Flying. But then the Nou Camp is slightly more glamorous than the 20,000-seat Letna Stadium, where Arsenal begin their attempt to make it third time lucky by progressing to the next round.

This is a competition Arsène Wenger believes he can win but past experience - and Arsenal's previous Champions League openers - goes some way to explaining why. Nwankwo Kanu missed a late penalty in a 0-0 draw at Fiorentina last September; Lens scored a 90th-minute equaliser in France the year before.

And, although Wenger remarked yesterday that his team's fate will be decided in the home games - finally being played at Highbury rather than Wembley - this match looks decisive.

If Lazio are the obvious group favourites and Ukraine's Shakhtar Donetsk look likely to pick up one of the world's more lucrative wooden spoons, Arsenal and Sparta appear certain to fight it out for second spot. Wenger does not sound short of confidence.

"I have been happy with the spirit and the way we have played but not with the points," he said. "We should be top of the league frankly, without a problem. I keep positive that we have the potential and spirit to do well. We have an inner strength."

It says much for Wenger's belief that he sees his team as potential winners of this trophy. He feels Lazio are the strongest side and puts Arsenal just behind a main pack in which he also includes Barcelona, Bayern Munich and Manchester United.

The abandonment of Wembley should help because on their travels Arsenal have already looked at home. In six away games their only defeat came two seasons ago at Dynamo Kiev. It was defeats by Fiorentina and Barcelona at Wembley last year which, more than anything, cost them.

Their defence remains a problem but Wenger knows that already. The German Kicker magazine yesterday claimed that Arsenal are the mystery club behind a big-money bid for Bayer Leverkusen's German international defender Jens Novotny.

Sparta's quality is relatively unknown to Wenger, who has had them watched only once. Knocked out in the second phase of last season's competition, they defeated Zimbru Chisinau of Moldova to reach this stage and have won all five of their league matches.

Three of their key players have departed for Germany since the summer and two young stars are at the Olympics. Much of the danger is likely to be posed by the 20-year-old midfielder Tomas Rosicky, who played for the Czech Republic at Euro 2000.

Patrick Vieira returns for Arsenal despite his league suspension but Wenger will be without Tony Adams, Lauren and Bergkamp. He has doubts over Parlour (knee) and Silvinho (thigh) and, if the Brazilian fails to recover, the 19-year-old Ashley Cole will get a first European start.

Sparta Prague (4-5-1, possible): Postulka; Bolf, J Novotny, Hasek, P Novotny; Jarosik, Svoboda, Flachbart, Obajdin, Rosicky; Siegl.

Arsenal (4-4-2, possible): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Keown, Silvinho; Parlour, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry.

fields.headline: The best imposter scene
fields.standfirst: X-men
fields.trailText: X-men
fields.body:
The near future. Mutants Rogue (Anna Paquin) and Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) are being trained by Profesor Xavier (Patrick Stewart) at his academy. The previous day, entirely by accident, Wolverine had accidentally stabbed his young friend - and the only way she could save herself was by draining him of his power to heal. Both are now recuperating.

Rogue is in the garden of Xavier's school when she is approached by Bobby (Shawn Ashmore), a boy in her class on whom she has a crush. He nods as he stands before her.

"Rogue."

"Bobby."

He sits beside her on the bench.

"Rogue, what did you do? They say you're stealing other people's powers..."

"No, no, I borrowed his power."

Bobby looks enraged.

"You never use your power against another mutant."

"But I had no choice... you don't understand."

He shrugs.

"Listen, the students are freaked. Professor Xavier is furious - I don't know what I'd do with you."

She looks hurt.

"I think", he continues, "it would be easier on your own."

"Yeah?"

"You should go."

She walks away. Cut to the real Bobby, talking with his friends - just as the figure on the bench transforms into Mystique (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos), the shape-changing mutant beholden to the evil Magneto...

See also: Spellbound, Some Like It Hot, Six Degrees Of Separation, The Impostors

Don't see also: Sommersby

Pointless trivia: Anna Paquin has never seen the whole of The Piano (for which she won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar in 1993).
